speech.para: I was informed by the opposition whip that there was a proposal from the government to recommit this particular division, and that was one that I readily agreed to. I think you would know, Madam Chair, that the opposition has consistently taken the view that we need to have the will of the Senate accurately reflected in votes of the Senate. I believe, and the opposition believes, that that is a very important principle. It did not take place, in my view, in relation to this division.

I accept, as I am sure all senators would, that there were mistakes made in that division. There were mistakes made, and we understand that these things happen from time to time. We also accept, by the way, that mistakes are made on both sides, which was the case in that particular division.

When you have a situation like that, the best thing to occur is for the whips to try to sort it out while the division is actually being counted. That did not happen in that particular division. That is the weakness. In fact, the acting government whip received instructions from Senator Campbell in relation to what ought to occur because, as I understand it, we had a situation where Senator Colston's vote was counted, and that was germane to the division result.

The government's original proposal for a recommittal of the vote is far more sensible and more proper in terms of the processes and procedures in this place than to suggest at the end of the day that a couple of foul-ups occurred that might not have made any difference to the vote. That is a much less preferred course of action. The voting in the division would have been different. In other words, it would not have had equal voting between the ayes and the noes. At the end of the day, I do not believe there would have been any difference in relation to the opposition amendment that was negatived. The question before the chair would still have been negatived. However, the votes would have been different.

This is an important principle. I am disappointed to hear the contribution of the government whip on this because, as far as the opposition is concerned, we believe that the will of the Senate ought to be reflected in votes on the floor, and I think recommittal would have been a much more sensible course of action in a circumstance where Senator Hill missed a division and these other knock-on effects took place.

I am sorry the government has changed its mind in that regard. I do not consider that good practice. I do not think that is a good precedent, and it certainly will not be treated as a precedent by the opposition. If mistakes occur, if they occur on both sides or on either side—in this case I think there were mistakes on both sides—we should do it again so the whips get an opportunity to sort it out. That way we do not have a situation where there is an attempt on the floor to sort these issues out between the government whip and the Manager of Government Business. That is not the way we ought to behave in this chamber.

I would ask the government to reflect seriously on what I have had to say about the good sense in this circumstance of a recommittal. It is not good enough for the government to say that the result would have been the same, even though voting might have been different. We want to accurately reflect the will of the Senate so that there is absolute integrity in the Senate's decision making processes.

talk.start.para: —by leave—On the vote that is being discussed, I just want to query whether the government can indicate whether Senator Colston's vote was counted and whether that means from now on Senator Colston's vote will be counted with the government.

—by leave—The position is that, if Senator Colston is sitting on our side, he is counted. That has to be done. We have to count him. That is in the standing orders. Normally, if we do not wish to accept his vote, one of our people leaves the chamber—and in that particular case it did happen. Unfortunately, Senator Hill had applied for a pair and it was not communicated to the chamber.

—by leave—The next question of course is: in subsequent votes, will the government accept the vote of Senator Colston or, as has been done in the past, will they send somebody out from the chamber to balance out that vote? This is what I am trying to find out: has that principle changed, or is the government suggesting it was a one-off occasion?
—by leave—There will be no change to the way in which we have been acting. We will be continuing to act in the same way as we have before regarding Senator Colston. There will be no change.
—You have accepted his vote on two occasions this week. Check the Hansard .

—by leave—In relation to the issue that we are speaking of—that is, the division on the request for amendment 5 on sheet 864—I believe Senator Calvert, the government whip, has indicated the vote was taken at 11.07 a.m. I ask that the division be taken again in respect of that opposition request. That is a far more preferable course of action in this circumstance. It is consistent with past practice and consistent with proper practice in this place.
—Is leave granted?
—No.

—by leave—Senator Faulkner is absolutely right. If the government is going to show propriety in this matter, the vote should be recommitted. The government needs to think this over. If it does not, it will be clearly seen to be breaching a public commitment about the vote of Senator Colston, and it will be clearly seen to have breached that because it was a politically important matter—that is, the government's commitment not to count the vote of Senator Colston can be breached when the matter is important enough and when it is convenient enough for the government.

speech.para: Senator Faulkner is really offering the government the opportunity to hold good to its word. The opposition is saying to the government, `Here's an opportunity to keep faith with your public commitment not to count the vote of Senator Colston.' That is what it boils down to. We can debate it all day, but that is how it will be seen.

I think it is a generosity from the opposition that the offer has been made, and I think all components of the Senate should ensure, as Senator Faulkner has put it, that the vote be recorded as we—and that includes the government—all want it.

Senator Faulkner says the outcome in terms of the legislative impact of that vote will not differ. That is all the more reason why the opposition should be congratulated for giving the government and the Senate the opportunity to recommit this vote and make sure it is properly counted, and that the actual wish of all sides in terms of how that vote is registered in the Hansard for good is how it is registered. I think the government is spiting itself if it does not accept this offer to recommit the vote. That is up to it. Let that be, if that is what the government wants.

talk.start.para: —They are accepting it. I am not. The government wants to have it recommitted.

—Then let me say the same applies to you, Senator Harradine. You are a stickler for form in the Senate. You have always shown generosity in correcting votes when they are wrong. One only has to say, `Well, why not, Senator Harradine?' If you make this exception, where does it end?

speech.para: There is discontent in the Senate with the vote as it is recorded because a mistake has been made on both sides. You would be true to form, Senator Harradine, if you allowed the matter to be cleared up. It would go counter to your form—and indeed your asseverations and strictures to me on many occasions in this place to show goodwill—if you yourself were not to show that goodwill and allow this vote to be recommitted, and allow yourself to be free of any contention that you, for whatever reason, may see political advantage in not allowing the majority in this place to express their wish that there be a recommittal of that vote.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I understand what has occurred. I understand that the vote would have been one-up for the government had Senator Bolkus's vote not been taken when in fact he was paired.
—But Senator Hill too, Senator Harradine.
—Yes, I understand that Senator Hill was in that same situation.
—That is the whole point I am making. It was not an accurate reflection of the will of the Senate.
—That is right, but the Senate now knows, and it is there ingrained in the records of the Senate, what the situation was. I see no purpose under those circumstances in having a recommittal.
—We have always done it when a vote has been fouled up through inadvertence.

—The advice I have from the clerks is that on previous occasions there has only been a revote when it actually changes the result of the vote rather than the personnel. That is the advice I have been given.

—by leave—That may be the advice you are given, but we will never know what the result of a revote will be until it is carried out. It may be contended that it could change a vote if a new vote is taken, but you do not know until a new vote is taken. You cannot gainsay what a vote in this place will be, and that is one of the important reasons why this vote should be taken again and recorded properly.

—by leave—The opposition consistently has argued in the case of divisions that, if there have been circumstances that have led to votes being recorded which do not accurately reflect the will of the Senate, then we ought to ensure that we go through the processes again so that no individual senator—nor, for that matter, no political party, government or opposition—is disadvantaged.

speech.para: That is a longstanding principle. I think it is important. I have suggested a course of action. It has not been accepted. So be it.
Progress reported.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 December 1997, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats will be supporting the Criminal Code Amendment Bill 1997 [1998] . I note that on 2 February 1995, in considering the Crimes Amendment Bill 1994, the Australian Democrats' former Senator Sid Spindler set out the issue. He stated:

speech.para: One particular provision I would like to address is the so-called Majewski issue . . . that evidence of self-induced intoxication cannot be considered in determining whether the conduct was voluntary. The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General decided to follow the UK decision in Majewski (1977) AC 480 that evidence of intoxication can be used to deny intention or recklessness in offences of specific intent, such as murder, but cannot be used as an excuse in relation to simple offences of basic intent, such as assault.

This section, which is now being passed in the bills before the Senate, would place the Commonwealth in line with the law in England, Canada, the United States, Queensland, WA, Tasmania, and the Northern Territory. However, it alters the common law in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT, where gross intoxication may be taken into account in relation to all offences as a result of the High Court's decision in O'Connor in 1980. This is one of the provisions of the bills which was very carefully examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. While we express some concern about the change in law, the Australian Democrats have decided to support it.

The Australian Democrats still support this legislation. We also support the introduction of these provisions around Australia. I understand that the effect of these provisions, or these kinds of provisions, may mean that the prosecution does not need to prove intention where it is alleged that the accused was intoxicated.

I accept that this is changing the requirement to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused intended the act and that it was voluntary. However, I think all of us here today have had to weigh up this aspect of the bill against the effects of violent crimes in our society related to self-induced intoxication. The meeting ground is Majewski, which preserves the requirement for the prosecution to prove intention in serious crimes where civil liberties are significantly at risk.

I find this distinction a difficult one, probably a bit tenuous at times; however, I am reassured that this is an exceptional defence plea. It cannot apply in negligence cases, and it is not part of the offence in strict liability cases. Further, the accused could be subjected to civil actions where it is not necessary to prove criminal intent.

I am advised that the recent decision in the Australian Capital Territory—we all know now about a case involving a footballer who was intoxicated and assaulted three women, including his wife—would have been different under the law in this bill because the footballer would have been unable to use the particular evidence of intoxication as was used. The Democrats think that it is appropriate that that cannot be used.

I welcome a law which seeks to address this situation and I dearly hope that the remaining states and territories will enact similar laws very soon. However, I am also concerned that excessive self-intoxication is a social problem. We need to recognise that we have a responsibility to address social problems through appropriate community actions, which are not always or necessarily addressed by criminalising that problem. This provision, and similar provisions, must not become the remedy that we apply to drug and alcohol abuses which are linked with violence.

I should note that domestic violence is a significant problem in our communities, and it is one we must address. We have a culture of physical conflict solving and it is usually, or very often, women who become the victims. Intoxication is a component of much of this violence even though it may not end up in the courts. I believe that this culture re quires attention, and the need for these sorts of laws is a flagging for attention.

The Democrats support this bill and I ask the government to consider further the social needs that make this law necessary. I should add that domestic violence and violence against women are only partly addressed by today's law.

talk.start.para: —The opposition also supports this legislation. The legislation has become necessary through the defence at common law established by the High Court in O'Connor's case. The defence ensures that those who may be criminally liable have an excuse for the offence if the offence was committed whilst the person was in such a state of intoxication that they were incapable of forming the intention to commit the offence.

speech.para: This issue has raised a number of different aspects of a range of issues. The starting point with respect to criminality requires, in most circumstances, if not the overwhelming number, a specific intention. To that extent the High Court established the O'Connor defence.

The trouble is that the High Court's judgment was one of concern that was addressed by the previous government. It was addressed in a manner that really appreciated particularly domestic violence situations and appreciated that the defence at common law was too wide in terms of protecting many innocent people.

During the term of the previous government, the Commonwealth Criminal Code was developed and that code developed a situation which ensured that the defence of intoxication would be removed. However, in the interests of uniformity, the Criminal Code Act 1995 provided that all these provisions would not commence until March 2000. This has been brought on by the Noa Nadruku case in the most recent instance where Noa was availed of the defence of intoxication with respect to the charges in the Supreme Court of the ACT. At that time, the Minister for the Status of Women and the Attorney-General both criticised the ACT and any other jurisdictions which were yet to remove the defence of intoxication. They should have appreciated that that defence was to be removed in a uniform approach across the country as part of the model Criminal Code. This matter has brought it on at a faster rate.

The opposition sees this legislation as bringing forward by two years an act which would have taken effect in March 2000. As I said at the time in response to the Nadruku case, there is no reason at this particular stage of the development of the model Criminal Code for this defence to be allowed to continue any longer. In that context, the opposition supports this legislation and recommends that the Criminal Code Amendment Bill 1997 [1998] be supported.

talk.start.para: —The Criminal Code Amendment Bill 1997 [1998] is supported around the Senate and is a bill where the sense of outrage overcomes the logic behind the criminal law. It is a central concept in criminal law that people should only be punished for what they intend. The logic behind O'Connor's case and behind the defence of drunkenness is that a person who is so drunk that he or she cannot form an intention should not be punished for what he or she does. This bill makes an exception to that very fundamental idea that underpins the criminal law.

speech.para: It is interesting to note that the defence of drunkenness is very rarely successful and today we are impinging on the criminal law to cure a matter that is not all that frequently successful. The thing that worries me is that if this were the beginning of a trend to punish people irrespective of what they intended to do so that the nature of the act becomes the thing that draws the punishment, then we are changing the criminal law in a very dangerous way. I sound that note of warning on this occasion. In the light of a particular case—it might have been more than one case—or in the light of very few cases, we have become so outraged that we are changing the basis of the criminal law in a particular respect and it would be a very dangerous trend if that were to go any further. In fact, it is a very dangerous trend as it is and is one that ought to be kept in check.

In my view, if we go down the path of a law and order campaign and, as a result of that, do injustice to people, then our moral sense as people in a society which respects the moral basis for wrongful acts is usurped. Let us hope in the hereafter that we do not go to places of punishment for things we do not intend. Let us hope while we are still on this earth that we do not go too often to gaol for things that we do not intend.

talk.start.para: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution. From memory, I think Senator Cooney and I shared the same law school. I well heed the warning in his contribution. Of course, I also identify very closely with the comment that was made by Senator Stott Despoja that women around Australia have been very concerned at the implications for them from people who have taken action as a result of drunkenness which has led to a lot of pain, anguish and worry for women.

speech.para: There are a lot of straws in the wind in any good legislating and a lot of issues to be canvassed. The relevance of the Criminal Code Amendment Bill 1997 [1998] is really that it has support across parties. It is something that the country recognises is needed and I thank you for your support.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 27 November 1997, on motion by Senator Ellison:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Schacht, the shadow minister, I indicate that the opposition supports the passage of the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 .
—I thank Senator Forshaw for his contribution. I also thank the opposition for its support of this measure.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 13 December 1996, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I want to make a very brief contribution to the debate on the Flags Amendment Bill 1996 . I think the Senate will be relieved that the government has finally got its act together and brought the legislation before the Senate. It was introduced in June 1996 and passed through the House of Representatives later that year. It is a piece of legislation that has been in the ether for 12 months or more.

speech.para: I think it is proper to say that this legislation is the culmination of work undertaken by the then opposition who, over a period of in excess of a decade, brought forward quite a number of private members' bills with similar objectives to the legislation we have before us. Given that circumstance and if it is of such importance and priority to the government, I am surprised that it has taken so long to come before us. Nevertheless, we do have a capacity to deal with it now. I think senators will agree that it is an important piece of legislation.

This legislation amendments the Australian Flag Act 1953 to require a vote by the Australian electorate for the Australian national flag to be altered and to ensure that the existing flag is one of the options that must be put to the Australian people. I am not entirely convinced that this legislation is necessary. Like the national song referendum in 1977, any sensible government would put such an issue to the Australian people and give them a voice. That is important in relation to the choice of the national flag.

It has consistently been the position of the Labor Party that, whatever occurs, it is essential that we have a thorough debate about the alternatives and that public awareness and involvement be encouraged to the maximum extent. That will be very important in determining any possible alternative to the current flag. It is worth saying that the recent contribution by Ausflag has been useful in this debate about the flag. Frankly, I think it is very unlikely that any government would propose to change the Australian flag without the participation of the Australian people.

That is unlike the approach our forefathers took when the issue of the current flag was being dealt with. As many would acknowledge, for some in the community the issue in the debate over the flag has been the prominence of the Union Jack as the feature of our flag. This has been significantly debated in the context of an increasing number of Australians who are embracing an aspiration for an Australian republic. Naturally, people in the community do look at the issue of the appropriateness of the current design or a new design of flag. Some believe that a new flag could symbolise the Commonwealth of Australia becoming a republic.

I consider the move to a republic as the priority issue. I, along with many in the Labor Party, have argued pretty consistently that the issue of the Australian people determining whether or not we become a republic certainly ought to be dealt with before the issue of the flag. If it is the community's view that that should also be debated then that should be done after referendums are held in relation to an Australian republic.
I recall that on Anzac Day 1996 the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made a commitment to this particular legislation. He said at the time:
The new Federal Government is to take action, as promised, to protect our great national symbol, the Australian Flag.

Legislation will be introduced early in the life of the new Parliament . . . to ensure that the Australian Flag cannot be changed without the approval of all of the Australian people voting at a referendum or plebiscite.
This will mean that no politician, no political party and no special interest group will be able to tamper with the design of our flag.

I have indicated that it would be a very courageous government and a very courageous political party that would suggest that the Australian flag be changed in any way without full public debate, participation, consultation and a vote of the Australian people.
It is interesting to note that the rules that governed the competition for the design of the current flag in 1901 stated:
The Flag should be based on the British ensign, as the flags of the countries added to its fold, signalling to the beholder that it is an imperial ensign of the British Empire.
When the final design was chosen, interestingly enough, it had to be to submitted to the British government and—I remind the Senate—the British admiralty for approval.

I am certain that all senators in this chamber would believe that our flag is a very important, very significant—if not the most significant—symbol of our nation and our history as a nation. The arguments are presented to us that the Union Jack symbolises the history of the union of Scotland, England and Ireland. I would also point out that at no time has the design of the great flag of Great Britain been taken to its people. Its new design and ours were adopted without a referendum or plebiscite.

I believe the principle of the Australian people determining these issues is one of fundamental importance. I have indicated that the opposition does question the necessity for the legislation. In these circumstances and because I have great faith in the good sense of the Australian people on these issues—in fact, I have enough faith in Australian governments and politicians to believe that no-one would propose a course of action without that level of consultation and participation and that decision being firmly in the hands of the Australian people—

talk.start.para: —I don't think the Left had their heart in this one.

—You would not know. I am in a much better position than you to judge that, Senator Boswell, let's face it. That is why you will just have to take my word for it, if that is okay. I have adequate faith in politicians and government to believe that this course of action would be an absolute requirement in any case. With those few words—assuring the Senate that I do have my heart in this contribution—I indicate that the opposition will be supporting the legislation.

—I support the Flags Amendment Bill 1996 , but I do so as a means of clearing the decks for action. I, like everybody else here, move around the country a lot and the feedback I get is that there is enormous interest in the prospect of changing our flag to bring us into the 21st century and to give us a flag which more appropriately reflects Australia at the end of 20th century rather than at the start of the 20th century. The opinion polls are changing. It is not going to be long before they will be reflecting majority support for that course of action. I am sure they would have already had there been a clear consensus on what the alternative should be.

speech.para: The next thing for the government to do is commit itself to giving Australians an opportunity to take part in the design of a new flag which Australians can be proud of as we enter the next millennium. I think many Australians would feel that, for example, the Olympics would be a great time to have a new flag symbolising this country and for people to feel that Australia is no longer part of the British empire and secondary to anybody else but a clear, proud, independent part of the community of nations.

The question is: where to next? There ought to be government moves to give the designing of the flag to the people. The popularity of the Constitutional Convention shows that the Australian people want to be involved. We should now devise the means of allowing them to be involved. Those people who do not feel that a change in the flag is warranted or wanted at this time have nothing to fear.

My reading of it is that there is enormous interest in a new flag. You only have to see the reaction there is to newspaper and other media competitions or polls to allow people to vote on new flag designs to see how keen that interest is. Let us get on with devising a new flag—whether it is taking the current flag and simply removing the Union Jack and raising the Federation Star to complement and balance the Southern Cross to a new design. Let Australians take part in that process. Let the parliament take Australians into its confidence and start the process of allowing people to be involved in a move towards a new design which is going to give Australians the feeling of distinction which the Canadians get out of their new flag. It has been many decades since Canada dropped the Union Jack and the confusing symbolism of its old flag. It is time we did the same.

I am an enthusiast for this. Not all those people around me agree. Many people feel that flags are of no significance. I note that it was stated in the second reading speech that the Australian national flag is our oldest and most important national symbol. It is not. The country itself, the nature of its land forms, its wildlife, its flora and its indigenous people are much older and more enduring symbols than the flag that has been with us for 100 years. That is a point to dwell on. There is much more symbolism about a country than the pennant which is taken up a flag pole on ceremonial and other occasions. It is nevertheless part of how a country identifies itself. It is time for change in Australia. I am an enthusiast for that change. I would inveigle the government to next think about how it is going to put this across to the people.

talk.start.para: —As the National Party leader in the Senate, I wish to express the wholehearted support of National Party members everywhere for the Flags Amendment Bill 1996 . Under this legislation, the only way our national flag can change is by the express and direct vote of the Australian electors. No government, no matter what their numbers or their political colour, will be able to change the flag for whatever reason without referring it to the Australian people.

speech.para: This bill will be greatly welcomed by those sceptical of the recent claims by republicans that they are not interested in changing the flag. It will be greatly welcomed by those sceptical of the Labor Party's intention regarding the flag. Our national flag is an important symbol of our country. It should not be vulnerable to the whims of political factions. This bill removes the Australian flag from being the victim of factional trade-offs. It removes the flag from the clutches of the wealthy elite who would turn our system of government upside down and change the flag at the first opportunity.

It was one of my proudest achievements in this place when I moved a motion in this place to have two flags placed in the Senate chamber either side of the President's chair. There was a Labor government in power and there was a marvellous new building for politicians, yet there was no flag in the Senate chamber to remind us of who we are here to represent. It was left to the National Party to move that motion. Those flags have been with us ever since. The National Party will always stand firm to protect that flag.

The bill is a safeguard mechanism for a national icon. It restores ownership to the people represented by the flag. The Australian flag is the highest part of Parliament House. As we owe our position to the people of Australia so too should the flag. This bill sends a message that the heritage and symbols of our nation are not up for political sale. It guards against the faddishness and trendiness by trusting in the stability and commonsense of the Australian people.

From now on the flag will not be able to be toyed with by the likes of the Malcolm Turnbulls and the Janet Holmes a Courts of this world. Make no mistake, the Australian flag is under a lot of pressure. There is great wealth and power lined up against it. Mr Turnbull's company sponsored an exhibition of alternative flags. Mrs Holmes a Court has opened exhibitions of alternative flags put on by Ausflag—the group that wants to change the flag. Sponsors of the exhibition include multinational corporations and overseas companies spending money to change the Australian flag.

What should we expect next—a flag section in the multilateral agreement on investment? These are people and organisations of power and influence nationally and internationally. What hope is there for an old digger who wants to keep the flag he fought for if he is up against the elite? This bill is the hope. This bill is the digger's flag insurance against the chardonnay set. This bill is the equaliser. It sends a signal that the ultimate power within our system of government rests with the people. Wherever the flag is raised—from prestigious international sporting events to humble scout halls—it can now be raised with a greater sense of ownership than before.

There have been attempts to diminish, belittle and undermine important parts of our heritage and even to rewrite history. This leaves people feeling great unease as their past is taken away from them. Certainty and identity are lost in an already changeable world. But with this bill, Australians can at least say, with assurance of compliance, `Hands off our flag.'

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the government, I thank all senators for their contributions to this important debate on the Flags Amendment Bill 1996 . It has taken a lot longer than the government would have preferred for this bill to rise to the top of the Notice Paper . We are very pleased that it has come on today. To have a bill debated on Thursday lunch time—and I know Senator Conroy wants to go and have some lunch—
—I do.

—and so too does the Deputy President—requires all senators to agree that it be treated non-controversially. I think that sends a special message—particularly to those most vocal supporters of this bill—that senators from all corners of the Senate have agreed that it be dealt with on an entirely non-controversial basis, meaning there will be no divisions called. I think that sends a strong message. It shows that the government has carried through its important commitment to ensure that any potential change to a flag in the future will be dealt with democratically by all Australians.

speech.para: I am particularly proud to have been given carriage of this bill through the Senate, having represented Australia in international competitions under this flag and my grandfather having fought in wars under this flag and indeed having the Australian flag draped over his coffin when he was buried. I know many Australians feel very strongly about the Australian flag. I know this legislation will make those people very happy. Equally, as Senator Brown has said, it gets the support of those who genuinely seek change to the flag. It ensures that those people seeking that change will have that change facilitated when they can agree on some alternative proposal to the most beautiful flag that is our national flag at the moment.

Senator Brown did make the point in summing up that the government should facilitate some sort of competition for the design of a potential alternative flag. I do not think that is necessary. There has been over the years, through Ausflag and other organisations, a range of competitions. I presume thousands of designs have been worked out by artists and other enthusiasts over the years. I do not think any government involvement needs to take place.

I suspect that at some stage in the next 100, 200 or 300 years someone may come up with some alternative to our flag. It would have to be very good to attract my vote and to see consensus formed for it. That is all part of a vigorous democracy. National symbols are very important to a nation, nation building and democracy. I thank all senators—not only those who have contributed to the debate—who have agreed to make this a non-controversial and non-partisan issue in the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.27 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Hill. In answer to a question in an estimates committee last Thursday, you stated that funding was provided to the Manly reservoir project in the Warringah electorate of New South Wales because of the lack of quality and quantity of applications from metropolitan areas. Minister, can you confirm that this project, $14,876 for restoration work at the Manly reservoir, was ranked 195 out of 202 applications for the state assessment panel? Can you also confirm that at least 14 metropolitan projects which the state assess ment panel ranked higher in quality than the Manly proposal did not get funding? As an example, why was a project for the Bankstown City vegetation management strategy, which was ranked in quality more than 100 places above the Manly project, not funded? Was the fact that this project is located in the electorate of Blaxland coincidental? Does this not confirm that political bias must have been involved in these Natural Heritage Trust grant allocations?
—I can understand why Senator Cook asked the question and not Senator Faulkner, because he would have to start by apologising to the Baillieu family.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You won't apologise to the Baillieu family.
—I won't apologise for identifying your rorts.
—Senator, dead men don't rort.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook could equally have asked me why the Tuggerah Lakes bushland environment rehabilitation program in the seat of Dobell, which was under the nominal cut-off line, was funded by the government. He could have asked me why the Redhead Beach dune revegetation and construction boardwalk scheme, in the seat of Shortland—and under the nominal cut-off line—was funded by the coalition government. He could have asked me why the trees in Newcastle environment education workshops—again, in a Labor seat and under the cut-off line—was funded by the coalition government.

answer.para: You see, this is a priority order as determined by the New South Wales government; it is not necessarily the priority with which we agree. Of those that went through the SAP, we judge each program on the basis of merit. On that basis of merit, the particular project in Manly was rated extremely highly.

This project, restoration and regeneration of remnant bushland corridor—catchment Manly reservoir, was submitted to the 1997-98 trust funding round by the Friends of Bantry Reserve Bush Regeneration Group, working with the Manly-Warringah councils and the Wakehurst Golf Club. The project aims to rehabilitate an area of native bush which is a significant link in larger bushland areas. The area is rich in native plant species, and native wildlife recording has identified varieties of birds, reptiles and frogs. The project is eligible under the trust criteria and was recommended for funding by the urban regional assessment panel and then, as Senator Cook said, by the state assessment panel. According to the advice of my department, the project is a very good one, helping voluntary community work which began in 1996 and which has been financially supported by the councils.

There is no doubting the community support for the project, nor the conservation importance of the area. In all, it is a great example of the partnership between the Commonwealth government, community groups, local government and business. That is why this project was funded—because it stood up in our assessment on merit. And you will find, Senator Cook, that every project that we are funding under the natural heritage program is one that has been determined on its environmental merit or its sustainable agricultural merit. You see, we will be well judged on this program by the overall environmental outcomes, and we are determined to choose the projects which will give the best environmental outcomes. Obviously this project fits within that criterion.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you still have not adequately explained to the Senate why this project, which rated seven places from the bottom of a list of 202 projects, was leapfrogged over many projects into the funding area. What you have said is not sufficient explanation. Will you table any documents you have which justify that selection? But more importantly, Minister, will you now give the Senate a categorical assurance that Mr Tony Abbott did not have discussions with you or with your office about this project or any other project in the electorate of Warringah?

—He certainly did not have discussions with me. I do not think he made representations but, if he did, so what? Many parliamentarians have made representations. I mentioned Mr Beazley yesterday. I could have mentioned Mr Evans in the other place. He is doing his job as a local electorate member—he made representations. Who is the member for Dobell? Is he Labor Party? Mr Lee? He made representations. Mr Kerr, the shadow minister for the environment—he made representations. That is a local member doing his job. There is nothing wrong with that. It may well be the case, in this instance, that Mr Abbott should be criticised for not making representations. The point is: it would not have made any difference, because the projects are judged on merit.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Is the minister aware that between 1983 and 1996—the years of the Labor government—the Labor Party transferred to the trade union movement sums from $2.5 million a year up to $18.5 million? Presumably they learned such cultural attainments as trashing the main entrance of Parliament House. What would be the effect on other cultural bodies in the community if a similar process were instituted?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is a very important issue for the people of Australia because they will have to consider not just what happened in the past, but what is likely to happen again if this mob ever gets another chance. The fact is that between 1983 and 1996, when they were thrown out, they gave nearly $92 million to the trade union movement—$92 million of taxpayers' funds. In the lead up to the 1993 election, what did the trade union movement give to the Labor Party? Answer: $2.2 million. The trade union movement gave $2.2 million—streets ahead of any other donor, I have no doubt at all. What did the government give in return the following year? It gave $14 million in government grants, including $5.7 million to 13 out of the 18 trade unions which made donations. How is that for a return on your investment? It is not bad. You could not beat that in the market place. That is a fantastic performance.

answer.para: It happens because of the massive conflict of interest that we have opposite. More than half of this lot here are paid-up members of the trade union movement. When we go to preselection, what do they ask us? They want to know where we stand on issues. They want to know a bit about our backgrounds. What do they ask them? Their first question is, `Which union do you belong to?' Their second question is, `How much did they give at the last election?' Their third question is, `What will you do for us for evermore if we put you in there?' Of course, they say all the right things, so the last 10 of them elected or appointed to this place were all trade union members. It is a massive conflict of interest when the interests of the trade union movement are put ahead of the national interest.

The Evatt Foundation, for example, got $250,000 at a time when it had in excess of $1 million cash in its bank account. It was simply a pay-off. Senator Faulkner likes to talk about fixes, but the fact is that this is political money laundering. This is your way of doing business. You think that if you pay out money, you buy support. Your previous leader Mr Keating did precisely this. He went around handing out hundreds of thousands of dollars to millionaires in the arts community in the hope that they would stand up and say the right thing at election time. In other words, it was another grubby and shabby attempt to buy political patronage. It is highly relevant because it happened last time; it will happen again this time.

Of course they do not want to know about it. They bury their heads in the sandpit as usual. We always have these ad hoc meetings of the sandpit committee because they cannot stand the heat. They know full well there is no defence for this behaviour. It will happen again if ever they get the opportunity. What ought to be exposed now is the fact that you are not able to vote sensibly and dispassionately on issues; you will simply do what your masters tell you. That explains why there has been a deafening silence on the MUA. As Senator MacGibbon pointed out, the CFMEU, which was responsible for battering down Parliament House, actually got $1.8 million.

talk.start.para: —What?

—It was $1.8 million. This is the old BLF dressed up in new clothes. It will keep happening because these outfits are wholly owned subsidiaries of the ACTU. As Graham Richardson said the other day, the trade union movement still holds the majority of stock in the ALP. There it is. That is the stock. That is what they own. They are getting their return on the investment. They are certainly not getting it in terms of quality performance, but they are getting it in terms of compromising the national interest. I think it ought to be abundantly clear to the taxpayers that, if they want real value for money, they ought not have a bar of this mob. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, during question time yesterday you admitted that the Liberal member for Leichhardt had lobbied you about specific projects in North Queensland. Are you aware that Mr Entsch today admitted to the Courier-Mail that he rang your office to attempt to influence your consideration of the hill slopes grant in Cairns and that he found your staff `very responsive'? Minister, I remind you that this is a project which was originally rejected and then reinstated after a request to the department from your office. Do you still claim, as you did in question time on Tuesday, that this is just Mr Entsch falsely claiming credit for this grant or do you now agree that this is a further case of political interference in the grants process?

—I think that it is yet another misrepresentation within a question, but I do suggest to Senator Faulkner that he would have more credibility if he started off by apologising to the Baillieu family. He is not prepared to go outside that door—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —If you want to treat this seriously, do not sit there grinning. Firstly, you should go outside this door—
—Order! There are too many interjections, and too much noise during question time.
—Firstly, he should go outside the door and apologise and make the claim again—
—You should apologise for rorting!
—or, alternatively, he ought to be able to get up here and apologise to the Baillieu family.
—You apologise for rorting!
—Slandering the dead! You have no credibility in this—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators will not shout at each other across the table.

—You have no credibility in this matter at all. Madam President, if he will not apologise to the Baillieu family, then he should apologise for misleading the Senate. Honourable senators will recall the taking note the other day when Senator Faulkner mentioned Richard Percy Clive Baillieu, the current secretary of EL&C Baillieu. He is the Richard Percy Clive Baillieu who died 57 years ago!

answer.para: You slander the Baillieu family and misrepresent the position of the Senate. You have no credibility in this matter at all. It is only Senator Faulkner and the Labor Party that think that. Why? For the most base of political motives. In relation to Leichhardt, certainly, Mr Entsch is an enthusiastic lobbier for his electorate. There is no doubt about that. I mentioned a number of ALP members who have lobbied for their electorates. There is nothing wrong with that also.

What I said in relation to this particular matter yesterday was that advice that I received from my department was not based on the representations of any particular member. I would have thought that that was clear-cut. I said that the department looked at applications that were rejected at the SAP in Queensland for reasons that related to the fact that the SAP did not seem to understand totally the biodiversity issues which they should have been addressing.

In relation to this particular matter, I have been told that a member of the SAP had, in fact, rung Mr Entsch before the SAP had made its decision to tell him that it was unlikely to get up because it had been said to be too regionally restrictive. There is nothing in the guidelines to that effect. I understand that Mr Entsch then contacted the Labor Mayor, Tom Pyne, in Cairns.

talk.start.para: —A life member of the ALP.

—A life member! As a result of that, Mr Tom Pyne ultimately sent the application back to Mr Entsch. That was not necessary, of course, because we were looking at all of those that had been rejected by the SAP in Queensland. As I said, the advice from my department was that this was a particularly good project, setting up a system of incentives for local government—just what we would like to encourage Australia-wide—to encourage local governments to give incentives to individuals to protect remnant vegetation and to revegetate. That is what the bushcare scheme is all about. We talked about it during the last election. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister tell us who in his office he gave responsibility to to contact his own department to provide the instruction that previously ruled rejected or ineligible grants should be reassessed in relation to both Queensland and Victoria? Which member of his staff gave that instruction? When was the instruction given? What representations had been received prior to the instruction being given?

—When is Senator Faulkner going to apologise to the Baillieu family and when is he going to apologise to the Senate for misleading it? When is he going to try to rebuild his credibility in this matter? He would then be in a far better position to ask questions. The national vegetation initiative, which we now call bushcare, is new and unique.
—Who gave the instruction?
—Senator Faulkner, you are persistently interjecting.

—He will not listen. The national vegetation initiative is the biodiver sity arm of the Natural Heritage Trust. It is the new part. It is the part that some RAPs and some SAPs did not totally understand. If it was the view of my department that it was not totally understood at the SAP level, I can think of no better reason for them to do a reassessment, and they determined that this one should be funded because of its high merit. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Justice. This week it has been revealed that Senator Bolkus leaked information from confidential Federal Court documents which resulted in the sabotage of the government's plans to seize the assets of Christopher Skase. Senator Bolkus has previously falsely claimed that you delayed signing service documents when there were no documents for you to sign. Yesterday, Senator Bolkus falsely claimed that your office is being investigated by the Australian Federal Police. Now Senator Bolkus has claimed that he got the Federal Court documents from the media. Minister, will you advise the Senate whether this was a legitimate source.

—Thank you, Senator Abetz, for your continued interest in this disgraceful exercise by Senator Bolkus. It is not a suitable excuse to simply say, `I got it from the media.' If $1,000 was stolen from someone in the gallery and they came down and gave it to someone here, would any of us say, `Oh, well, someone gave it to us. Someone in the media stole it from the gallery and just gave it to us.' How convenient to blame the media—how very convenient.

answer.para: This is the alleged alternative first law officer of the Commonwealth, so when he had a document that was a clearly a Federal Court document, some bells should have rung. He presumably new that it was an ex parte application. He knew that the document was not his. He did not sit there thinking, `This was destined for me.' It was clearly a court document, and he had a choice.

He could have done the right thing with it and gone to the trustee in bankruptcy, Mr Donnelly—he did not have to come to us in the political environment, he should have gone to the proper owner of the document, Mr Donnelly. He should have said to Mr Donnelly, `Will the release of this information cause you any difficulty?'

Why didn't Senator Bolkus do this? Because the document itself revealed to him that the release of it would cause Mr Donnelly some difficulty. So he did not want to go there—oh, no. If you read the document that he released a portion of to the media—read to the media sotto voce off the record—it actually says:

If this matter comes to the attention of the respondents and in particular Mr Skase before the orders can be obtained in all jurisdictions, I have serious concerns that steps will be taken to prejudice the substantive proceedings.

Despite reading that in the document, Senator Bolkus went ahead. That gives you the answer why he did not go to the owner, why he did not go to Mr Donnelly, because he knew that Mr Donnelly would have said, `Don't do it.'

There is another alternative. We do have open courts in Australia, and Senator Bolkus might have stupidly thought that he could roll up to the Federal Court, pay $20 or $30 and get a copy of the document, because you can get copies of a wide range of documents from the courts—as it should be. But order 46, rule 6, of the Federal Court Rules makes it perfectly clear that you cannot get an affidavit in proceedings without leave of the court or of a judge, and no such leave has been sought.

So the owner of the document did not want it released. Senator Bolkus could read that in the owner's affidavit. The Federal Court did not release it. Senator Bolkus had, and knew he had, an illegally or improperly obtained document. He knew after reading the contents of it the risk that was there if he revealed the details. What did he do? He wants to blame the media. He says, `They gave it to me.' Nobody up there, no person in the media that has ever alleged to me they have had this document used it. And that is the difference: Senator Bolkus had it and he used it. He put it in the public arena.
Senator Alston interjecting—

talk.start.para: —A suggestion is that he had it, gave it to the media and they gave it back—I do not know if that is right, but the difference is he used it. What did he tip Skase off to? Skase always knows we are after him. But what Senator Bolkus said was that hearings had already been held and that they are doing it without him. He told them where the hearings had been held, which gives an indication of the assets and the people that are involved. He further told them they were around the corner with service. (Time expired)

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the minister assure the Senate that every one of Minister Anderson's decisions regarding the Natural Heritage Trust grants have been made in accordance with the requirements of the NHT and made without any taint of political influence? I draw the minister's attention to the following projects approved by Minister Anderson: $63,350 for a marketing officer for the Queensland Grain Growers Association; $63,780 for a property management officer for the United Graziers Association of Queensland; and $49,911 for a project officer for the Cattlemen's Union. Can you tell the Senate exactly how these projects—effectively employment projects—meet the Natural Heritage Trust's objective of `a better environment for Australia in the 21st century'?

—I do not cease to be amazed by the total hypocrisy of these people opposite. Here we have put in place a trust fund to repair environmental damage that has been done over many, many years. Where this ideological stuff comes in is that they do not recognise the fact that most of the repair of that environmental damage is to be directed to rural and regional Australia, because that is where the damage is.

answer.para: Let us take it a step further. You would like to exclude the Cattlemen's Union, the United Graziers Association and all those people who have a direct interest in the repair of their environmental damage. The other thing that comes through pretty hot and strong from everyone is that if it is private or leasehold property—in other words, someone owns it— you should not put any funds into it. Where are we going to end up, for goodness sake?

talk.start.para: —What about the grants?

—Okay, let me give you the process: following receipt of each state bid, projects are checked by DPIE officers to see if prior advice on eligibility issues had been heeded. South Australia was the first state ready for approval and its assessment process established a general pattern. It goes through projects for approval, projects for approval in principle, projects subject to finalising and so on. Senator Hill has made it very clear that it goes through the regional assessment panel, the state assessment panel and then, of course, it goes to the people responsible.
—The fix is put in by the minister's staff.

—Senator, I think it is worth mentioning because Senator Reynolds is a Queenslander and she does have some interest in north and Far North Queensland that I could not help but notice a question that was asked yesterday or the day before—this is one of the ones that relates specifically to Minister Anderson—on a grant given for the control of tilapia in Far North Queensland and the question has been raised by Mr Entsch as to whether there was some interference.

answer.para: Let me explain to you that Mr Entsch wrote to me about this matter. Why would he have written to me? Because he was the local member who had been approached by those people who had applied for the grant—and this was for the fisheries action program. Mr Entsch wrote to me on 3 September 1997 arguing that the project should be given a high priority. The letter arrived after the state assessment panel had formulated its recommendations on 23 and 24 June. I responded to Mr Entsch on 14 October with a letter that explained the assessment process.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you understand how Queenslanders could see these large grants of money for the employment of staff by the United Graziers Association, the Grain Growers Association and the Cattlemen's Union as having a political basis, if not a political bias?
—Senator Reynolds is casting aspersions on organisations that have in their interests—
—No, she is casting aspersions on your government. That is what she is doing.

—The environmental and resource management problems—I do not know how often we have to say this—being addressed by the Natural Heritage Trust are in rural and regional Australia. Who is Senator Reynolds suggesting should be those people who have the keenest interest in repairing the damage? It would have to be people such as those from the Cattlemen's Union—who were the other ones?—the united graziers and the grain growers.
—You're not even listening to the questions now.
—Of course I am listening to the questions. I would have thought they have gone through—
—You're making a goose of yourself.
—Big mouth. Give us a chance.
—Senator Faulkner, I would ask you to cease interjecting.

—My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State. Minister, given that you have dismissed outright the advice of the Clerk of the Senate on the handling of the Native Title Amendment Bill last December in the House of Representatives in favour of your own advice, and given that the cost of a double dissolution election to enable the Wik bill to be passed in a joint sitting would be more than $60 million, do you agree that the government has effectively placed a $60 million bet with taxpayers' money that your legal advice, which has no precedent, is correct? Given the taxpayers' investment in this advice, will you table it today and also table previous advice to governments on this subject?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The government does not seek a double dissolution at all. What we want is a normal election of half the Senate and the House. What we want is this Senate to pass our fair and balanced

answer.para: Native Title Amendment Bill.

If there is a double dissolution on this issue, it will be because of the minor parties, and most particularly the Labor Party, obstructing what has been passed by the people's house, the House of Representatives, with an overwhelming majority. It is fair and balanced legislation which should be supported by this Senate. There is nothing in this legislation which should be opposed by this Senate.

What we have clearly revealed in the Sydney Morning Herald by Alan Ramsey is a rort by the enlightened ones, including Senator Bolkus, who actually believe it is going to be in the Labor Party's interest to have a double dissolution on native title. It is the enlightened ones—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is a question of relevance. Usually Senator Minchin does answer questions, but I would be grateful if he would answer the question about the bet and whether or not he will table the advice.

—As I was saying, it is regrettable that it does appear to be Labor's strategy to force a double dissolution, come what may, on this issue. Their insistence on subjecting the Native Title Act to the Racial Discrimination Act, they know full well, is an amendment that the government cannot accept. The Labor government could not accept it. Father Frank Brennan, hardly a great supporter of the government, has asked the opposition to withdraw that ridiculous amendment. They do seem hell-bent on forcing a double dissolution, which we do not want.

answer.para: Senator Woodley, with great respect to the Clerk of the Senate, we do not accept his advice. We think his advice is wrong on this issue. We have very good advice that he is wrong. We are satisfied that the way in which this bill is being dealt with by the government will, if necessary, satisfy the requirements of section 57 of the Constitution. We do not propose to table that advice.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, was this legal advice provided to your government on this matter before the House of Representatives laid aside the legislation or was it sought after the event to justify an on-the-run decision, which I must say looks like it was a result of pressure from government MPs so they could go home or overseas for Christmas? Was your advice given before or after the House of Representatives laid aside the legislation?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I can assure you, Senator Woodley, that the government made absolutely certain that it was acting in full compliance with the Constitution when it dealt with the bill in the House of Representatives when, regrettably, the Senate passed amendments unacceptable to the government, therefore risking a double dissolution. We do not want a double dissolution. It is the responsibility of this Senate to pass the bill when it returns to the Senate. It is a fair and balanced bill which deserves the Senate's support. If you do not want a double dissolution election on this issue, Senator Woodley, vote for the bill when it returns to the Senate.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, do you recall that in October of last year your government refused to comply with a Senate return to order requiring the production of documents related to your government's waterfront strategy and justified your refusal by claiming that the documents in question were covered by cabinet and commercial-in-confidence? Minister, how do you explain why, according to evidence given at estimates hearings last week, Mr Reith and Mr Sharp shared this material with a large number of individuals, including representatives of the National Farmers Federation, at a meeting in Melbourne on 18 September last year? Minister, has this apparent flagrant breach of cabinet and commercial confidentiality been referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation? If not, why not?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I take it that that was asked tongue in cheek. I am not aware of any—
—No, it is very serious.

—Have you referred any matters to the police? Go for it. If any Labor member of parliament is concerned on this issue and they think that matters ought to be brought to the attention of the police, I am sure they will not hesitate to do it.

answer.para: The fact is that, as I recall, we were claiming public interest immunity rather than simply cabinet documents and commercial-in-confidence. That was an assessment made on the merits of the documents. It has nothing to do with what might happen to those documents in certain circumstances. It does not change the status of them. The status is determined by the contents of the documents and they retain that status. Accordingly, our position is still the same.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, why don't you come clean and admit now that your government refused the Senate access to these documents because of political rather than security considerations?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not sure that is a serious question either, Madam President.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I will give it a serious answer. I am sure the disgruntled unionist faction would expect no less. The fact is that judgments are always made about the status of documents when requests are made either through the FOI procedures—

answer.para: Opposition senator interjecting—

talk.start.para: —If you want to apologise, do it after question time. It is a lot more convenient. We will not have to interrupt you then. We will give you absolute silence. If you have got something to say, which at least portrays even a suggestion of regret, then we would be happy to hear you do it at the appropriate time.

answer.para: In the meantime, let me simply say that, in relation to both requests by members of parliament, questions on notice or without notice, and FOI requests, the documents are judged on their merits against the various criteria that are important in assessing whether they should be released to the public. In this instance the judgment was made. It had nothing to do with the sorts of motives that you attribute, but simply on merit.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government representing the Prime Minister. The government is insisting on the passage of its common youth allowance bill, pointing to its overall beneficial effect. However, is it not a fact that the legislation will transfer the costs of its social security responsibilities for some young unemployed Australians from its own budget to that of their parents to the tune of $135 million? If that legislation assumes those siblings are sharing in their parents' income, should not the essential income transfers within a family be also recognised in the taxation system? Is it the intention of the government to include in its restructuring of the Australian taxation system measures to give further recognition to the function of parents in raising sons and daughters, Australia's future taxpayers?

—Before calling Senator Hill, I point out that a significant part of the question related to a bill that is before the committee of the whole at the present time. We are usually fairly tolerant about that sort of thing, but this is before the committee. The latter part of the question certainly raised another issue.

—If I respond to the substance: as I understand it, the issue of Senator Harradine's question really is the commitment of the government through the taxation system to give support to parents, recognising the extra financial burden that children obviously must be upon any family. There can be no doubt about that commitment.

answer.para: The best example I can give to demonstrate that commitment is the family tax initiative, which we introduced after this government came to power, which gives additional help to low and middle income families with dependent children. That was a commitment that the now Prime Minister personally made during the election and it very much demonstrates his attitude and that of his government towards this very important issue.

It is also why the Prime Minister when announcing that the government would undertake an overhaul of the Australian taxation system specified that one of the criteria of tax reform would include further relief in relation to the taxation of families. I take this opportunity to reiterate that here today.

I can, therefore, assure Senator Harradine that, in restructuring the Australian taxation system to which this government is committed, the government will give further recognition and help to Australian parents concerning their responsibilities in—using Senator Harradine's words—raising sons and daughters, Australia's future taxpayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. When you were first asked at estimates last Thursday about whether a strategy had been prepared for a $750,000 publicity campaign for your government's policies on CD imports, why did you deny it? Why did you say, `No particular strategy is being proposed or put forward at this time,' when you knew perfectly well that not only had a strategy been prepared but you had already let a contract for $73,000? Is it not also a fact that the publicity campaign is in part directed at persuading your own backbenchers that your CD policy is the right one?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Senator Lundy did her very best at estimates recently to try to beat up this issue and then, because it did not go anywhere, she put out a press release that said `despite intense questioning by her good self'. I think that tells you that she was running into the sand by that stage. The fact is that Senator Lundy had a document, but by being cute and coy about it she asked a question in such a way that it was very difficult to comprehend precisely what she was asking in the first place.

answer.para: The fact is that all the relevant matters were provided to Senator Lundy. She is very much aware, as she was from the outset, of the decision taken. I think the way in which she put it was: `Was a strategy prepared by the department and presented to you?' Essentially, I think the answer was that the department put forward a possible strategy.

I can understand Senator Lundy not understanding the difference. She has not been in this place all that long, but there is, unfortunately, quite a deal of difference between the department wanting something or even the minister wanting something and it ultimately finding its way into government policy. I would have thought that that particular understanding would have dawned on Senator Lundy by now.

I now go to the more important part of the question: why was it that backbenchers should be somehow involved in the campaign? The fact is that the record industry has spent literally millions of dollars on mounting a significant disinformation campaign. There are very many people in the community who need to understand the true facts of the issue. One of the best ways of doing that is, when people ring up with concerns to a backbencher's office, for that backbencher to be in a position to provide the facts to overturn the misunderstandings and inconsistencies that might otherwise influence their judgment.

This is the lot that spent millions of dollars on information campaigns. Do you remember those little trees that grew all about the superannuation guarantee charge? You know who were the significant beneficiaries of that, don't you? The crowd that set up the industry funds—the superannuation funds run by the trade union movement. This was an absolute godsend to the trade union movement because every income earner in Australia was forced to contribute and many of them had no choice but to put their money into industry funds. So, once again, they were the classic beneficiaries of a system and yet you still had to get out there and spend millions of dollars advertising it.

We make no apologies at all for, from time to time, finding it necessary to ensure that the public are not misled and for ensuring that all those who might be in a position to clarify any misunderstanding on the part of the public are fully informed, and backbenchers come into that category. Can I simply say that we would not expect you lot to, in any shape or form, try to undo those misunderstandings because you threw in the towel on this issue long ago. You were prepared at one stage to take the right and proper course of action. Of course you buckled at the knees on CDs. Senator Schacht is on the public record as saying we are doing the right thing. You know we are doing the right thing. You threw in the towel because you were too gutless and yet you are not prepared to debate the issue on its merits. As it therefore happens, it may be necessary for an information campaign.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. How do you justify spending $750,000 of taxpayers' money advertising what is merely government policy given that legislation has yet to be passed by parliament? How do you justify spending any taxpayers' money at all to sell the message to your own backbenchers?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is as though I had said nothing for the last three minutes—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You cannot have it both ways. Either you want me to answer the questions or, if you do not want to hear it, if you do not think the answers are worth having, you can save yourself the time and trouble and not ask the questions. But, unfortunately, Senator Lundy chooses to ask the question. She therefore gets an answer. She gets an answer in spades about the necessity to mount a campaign to refute the disinformation that is provided by the Record Industry Association. She ignores all of that and pretends it has not happened and asks me again why we are mounting an information campaign. Well, I do not want to say it anymore. We are doing it to correct the record to make sure people are not misunderstood. We have not yet decided to go down that path, but if we do it will be because there is a necessity to correct the disinformation on the subject. (Time expired)

—My question is to the minister for schools. Minister, in estimates last week we heard that the government will take $11.9 million from state budgets through its enrolment benchmark adjustment even though enrolments in government schools have increased by 8,500. Minister, what justification do you have for continuing to punish state schools when it is clear that all the students which your government predicted would exit public schools have not done so? Minister, why did Dr Kemp this week publicly deny that this money will be moved from government schools?

—I thank Senator Allison for this question. As Senator Allison well knows, the situation here is that there is no punishment at all. This government believes in a strong government school sector. It also believes in a strong non-government school sector so that parents can choose to which school they will send their children. That is a platform we went to the Australian people with at the last election and a platform on which we were elected.

answer.para: Senator Allison, I am glad you mentioned that figure of $11.9 million because in your address to the Senate the other day you mistakenly referred to it as $16.8 million. This figure represents under half a per cent of the total expenditure of the Commonwealth on government schools. In fact, in this year the Commonwealth will spend $127 million more on government schools than Labor did it its last year.

Senator Allison also fails to remember the fact that, in recurrent expenditure, we allowed a supplementation of 7.4 per cent. This was a windfall because it exceeded the CPI index by several per cent and in fact involved a windfall of $228 million to schools. When you look at it in that context, there is an increase in expenditure towards government schools. This EBA adjusts funding between the Commonwealth and the states and addresses where you have a proportional shift between government and non-government enrolment.

In some states and territories—Tasmania, the Northern Territory and the ACT—this was not even triggered. There was a lower result than anticipated because the drift from government to non-government was between 0.3 and 0.4 per cent. That was much lower than anticipated. What we are saying, Senator Allison, is that we believe in a strong government sector and a strong non-government sector so that Australian parents can choose to which school they want to send their children.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you say that this is a small percentage of the total schools budget, but I ask you again why is it necessary to impose this measure at all? What is the purpose of the mechanism if it is not to bleed government schools of very scarce resources? My question to you was: why does Dr Kemp continue to mislead the Australian public on this issue and these cuts?

—The legislation to which the EBA is tied went through this very chamber—it went through the Senate. Can I also say that it was part of the 1996 budget announcement. So there has been nothing clandestine, nothing covert. It is something which has been debated, passed and accepted. We have also discussed this with the states. There is no intention to bleed the government sector. We are spending more money on government schools. We believe in a strong government sector.

—My question is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Do you recall that, after cabinet decided your policy on CD imports last year, you stated publicly that you would be strengthening the copyright laws by increasing penalties and reversing the onus of proof? Do you recall, for example, stating on radio 2BL on 10 October, `We'll be tightening the rules, increasing the penalties, reversing the onus of proof'?
