Minister, when and how do you propose to reverse the onus of proof?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not quite sure what that means—`when and how do you propose to do it?' You would make changes to legislation which would put in place a mechanism—
—You are supposed to be a lawyer, Richard!

—I am just explaining what I think he means. It is not done person ally by a member of parliament or the minister. You would move an amendment that would enable a court to make a judgment by reversing the onus of proof. In other words, in a civil dispute, instead of having to establish that something was imported from a jurisdiction where there were no copyright arrangements—and therefore was pirated—the onus would be on the importer to show that it was not illegally imported. That makes one very big difference. Otherwise, you have to go offshore, gather evidence and prove what the law might be in that particular jurisdiction. If you simply put the onus on either the retailer or the importer, then it is their responsibility to ensure that, before they put the CD on sale, they have satisfied themselves that it is not a pirated import. Therefore, their records would be part of their satisfying the onus of proof and meeting that test. That is what I had in mind and that is the way in which I believe we are still proceeding.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, given what the minister has just said on what seems to be his view of onus of proof now. Minister, how do you reconcile that with what the Attorney-General's Department stated to the communications and arts committee the other night—that the government has never stated it will reverse the onus of proof either in parliament or to the public? How do you reconcile that position with your public statements?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I presume you told them where they were wrong because you have just confirmed that I did say it on radio. To the extent that they were saying I had never said it in public, I presume you pointed that out to them and drew it to their attention and they apologised to you for any misunderstanding.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer the minister to the current problems in the Asian economies. Will the minister outline how the government's prudent budgetary policies will enable Australia to continue to record high levels of growth notwithstanding the problems in Asia? Will the minister also outline the adverse consequence if these policies were not maintained into the future?

—Thank you, Senator Crane, for that important question. The Asian crisis will have a significant impact on the Australian economy, and that has been stated before this. The impact was incorporated into the mid-year economic and fiscal outlook, with growth slowing to 3¼ per cent in 1998-99 from 3¾ per cent in 1997-98. I stress that the fact that Australia is expected to continue to record high growth levels in 1998-99 despite the Asian turmoil is a result of strong domestic demand. As my colleague Senator Parer pointed out, this is a high growth economy compared with other countries.
—No, it isn't.

—It is a high growth economy. Let there be no doubt that the government's responsible budget policies provide investment confidence to maintain high growth, low inflation and low interest rates. If it were not for these responsible policies, if we had maintained the budget deficit policies of the previous failed Labor government, the economic situation in this country would be worse—far worse. What would happen if by some mischance Labor were returned to office? We can judge somewhat from what is already on the public record. We know Labor would spend, spend, spend. Labor would run up the deficit—

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber.

—There is no doubt, and we have this on the record, that Labor would spend, spend, spend. In fact shadow minister after shadow minister has gone around this country saying that there will be further additional spending policies. We all know that if spending rises taxes will rise and, ultimately, we know from the Labor experience that there will be substantial rises in deficits. They are the record government for running up massive deficits while in office.

answer.para: Mr Martin Ferguson has said that the government ought to be digging into its surplus. That is what Martin Ferguson said. Michael Lee wants to spend more money in the health area. And so it goes on. Simon Crean wants to spend more money in the R&D area. We are quite entitled to ask where this money is coming from. A blank look collectively goes over the Labor frontbench. Where is this money coming from which Labor has started to promise? It is the same old story. What we are seeing again is a re-run of the old Labor story—promising spending and at the same time pretending they will not raise taxes. We all know from bitter experience what the effect of a Labor government is.

I also point out that the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, racked up massive deficits when he was the Minister for Finance. So for Mr Beazley to be going around the country talking about surpluses is a joke to any person in this country who has any memory whatsoever of the experience of the Labor government. Senators may be interested to know what Senator Cook said when asked what Labor would do in response to the Asian crisis. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would particularly like Senator Kemp, the minister, to outline further Mr Beazley's performance in terms of his years as Minister for Finance and the impact that had on the Australian economy in terms of the deficits that were brought down.
—That supplementary question is very nearly out of order. You should not canvass matters which ought not to be raised within it.

—To expand on the point, when asked what Labor would do in response to the Asian crisis on Australian jobs, growth and inflation, Senator Cook's first response was this—and I had to read it twice to make sure I had read it correctly:

answer.para: We have made quite clear over a long period of time what Labor would do, we would have moved earlier to recognise the extent of the crisis.
and then we waited breathlessly to see what Labor would have done, and Senator Cook went on:
We would have conducted seminars around Australia . . .

That is what Senator Cook said. Like his colleagues, Senator Cook then announced some further spending programs, again uncosted. But, I must say, what a fantastic idea! The shadow minister for trade, in order to deal with the Asian crisis, would go around this country conducting a few seminars. It is truly pathetic. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—I wish to move a censure motion against Senator Bolkus. I want to do it straight after question time, and I have the appropriate motions in front of me. I do not want to do that if there is another matter that you, Madam President, need to deal with first, but I do want to deal with it before taking note of answers.
—If you wish to move a suspension of standing orders, you may do so.
—Why didn't we get the call here then?

—I have not called on motions to take note of answers. The procedure is that, at this point, I call ministers who stand up, who usually are giving additional answers and information to questions. I called Senator Vanstone. She now says that she wishes to move a censure motion.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. Senator Vanstone is the only minister on her feet. Surely, before you accept that Senator Vanstone can bypass any minister who wishes to add to their answer, you should first ascertain whether any minister wishes to do so. There is a clear case that one minister, Senator Kemp, at least should do so after that despicable display a moment ago. Surely you should establish that fact first.
—Order! There is no point of order. No other minister stood up other than Senator Vanstone.
—I will raise another point of order. You yourself have said you called Senator Vanstone because you thought she was going to add to an answer. That is the reason for her getting the call.
—True. Correct.
—Normally you would take the noting of answers and then, if a minister wished to move a suspension, you would recognise and call them then.
—Correct.
—Senator Vanstone has the priority over Senator O'Brien, who was on his feet to take note, on the basis that, in your own mind, she was going to add to an answer.

—On the point of order, Madam President: I sought the call and received it. I indicated at that point that I would immediately move the motion. You would have had no option but to accept that motion. I simply did you a courtesy in indicating that, if you had something you wanted to say in relation to question time or whatever, you could go first. But the facts are that I was on my feet, I had the call and I wish to proceed.
—If there is a contingent notice of motion that permits the minister to do so, she may proceed at any time.
—Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 1 standing in the name of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion of censure of the shadow Attorney-General (Senator Bolkus) for his unauthorised disclosure of a confidential court document relating to proceedings concerning Mr C. Skase.

talk.start.para: —I am happy for them to speak to it, but I am conscious that people, on the other side especially, say that they would like to run this place efficiently. I am giving them the opportunity to agree to suspend standing orders and move straight to the substantive motion. If they do not want to do that, I will debate it.
—There are 30 minutes in which to debate the motion for the suspen sion of standing orders, during which senators may each speak for a period of five minutes.

—It appears that that offer has been rejected, so I will speak to the motion. This is a very serious matter. Mr Skase left Australia under the Labor administration owing millions of dollars to small investors all around Australia. Labor, I have no doubt, did its best to get Mr Skase back, but it failed and failed spectacularly. Now we are in government, and we have confirmed that we are also pursuing Mr Skase's assets.

speech.para: We have a situation where a member of this place, the would-be alternative first law officer of the Commonwealth, who had the opportunity over the last few days to admit this, has quite clearly used improperly or illegally obtained court documents. That is the first charge against him.

Not only has he used them, he has not revealed inconsequential material from these documents. He has revealed material which was relevant to the proceedings, and it is quite clear from the material that has been led through the chamber this week that he did so knowing the damage he might cause. The affidavit from Mr Donnelly that was in the Federal Court from which Senator Bolkus read to the media quite clearly indicated that Mr Donnelly wanted these proceedings to go ahead without Mr Skase knowing, and the Commonwealth was backing Mr Donnelly and making every attempt for these matters to be dealt with without Mr Skase knowing.

Nobody can deny that there is always a Skase story in the paper. Someone just has to think of a few million dollars, attach it to Skase's name and it will get in the paper. The reason for that is the Australian community are sick to death of people like him doing that sort of thing, and they are interested in it.

But I know of no journalist who ran a story—prior to Senator Bolkus releasing these details from illegally or improperly obtained material—with any of the detail that Senator Bolkus released. What the journalists have done has been responsible. Some have indicated—and Senator Bolkus has indicated—that journalists have had this document, but the difference between Senator Bolkus and the journalists is that he used the document, he encouraged the details of it into the public arena, but the journalists did not.

In doing this, Madam President, he tipped off Skase's advisers in Australia, and not only that we were after his assets. Mr Skase knows we are always after his assets. He has a trustee in bankruptcy. Mr Donnelly has been quoted as saying something like he thinks he will be Mr Skase's trustee in bankruptcy until one or other of them dies.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Vanstone, this part of the debate should be focused particularly on urgency.

—Madam President, what I am trying to do—and I will come to the point—is indicate to you, with the background material, why it is urgent. We have over the last four days set out this case for all to see. At no time has Senator Bolkus taken the opportunity to apologise to Mr Donnelly. At no time has he apologised to the Senate. He has just proceeded as though he was on a decent footing.

speech.para: The urgency is, Madam President, that we have a senator who has behaved outside of this place in a way that nobody in this place would ever let him behave. And he purports to be the alternative first law officer. In a democratic system where you have two major parties and sometimes other key players—in the Senate there are always key players—the alternative first law officer holds a position of some significance. By behaving in the way he has, he has brought this place, himself and his party into disrepute.

It is appropriate for this chamber to indicate to the community at large that we do not accept this sort of behaviour. It is not the way that senators should behave. It is not the way that first law officers should behave. If we do not deal with this today, if we do not make it abundantly clear, after all that we have heard this week, which has not been refuted by Senator Bolkus, that these are not the standards that this place will accept—not Liberal-Labor but this place as a whole—then the Australian community takes it that we nod to Senator Bolkus and say, `Oh, it's okay.'

Madam President, the pursuit of Skase is a matter that the government has an interest in, that all Australians have an interest in, and they do not think it is okay. They are looking to this chamber to make that abundantly clear to Senator Bolkus as soon as is practicable, and that is today.

talk.start.para: —Thank you very much, Madam President. I oppose the urgency motion that has been moved by Senator Vanstone.

speech.para: Madam President, if we ever needed any evidence of the coalition's inability and incapacity to adapt to the responsibilities of governing Australia, then I believe this stunt is it. Most people are aware that, traditionally in the parliament, censure motions have been weapons for opposition. They are not weapons for government. You are making a habit of it.

What we are told time and time again is that this government has more important things to deal with—perhaps like getting on with governing the country. But that, of course, as we know, Madam President, is beyond the capacity of those opposite.

I have to say that probably the government has made a tactical decision—`We need a bit of a confidence builder for Senator Vanstone because she was sacked from the Howard cabinet.' I have to say, Madam President, there are many decisions that Mr Howard has made that I do not agree with, but that is one he got right. Senator Vanstone was a failed minister; she deserved to be sacked, and this is just a confidence builder for her.

talk.start.para: —Could I take a point of order, Madam President? I respectfully urge you to remind Senator Faulkner that this is a debate where he should be arguing against urgency.
—We are dealing with the question of urgency at the present time, Senator.

—I am making the point, Madam President, that one of the reasons this is proposed by the government now is that it is a confidence builder for Senator Vanstone who has had such a miserable and pathetic ministerial career for the past two years.

speech.para: This is the same government that carries on, day in and day out, about alleged Senate obstructionism. This is the same government that whinges about their incapacity and inability to get their legislation program through the Senate. But what do they do? They bring yet another time-wasting stunt. They decide to run this particular censure motion on a Thursday afternoon, deliberately to take away from the small amount of time in the Senate routine of business—that is, general business—for opposition and minor parties, non-government senators, to build a case around important issues of public policy. Perhaps it is because of the issue that was proposed for debate today. Perhaps that is another reason why Senator Vanstone decided to put forward this very cheap stunt.

I have to say to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Manager of Government Business in the Senate that, after this, there can be no more of their usual carping and whingeing about the government's legislation program in the Senate. No more can there be any suggestions at the end of the sittings program that we should be putting our efforts into longer sitting days and more sitting weeks for the Senate.

If you are willing to put the Senate's time into this sort of time-wasting stunt from a failed minister for employment, education and training, then, on behalf of the opposition, I say to you, `Well, let the consequences be on your head because this is a cheap, miserable, political stunt developed by a failed minister to try to retrieve a bit of ground after an abominable performance as an office holder, as a cabinet minister, for which eventually even the Prime Minister of Australia caught up with her.' This is a pathetic, time-wasting stunt. The opposition will not support this suspension of standing orders. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We have just witnessed a half-baked excuse by a half-baked Leader of the Opposition as to why this matter should not be brought on. What is the urgency in this matter? Very clearly, it is this: there is no more serious allegation that can be made against a senator, let alone the would-be Attorney-General of this country, than to accuse him of leaking Federal Court documents for no apparent reason other than what he perversely sees as his own personal aggrandisement.

speech.para: The allegations that have been made each question time this week against Senator Bolkus have never been denied by Senator Bolkus. He has now had all week to come clean or make a denial. Therefore, this Senate is confronted, I would suggest, with a very strong prima facie case that Senator Bolkus has behaved in a manner which is completely unacceptable to the standards of this Senate. Therefore, we should deal with this matter by way of a censure motion as soon as the case has been built up to the extent that it now has been built.

One of the telling points of the half-baked contribution by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) was that he failed to comment on the integrity of Senator Bolkus—not a single word of defence in support of Senator Bolkus. I must commend him on this: this is a tactic learned from Senator Ray. When he refuses to support a colleague, he will bag the government and hope that we forget about the colleague who is under fire. Let me say this to Senator Faulkner: we saw through that little tactic because you do not quite do it as convincingly as the should-be Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Ray.

We on this side accuse Senator Bolkus of acting somewhat deceptively in this matter. Senator Faulkner, in trying to make out his case, has also misled the Senate, because he asserted that the tactic we are using today is a tactic that should only be allowed to be employed by the opposition—rules that ought to be applicable only to the Labor Party and not to the government.

But how short his memory is. Do you recall the censure motion against my colleague former Senator Michael Baume? Senator Faulkner, you voted for it. Was it that you just forgot—a convenient lapse of memory, like Dr Carmen Lawrence's—or were you deliberately misleading this Senate, which your colleague who sits behind you is so blatantly guilty of doing?

In the past, the then Labor government in the other place also censured the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the now Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge). That was in 1995. So the only part of Senator Faulkner's contribution that had some ring of confidence about it was this allegation that it should be used only by oppositions. That argument has fallen flat because of the facts that I have just laid before this place.

What are we confronted with? We are confronted with a very weak argument by Senator Faulkner. The one area that had the potential for substance has been utterly destroyed and, as a result, there is no support for the arguments being put by the Labor Party that this is not a matter of urgency.

We will undoubtedly hear from Senator Ray in this debate. It really is sad that somebody who had the esteem and the seniority is now only ever making contributions in this place when there is mud to be slung or when trying to sledge a minister.

As I said at the outset, there can be no more serious matter than an allegation that a senator in this place, let alone the would-be Attorney-General, deliberately leaked information from confidential Federal Court documents, against the rules of the Federal Court, which had the capacity to sabotage and prejudice the taxpayer-funded pursuit of Christopher Skase. Senator Faulkner and the Labor Party are only seeking to defend Skase's mate.

talk.start.para: —Over the years, censure motions are supposed to have been a very serious matter in this chamber. But one would have to say that their effectiveness has been debased by those on both sides of politics in the last 15 years when they have been thrown around like confetti. I have always had a great regret in my political life: I have never been subjected to one. Every time I go to my preselection panel, I have to say, `I appear as a failure before you yet again. The Senate has failed to censure me.' If only you blokes opposite would get your act together, clean me up, slap me on the wrist and censure me, at least I could walk tall before my own preselectors.
—This isn't a joke, Senator.

—Of course it is not a serious matter by those opposite; otherwise their behaviour today would not have been so puerile. It has been absolutely political and puerile behaviour from the government. But, if it were a matter of urgency, why wasn't it raised when Senator Vanstone answered a question three days ago? I can tell you why: that was a government business day. When it was raised yesterday and we were given the same repetitive answer, why wasn't it urgent then? Of course, it wasn't urgent then.

speech.para: I will tell you why it is urgent today: because today is the day there is little government business left. Today is the day we have general business which is the time allocated to us, the Democrats, the Greens and others in which to put forward our views. So, cynically, this government has thought, `Not only will we jump into a puerile, opportunist censure motion, but we will also make it at the expense of the opposition, using their time.'

Senator Vanstone, I think in a previous answer, said this matter was in the hands of the Federal Police. Senator, have you not said at some stage that the leaking of matters associated with Skase is in the hands of the Federal Police? If so, have they reported or have you jumped the gun into an operational matter and want to prejudice their investigations here in the Senate by making a cheap, opportunist censure motion? Is that the case, that you as a government refer something to the Federal Police for investigation, that they have not in fact reported, but once again you jumped the gun with a censure motion associated with this? I wonder. We might hear one of your later speakers respond to whether this is before the Federal Police and whether you are jumping the gun in the Senate, doing your own lynch-mob mentality job, not leaving it to the professionals to investigate properly and establish the facts.

This government never hesitates to put leaks in the hands of the Federal Police, be it a leak from PM&C, as occurred recently, or a supposed one in DoFA. But when a key report goes missing, such as the Kennedy report, it is not put in the hands of the Federal Police; it is referred to the internal fraud people to cover up. When two crucial documents disappeared from the Prime Minister's office on 11 April 1997, was there a police investigation? Was there any investigation? No, there was not. So we can have a Prime Minister get up in the House of Representatives and talk about the perverters of the course of justice only on the basis that his own office has deleted two critical aide-memoires that would clear the people he accused. They are the people who should be censored in this place.

This exercise is about precisely what Senator Faulkner said. We have a justice minister here whose portfolio responsibilities, whose staffing and whose image in politics have been massively reduced—not by us. We did not demote Senator Vanstone. We did not say to Senator Vanstone that she was no good. Her Prime Minister did so. Her Prime Minister demoted her out of cabinet. Her Prime Minister cut the then duties of the Attorney-General in about half and gave half to Senator Vanstone. She is suffering from deprivation of publicity and role in politics because she has gone from the second biggest spending department in the country to doing nothing. She is bored and she is demoted. So she gets into what I assume is a South Australian thing, a little South Australian feud, so that she can get her kicks over this particular issue.

If you want to waste the time of this parliament, you will be repaid in kind. If you want to take up our general business time, we will start moving urgency motions and MPIs every day. We have been responsible in giving you time, but if you want to waste the time allocated to us, you will get it back in kind.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, the timing of this urgent censure motion is indeed cynical, but I believe that it is an important issue. It is about whether or not a senator of this chamber, in their conduct as a minister, deserves the censure of the Senate. So whilst the timing is cynical, I am prepared to support the suspension of standing orders to hear the arguments. I hope we get more arguments than some of the politics back and forth that we have had so far. I hope it can be done in such a way that it does not impinge on any current police inquiries. I think that should be possible. I am prepared to listen to the arguments of this important censure—in my opinion it always has been important; the Labor Party has not always considered that censures are important, but I believe they are—to find out what the case is really about.

—I am going to vote against the suspension of standing orders. How I vote will not make any difference, of course, but I believe that there has not been a case made out for the suspension of standing orders today. If it was to be made out today, why was it not made out two, three, four or five days ago when the details were known?
—We have had a Federal Court letter today.

—Well without getting the Federal Court's letter, you know precisely what the rules are. Other honourable senators who are interested would as well. I wanted to make that point. No doubt it is necessary now for me to listen to the arguments. I am reserving my view on the subject until I have heard the arguments. I am just disappointed that the matter is coming on today. I had heard around the traps that there was something going on, but I have been otherwise engaged in connection with legislation and thus I will be voting against the suspension.

—The Australian Democrats will be supporting the suspension. We do so because we believe this is a serious matter and we are anxious to hear the arguments which we believe should have a hearing. We are not really interested in the political debate but we are interested in the legal debate. We are concerned though that, if the government does have a number of censure motions in future, they might give consideration as to when these take place—especially if it is a Thursday afternoon, which is of course our only opportunity to have general business. That is our main reluctance to support the suspension. But we will do so, in order to give what we consider a serious matter a hearing, and we will be listening to the arguments and then deciding on the issue.

—No case has been made out this afternoon for an urgency motion on this matter at all. The speeches that have been given by the government have been speeches attacking Senator Bolkus. They have not been speeches about why this matter is allegedly urgent. Nothing that has been put forward says, for example, that the nation is in peril. We are not talking about the Gulf War or something of that level of magnitude. Nothing that has been put suggests urgency. Nothing has been put to say that if we deal with it exactly now something that is about to happen will change or be stopped. There is no urgency in terms of time. This is not a question that, if we do not act immediately, something will change. No case whatsoever has been adduced that that is true. Indeed, what Senator Harradine said before ought to weigh heavily with the minor parties and the government. If it is urgent, why wasn't it done sooner? Why did you wait until now? There is no case before this chamber that, if we act now, we will stop something. We will not.

speech.para: Of course it is idle to pretend that there is something urgent. There is nothing that is leading the news tonight, nothing on the front page of any newspaper, nothing out there that is publicly notorious, that indicates urgency or significant importance. It is a joke and a political fix. That is what it is. We ought to call it by its real name and not engage in humbug and pretence that there is something urgent. It fails on all of these dispassionate tests. Is the nation imperilled? No. Is there something we can do to stop something? No. Is there something that is publicly notorious? No. Can we act to change events? No. None of these things suggests urgency. Everyone in this chamber knows that.

What do we have? We have a series of dorothy dixers this week to Senator Vanstone, so that she can have an unguarded rave against Senator Bolkus because Senator Bolkus annoys her. That is part of politics, Senator Vanstone. If you can't stand it, get out of the joint. That is what politics is about, in part.

And why is the government concerned about Senator Bolkus? Last week a High Court judge stepped down from hearing a major case, because Senator Bolkus put in the public domain information that the government knew about and would not make available. As a consequence of that, a High Court judge stepped down. And who is the proponent in this case? Who is taking it? The government. That is, of course, a major setback for the government in that case. That is why Senator Bolkus must be stopped now—not because of any other matter of public urgency, but because he has acted in the public interest to make information available to the judiciary that the government knew about and did not reveal.

So let us cut out all this cant, humbug and pretence of urgency or of a substantive issue here. There is no substantive issue here. The matter should be dealt with on the voices and dismissed, and this chamber should go about its business. What the Leader of the Opposition said is true: the most frequent refrain from the government is obstruction. Who is obstructing now? The government. The business of the Senate should proceed normally and not be obstructed. If we hear another peep out of you lot about obstruction, we will quote back to you, chapter and verse, the events of today, because that is exactly what you are doing. I know the vote is coming shortly. I think we are just about out of time. I ask those that have declared themselves to pause again and think: what is urgent; what cannot wait until next week; what cannot take its place in the normal batting order? Nothing here is in that category. Do not lend yourself to a slimy, grubby manipulation of the program.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for this debate has terminated.

interjection.para: Question put: That the motion (Senator Vanstone's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Vanstone) proposed:

That a motion of censure of the shadow Attorney General (Senator Bolkus) may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today, including general business and consideration of committee reports and government responses, until determined.

talk.start.para: —I would like to address this motion, which the opposition will not be supporting. Why should this Senate give precedence to Senator Vanstone when the Prime Minister has shown what precedence she deserves by sacking her from the cabinet? Why should we give precedence to this absolutely incompetent minister? I think I can make a very strong case to you, Madam Deputy President, as to why precedence is not warranted on this issue.

speech.para: Let us look at the record of this failed and miserable minister. Do you remember this? As soon as Senator Vanstone came into office, she refused to set targets for unemployment. As background for anyone who might be silly enough to listen to this absurd debate and as background for my colleagues, I have got to say that this was, of course, before she was sacked. So that we are clear, it was when she was the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, before Mr Howard refused to give Senator Vanstone precedence.

She refused to set targets to deal with unemployment. That is one of Senator Vanstone's great achievements. Who could forget the political time bomb that she then handed her leader, Mr Howard, who subsequently sacked her? The political time bomb was this: Senator Vanstone puffed herself up on a television program on a Sunday morning; she went on television and said, `If a government fails to get unemployment down, then a government does not deserve to be re-elected.'

That was the second major foul-up by Senator Vanstone, the minister who is moving precedence on this motion to give her an opportunity to peddle lies about Senator Bolkus. The minister who has asked for precedence is the same one who, in question time in May 1996, said to the Senate:
The reason you will not have some information is that we will not give it to you if we don't want to.

That is what she said in response to a question asked of her ministerial responsibilities in this chamber. That is what Senator Vanstone thinks about responsibilities: we will not give you any information if we do not want to. That was her view of what being a minister of the Crown was about.

It ill behoves Senator Vanstone, with an attitude like that to ministerial responsibility, to be criticising anyone in the opposition in relation to the conduct of their duties in public life. We should not forget that the minister who wants precedence to deal with this politically motivated stunt is the same minister who is single-handedly responsible for building the most powerful coalition of opponents imaginable in higher education. This is the minister—the first in Australian political history—who managed to unite vice chancellors, students, university staff and the public against her higher education policies.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I take a point of order under standing order No. 194(1) which says:

interjection.para: A Senator shall not digress from the subject matter of any question under discussion, or anticipate the discussion of any subject which appears on the Notice Paper.

I refer to the first part of 194(1), in that Senator Faulkner has not yet talked about the issue that is before the Senate, and that is the question of Senator Bolkus's behaviour, not Senator Vanstone's. Senator Bolkus's behaviour is the question before the Senate, and I ask you to rule accordingly.

talk.start.para: —On the point of order: Senator Knowles, what is before the chamber at the moment is whether this matter should have precedence—not Senator Bolkus at all. On the question of precedence, we are entitled to argue, in terms of priorities, what should have alternate precedence.

—Thank you, Senator Ray. There is no point of order Senator Knowles, because the question that Senator Vanstone moved relates to whether or not this should have precedence, and I am sure that Senator Faulkner is debating whether precedence should be given to this and not the censure motion.

—As I was saying, we will not be voting for any motion to give precedence to Senator Vanstone when the Prime Minister demonstrated his approach in terms of the precedence he gave to Senator Vanstone by sacking her. Do not forget the coalition that developed in the higher education sector. On that occasion, you had the Prime Minister—
—Point of order, Senator Knowles.

—I know you are sounding exasperated, Madam Deputy President, but I would prefer that you just listen to the point of order that I am about to take, without the exasperation. That point of order is on standing order 194(1) again—

—Senator Knowles, I caution you on some of your word choice because I find that it is going very close to reflecting upon the chair, and I do not appreciate it. Would you please continue with your point of order.

—Madam Deputy President, I still say that I would prefer that you did not call me in such a way as to express your exasperation. On a point of order: I am raising standing order 194(1). I ask your guidance as to how the disparaging comments by Senator Faulkner about Senator Vanstone relate to the subject of precedence or anything else in the current debate before the Senate. I sought your guidance. You have ruled accordingly, so I now ask you to tell the Senate why you have ruled that his comments about Senator Vanstone are in order in this debate.

—On the point of order: Madam Deputy President, you are being asked to bring Senator Faulkner to order because a senator opposite does not like the way in which Senator Faulkner is addressing the subject of precedence. On the question of precedence, it is entirely appropriate for this chamber to have canvassed before it the competing issues of what could have been on the agenda and what could have been dealt with.

interjection.para: I submit that it is also entirely appropriate, when looking at that question of precedence, for it to be canvassed on the issue of motive: what is the justification for displacing a particular item on the program with a new item? That goes to the motive of those people who wish to place that matter on the program, and to some extent that is what is being dealt with here.

talk.start.para: —What absolute rubbish!

—Senators opposite can interject and disparage as much as they like, but nonetheless it does not go to the point, and the point is that in a debate on precedence there is a wide-ranging opportunity for all elements attaching to the issue of precedence to be canvassed. That is what is being done here. I think that the Leader of the Opposition is entirely in order.

—Senator Knowles, in this particular debate, senators are being asked to justify why they think precedence should or should not be given. I ask all speakers who are speaking in this debate on the current motion to speak to that particular motion.

—As I was saying in relation to the issue of precedence before the chair, why does this particular matter deserve any more precedence? The opposition did not come forward and move a censure motion when Senator Vanstone was responsible for the hike in HECS and when science enrolments dropped across Australia. That was the time when Senator Vanstone and also the then science minister, Mr McGauran—remember him?—blamed the schools. Neither blamed themselves, but the opposition blamed Senator Vanstone. We did not ask for precedence at that time to come in and talk about Senator Vanstone's incompetence.

speech.para: Then we got to the budget in 1996, when Senator Vanstone went forth as a minister with an eye to the bottom line but not to any of the social and economic repercussions of her policies. She savaged her department to the tune of $1.8 billion of cuts.

talk.start.para: —How much!

—There were cuts of $1.8 billion with the destruction of labour market programs, the destruction of skillshare and other mechanisms that the Labor government put in place to ameliorate long-term unemployment—and particularly youth unemployment—in this country. This was the minister that was responsible for that course of action.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order: you ruled a moment ago that under standing order 194 senators' comments should be constrained within the area of debate on precedence. Senator Faulkner has deliberately defied that ruling and is now continuing to talk about Senator Vanstone and education funding, and everything else that is irrelevant to this debate. I ask you again: I take the point of order on standing order 194(1) and ask you to make a ruling accordingly.
—You are an idiot.
—My ruling is that Senator Faulkner is giving reasons why he thinks it should not be given precedence and is quoting other examples when he thought it could perhaps have been used.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order: I distinctly heard Senator Conroy call Senator Vanstone an `idiot' and I require him to withdraw it.
—Senator Conroy, would you please withdraw.
—Was it the tone that I called her an idiot or the actual fact that she is an idiot that you would like me to withdraw?
—The fact that you have used unparliamentary language, Senator Conroy. Would you please withdraw it.
—I withdraw.
—If we were not debating this motion, we would be dealing with serious issues before the Senate—
—Federal-state relations.
—Yes. Senator Carr has placed on notice this motion—I might say that at lunchtime the Manager of Government Business in the Senate moved that we deal with this issue this afternoon—which reads:

speech.para: That the Senate notes the Government's inability to work cooperatively with the States, as evidenced by its failure to negotiate agreements with the States to the detriment of service delivery in a number of important policy areas, in particular, the failure to reach a satisfactory agreement on the Medicare agreement, the Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement, Enrolment Benchmarking and Schools Policy—
I interpolate to say, the very issue I have just been speaking of—
the Australian National Training Authority—
another issue I have canvassed—
Legal Aid and the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement.
These are important issues, and they deserve precedence over this mindless political stunt that has been proposed by Senator Vanstone.

I recall, as some other senators might, when Senator Vanstone slashed her own department's budget by $1.8 billion—do you remember what she said about it? I do. I just remember that a `mere nick' is what she said about those cuts.

But that all pales into insignificance compared with her efforts on the Wright family. It is not as if we proposed to up-end Senate business to deal with the issue of the Wright family. The creation of the fictitious Wright family was an infamous performance by this minister. Senator Vanstone is criticising Senator Bolkus for alleged leaks to the media. This is the same minister that allowed a story to go on the front-page of the Daily Telegraph in Sydney uncorrected and who had to be exposed again by the opposition in estimates committee hearings. I remember that the Sydney Morning Herald on 18 October that year said:
Mr Howard is wrong to be tolerant about (Senator Vanstone's) performance. Ministerial heads have rolled for less than Senator Vanstone's folly.
This is the same minister that has asked this Senate to give precedence to this political stunt and asks the opposition to support it.

An issue that I wanted to raise in the debate this afternoon, when I have an opportunity to speak on Senator Carr's motion, is the fact that Senator Vanstone misled the Senate over projections for unemployment reductions when she—

talk.start.para: —Don't forget the Wright family.
—Senator Ray, you were not listening. I have mentioned the fictitious Wright family.
—I wasn't!
—Senator Ray will be disciplined for not hearing that very important part of the contribution that I have made.
—Senator Faulkner, would you like to address the chair please.

—Madam Deputy President, in a general business debate before the chamber this afternoon, we would have been able to mention the fact that Senator Vanstone misled the Senate over her projections for unemployment reductions when she claimed that the Labor government did not have departmental advice that a five per cent unemployment rate could be achieved. Senator Vanstone also misled the Senate, and I might say no censure motion was proposed or moved.
—No.
—No censure motion was proposed or moved.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order—
—You have remembered to come! You have turned up. Very good!
—Order!

—I would like to thank you for that welcome. Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order on the irrelevance of the contribution made by Senator Faulkner. What is happening here is quite transparent: it is a filibuster to avoid the debate of the substantive motion which is a censure. One can only ask what Labor has to hide and what Senator Bolkus has to hide. Why is it necessary to filibuster rather than face the music? Why can't the Australian people hear Senator Bolkus's explanation so that judgments can be made.
—What's your point of order?
—Order! Senator Hill, would you care to address the chair, please, instead of debating the issue.
—I am sorry, Madam Deputy President. That should happen so that judgment can be made as to whether or not he should be censured. Isn't that what the Senate should be debating this afternoon?
—What's your point of order?
—Order! Senator Murphy.

—The point of order is that Senator Faulkner is filibustering and not arguing precedence at all. He is not arguing it because the next item of business was taking note of answers from question time. He is not arguing that that should take precedence, but he is filibustering because the Labor Party clearly has something to hide. Clearly Senator Bolkus has something to hide, otherwise Senator Bolkus would be in here prepared to answer the case. Why won't he answer the case? One can only assume guilt.
—Senator Hill, you are beginning to debate the issue.

—Madam Deputy President, on the point of order, I do think that I have been making a persuasive case, but that is in the eye of the beholder. If the Senate were not debating this—what I consider to be a political stunt proposed by Senator Vanstone—we would soon be dealing with general business matters. Of course, if precedence is given to the censure motion, then the Senate will not have an opportunity to deal with the sorts of issues I am speaking about. I submit to you that my comments are directly relevant to the motion before the chair. I would appreciate the opportunity not to be interrupted by members of the govern ment as I continue to make what I believe is a strong case.

—Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition is quite clearly not addressing the motion before the chair. It is obvious that he and the Labor Party are simply filibustering. One can only ask why that is. Why won't Senator Bolkus answer the charges that are against him? Why are they trying to stop debate on this very important issue? If you were to rule that Senator Faulkner should get on with the substantive part of this motion, then we could get on to the debate about Senator Bolkus and give Senator Bolkus the opportunity to answer these allegations. Why is it that the Labor Party do not want this done? Why don't they want debate on this? That is the point to be considered in dealing with this point of order.

—Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator Faulkner, for those of you who are actually listening, has already talked about taking note. He is now talking about the general business items. If necessary, I am sure he will be talking about the committee reports and government documents that are being taken away by the government's stunt.

—There is no point of order. We are debating the reasons why precedence should or should not be given. People have the right to have 20 minutes to speak. We will continue this debate until the time has expired.

—If we were not dealing with this slimy and sleazy political stunt that Senator Vanstone has proposed, we would be able to deal in general business with the fact that Senator Vanstone misled the Senate over the level of university fees charged in overseas institutions. Again, that is something that we did not move a censure motion on, though I believe it would have been successful if we had. I am glad Senator Stott Despoja is in the chamber at the moment, because she would probably recall the misleading of the Senate by Senator Vanstone over a Democrats Internet e-mail question. That was during a half-smart dorothy dixer from the government. So this is the record of Senator Vanstone. These are substantive issues that we would be dealing with if we did not have this slimy, sleazy stunt from Senator Vanstone about Senator Bolkus.

speech.para: Frankly, I think that Senator Vanstone, instead of trying to argue for precedence for this motion, would be much better getting her office organised. She has the worst record of any minister in relation to answers to questions on notice.

talk.start.para: —Not even Dom Perignon overcomes it.
—It might have been Dom Perignon one Christmas, but the next Christmas it was strychnine.
—Senator Faulkner, would you please address the chair and relate your comments to precedence.

—Some of the answers to questions on notice from this minister have taken nearly a year to answer. We could be dealing with those issues and not providing precedence for this slimy stunt. Senator Vanstone ought to be concentrating on these other issues. That is what she should be doing. She should be getting her office into order. It should not be hard. She has hardly got any—
—She has a lot less staff.

—She has hardly any staff left since she has been sacked. It is not as though she has much work to do any more. It should not be hard to get the old questions on notice churned out, but she does not seem to be able to do it.

speech.para: I wanted to have the opportunity—and I hope I will get it this afternoon in the general business debate—to raise the issue of Senator Vanstone's blunder in relation to the Austudy actual means test, which I am sure everyone remembers. That went on for a couple of months. Senator Vanstone did not do a thing about it. Then, of course, she announced the changes when university students had actually decided to quit university because they could not afford to go. Her policies and her administration caused genuine hardship amongst young Australians and heartache amongst poorer families. They got caught out by the botched means test administered by this hopeless minister over there. I think 7,000 or 10,000 families and students were affected by this.

I am reminded about the ship of fools. I had intended to raise this also in the general business debate because it is an important point to make. Did the opposition come into the Senate and move a censure motion on the ship of fools, the botched South Pacific Cruise Lines issue? This minister deserved to be sacked for her incompetence in the administration of her own department. Did the opposition move a censure motion against this incompetent minister? No, we did not.

We are offended. The minister responsible for those foul-ups and botch-ups was sacked by the Prime Minister, who will not give her precedence. The Prime Minister does not given Senator Vanstone precedence, so why should we? That is the real point. This is the minister who after she was dumped and handed back the bottle of Dom Perignon became the Minister for Justice with no staff, hardly any responsibilities, nothing to do with her time and plenty of time to do the odd fuzzy media interview and the like.

However, this is the same minister, as the Minister for Justice, who has been responsible for presiding over the extraordinary cuts to the Australian Federal Police. I do not think any senator should forget that.

talk.start.para: —And the NCA—no, not that one. You can't blame her for that one.
—But I do, Senator Ray. There was the $8.9 million cut when an AFP minute dated 28 January showed that the AFP has a funding shortfall of $18.1 million this year alone.

speech.para: We would have raised this under the general business item on Commonwealth-state relations, but this is also the same minister who accused Victoria of not honouring the agreement on uniform national gun laws by moving to remove the 28-day waiting period for second and subsequent gun licences when Western Australia has not put this measure in place since 1996 and when neither Senator Vanstone nor her predecessor, the then Minister for Justice, Mr Williams, did anything about it.

This is the same minister who comes into this chamber and seriously tries to move a motion that we should give her precedence when her own party, her own government and her own Prime Minister show what they think of her by properly dumping her to where you deserve, dumping you right down the bottom of the list of the outer ministry because you are incompetent, because you are an embarrassment to your government and your colleagues—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Faulkner, please address the chair.
—Point of order, Madam Deputy President. Did I just hear you asking him to address his comments through the chair? If you did, that was the point of order I was going to bring up.
—Yes, I did.
—Thank you. I ask that you insist that he does that.
—Senator Faulkner, would you please address the chair.
—The point I was making through you, Madam Deputy President, is that this minister is hopeless. She asks for precedence when her own Prime Minister has shown what precedence she deserves—
—Shown her the door.

—He has shown her the door. He has dumped her. He has sacked her and she deserved it. She is one of the most incompetent ministers in the history of Commonwealth administration. For all those reasons we will not support the motion to give this matter precedence.
—Precedence should clearly be given to this motion. There is a huge number of reasons—
—Huge; huge reasons.
—Order on my left!
—And the substance of the motion has been set out.
—Really, really big ones?
—Unfortunately, Senator Evans, absolutely huge. You ought to be doing the right thing by Senator Bolkus and cut him loose now because he is swinging in the breeze.

speech.para: I remind this place of the importance of parliamentary standards. On one occasion a shadow minister in the Howard shadow ministry—one Mr McLachlan—was the recipient of some confidential documents that were delivered to his office. He was not aware that they were of that nature, but as soon as it was pointed out to him that they were of such a nature, what did he do? He resigned. That is all that Mr Beazley needs to do in relation to Senator Bolkus.

Senator Bolkus has been peddling a leaked document. What is more, unlike Mr McLachlan, he did so deliberately and knowingly. How do I make that allegation? From the words spoken out of Senator Bolkus's own mouth, from the transcript that was taken where he says, `I can't give this document out, but maybe'—

talk.start.para: —Point of order, Madam Deputy President. I draw your attention to standing order 194(1), which says:

interjection.para: A senator shall not digress from the subject matter of any question under discussion, or anticipate the discussion of any subject which appears on the Notice Paper.
Certainly the first part of that is very appropriate in this instance. The good senator has not yet addressed the question of precedence.

talk.start.para: —On the point of order: Madam Deputy President, I urge you to be consistent. I believe Senator Abetz—unfortunately, Senator Quirke—is well within his rights with what he is going to. You have let a fairly wide debate as to the interpretation of precedence. I think Senator Abetz is absolutely in order and you should dismiss the point of order.
—There is no point of order. I am sure Senator Abetz will, as Senator Faulkner did, get to relating it back somehow.
—Except I will do it with more style and more grace. Senator Bolkus is on record as saying in relation to these peddled documents that were confidential:

speech.para: I can't give this document out, but maybe if I just read it out off the record.

He knew what he was doing. He knew that he could not deal with these documents on the record. So, as I asserted before, he deliberately and knowingly peddled documents which he knew were confidential and should remain confidential.

Why should this matter be given precedence? There were four courts around the world that held that the matter which was the subject of this affidavit was of such an important nature that it should remain confidential. Those courts were in the Cayman Islands, in Spain, in London and our own Federal Court. Four courts around the world said it should remain confidential. Senator Bolkus admits to as much in the transcript of the interview when he tells the assembled media:
In terms of secrecy, four courts across the world have deemed it appropriate for the proceedings to be in secret.

Yet he deliberately went out to seek to divulge and peddle this information despite the ruling of four courts around the world—and that from the would-be first law officer of this country! If Kim Beazley were ever to become Prime Minister, the person who peddled these confidential Federal Court documents, who peddled this information to absolutely prejudice the case against Skase would become the Attorney-General of this country. I have to say to you that, when you look at the standards of the opposition as we then were, with Mr McLachlan, compared to the opposition as they now are with Senator Bolkus, the standards are in very stark contrast.

talk.start.para: —What about Vanstone and the Wright family?

—Senator Murphy says, `What about Senator Vanstone?' I will tell you. When Senator Vanstone received departmental confidential documents, she did not seek to use them for her own benefit. What did she do? She gave them back to the government. You see, they are the standards that we on this side abide by. When people breach those accepted standards, we should be debating it and dealing with it as a matter of precedence, as a matter of importance to the wellbeing of the parliamentary democracy in this country.

speech.para: Millions of dollars have escaped Australia. A lot of people are out of pocket as a result of Mr Skase's antics.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I would have thought there would be a degree of maturity shown by the opposition so that we could deal with the Skase matter in a bipartisan manner. There is no benefit in the parliamentary sense in anybody getting Skase; the benefit is for the Australian people. You have to ask yourself: why did Senator Bolkus seek to divulge this information to the media? Might I add, to their great credit they did not use it. Even the journalists had a higher standard of propriety than the would-be Attorney-General of this country. That is saying something.

speech.para: The journalists refused to peddle the information that Senator Bolkus was seeking to peddle. If journalists will not write something for the purpose of a good story—and they usually do—if even they desist, doesn't that reflect on the would-be Attorney-General's behaviour and integrity? Indeed, it shows up the sort of character that he is. It is a clear example of undermining the authority of the Federal Court. If we believe in the rule of law in this country, if we seek to believe in the proper administration of justice in this country, then we ought be very concerned about the behaviour that has now been outlined chapter and verse and not denied by Senator Bolkus.

I turn to the assertion as to whether or not this is a matter currently before the Federal Police. We do not know whether it is or not other than that the matter has been referred, and that is in relation to the leak. Especially for the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Stott Despoja, who I note is returning to the chamber, if you read very carefully the wording of the motion, it does not accuse Senator Bolkus of leaking the information but simply of revealing certain contents of a confidential Federal Court affidavit.

What is Senator Bolkus's defence? He said, `Well, I knew it was confidential. I knew I shouldn't do it but it was already in the public domain, so it was okay.' That is like saying, `Well, somebody else has committed this crime so it's okay for me to commit it as well.' What a terrible set of standards for the would-be Attorney-General of this country. That is the only defence that Senator Bolkus has proffered to this place or indeed to the people of Australia.

Let us not be fooled by that assertion that we might be prejudicing a police investigation. Indeed, if the Labor Party were genuinely concerned about prejudicing investigations and legal processes, why on earth did they allow their shadow Attorney-General to peddle confidential documents from the Federal Court? You cannot have it both ways. You clearly are trying to, but you have been exposed.

I have to say that not a single member of the Australian Labor Party today, in this chamber or the House of Representatives, has sought to stand by Senator Bolkus and say that what he did was right, that it was full of integrity, that it was acceptable behaviour within the appropriate standards and within the sort of conduct one would expect of a shadow Attorney-General. There has not been a single word of defence; just a bucketing of the previous conduct of people on this side.

The only conduct on this side that goes anywhere near what occurred is the example I set out at the very beginning of my contribution. That is, when Mr McLachlan did so inadvertently, he did the decent thing and resigned. Senator Bolkus did an indecent thing knowingly—he knowingly and deliberately divulged the information—and he still continues to refuse to resign. What is more, his leader is too weak to force him to resign or to sack him.

This matter ought be taking precedence over all other matters because we are talking about some very fundamental principles here of the behaviour of the shadow Attorney-General. If a terrible fate were to befall this country and Kim Beazley were to become Prime Minister, Senator Bolkus might in fact become the Attorney-General and the first law officer of this country—a very serious matter indeed. Somebody who would peddle in confidential, Federal Court documents knowingly and deliberately—

talk.start.para: —If he were a practising lawyer, he would be struck off.

—Indeed, as Senator Coonan has just interjected—and it ought go on the record—if a practising solicitor were caught doing something like that, there is a very fair chance they would be struck off the register of legal practitioners, yet Mr Beazley is too weak to strike him off the front bench. That is the telling point in this debate. That is why this matter ought be taking precedence. Senator Coonan has made a very telling point by that interjection. If the Law Society would strike off a lawyer for doing something like that, the question remains: why doesn't Mr Beazley strike off Senator Bolkus?

—I was very pleased to hear from Senator Abetz, the Bristow of the Liberal Party, 23rd in line for Attorney-General on their side of the house. This was all an exercise to prevent us from noting answers today. After a devastating question time when we had them on the back foot, they invented this at the last moment because we had some serious matters to note. We were going to almost bring the government down, and what happens? This brilliant, machiavellian Senator Vanstone, coming to the aid of the embattled Senator Hill, decided to move a censure motion.

speech.para: She argued the urgency of this and why it should have precedence. Even though she raised it on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, it suddenly should have precedence on Thursday. Guess what, Senator Vanstone. There have been two censure motions contemplated and under way against Labor members, both on a Thursday. You never do this on a Monday, Tuesday or Wednesday when you will impair government business. You do it on a Thursday. Let me say that we should have been able to note answers today. I think that should have higher precedence, and this is the nub of my argument. This matter should not have precedence over noting of answers, nor do I think it should have precedence over general business.

Let me digress for a moment. One of my colleagues is terribly distraught over this. One of my colleagues had expectations, had his hopes up, that the Ballast Water Research and Development Funding Levy Collection Bill 1997 may have been considered this afternoon. He had put hard work into it. He had put emotional time into it, and there sits a forlorn Senator Forshaw, unable to pursue this. He alone requires precedence for that particular matter, let alone Senator Vanstone.

But today, if we had been able to pursue Senator Hill, we would have wanted to know why he will not answer the question of who in his office directed the re-evaluation of some rejected proposals under the Natural Heritage Trust. That is what we would have wanted to ask. Who was it in his office?

talk.start.para: —Who in your office couldn't even check up the directors of companies?
—Senator Campbell, the ex-campaign director in Stirling, wants to interrupt and broaden the debate—
—I've never been a campaign director in Stirling.

—Never been a campaign director in Stirling? Oh, obviously some other investigation was not accurately reported. We would have wanted to ask Senator Hill who suddenly from his office, without his knowledge apparently, directed that these grants in Victoria and Queensland—not, note, in Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania or New South Wales—should be reopened. Then we would have wanted to know what lobbying efforts went in. It is not wrong, by the way, having reopened them for someone like Mr Entsch or anyone else to lobby to get these failed projects—because they were not bad projects in the main—back on the agenda. There is nothing wrong with that. Where the crux of this comes is where you have ministerial discretion. It is who has the ability to talk to the decision maker that becomes critical. If it is only limited to certain cronies to do so, like Mr Entsch—

speech.para: Senator Lightfoot interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Lightfoot is talking about stolen documents. Senator Lightfoot, why don't you go back and read the evidence of what happened to the two aide-memoires that disappeared out of the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to protect the Prime Minister when he accused Mr Beazley and Senator Evans of being perverters of the course of justice—when he, his staff or someone disappeared the very documents that argued to the opposite? Why don't you go and have a censure motion on that, Senator Lightfoot, if you are so keen? If you are the Inspector Javert out of Les Miserables of the Liberal Party—and it is a good role for you—why don't you go and pursue that particular matter?
—Inspector Clouseau.

—No, he is not Inspector Clouseau. That is going just a little beyond. I know your disappointment has got to you, Senator Forshaw, but I can assure you that we will get to the Ballast Water Research and Development Funding Levy Collection Bill 1997 , and you will be able to give that scintillating speech that is just waiting to break out.
—Order! It being 4.30 p.m., the Senate will now proceed to the consideration of general business notice of motion No. 937.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate notes the Government's inability to work cooperatively with the States, as evidenced by its failure to negotiate agreements with the States to the detriment of service delivery in a number of important policy areas, in particular, the failure to reach a satisfactory agreement on the Medicare agreement, the Commonwealth/State Disability Agreement, Enrolment Benchmarking and Schools Policy, the Australian National Training Authority, Legal Aid and the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement.

The motion before the Senate draws attention to severe difficulties that seem to have developed between the Commonwealth and the states. I suppose you would have assumed that that could have been expected between the Commonwealth and states like New South Wales where there are Labor governments, but I certainly do not understand why a Commonwealth government, dealing with its political brethren in the other states, should have so much of a struggle as it seems to have had.

The only conclusion that can be made about this particular government, this coalition government, is that it does not cooperate very well with other people, and it certainly does not cooperate well with the state governments. That might be something that could be seen to be amusing. You could have report cards saying, `Does not play well in the playground.' It could be funny, except it has extraordinarily severe consequences for most of the Australian people because most of the arrangements that make the situation of the Australian people unbearable arise because of the arrangements that are made between the Commonwealth and the states.

Some of the difficulties in areas are shown here in this particular motion, but I have to say that it is evident in all sorts of arrangements that normally would go on between the Commonwealth and the states. In every area, this government does not understand what `negotiation' really means. This government does not understand what `consultation' really means. In every area where it actually has to consult and negotiate, this government believes that walking into the room and saying, `This is what we're going to do. Take it or leave it,' is negotiation and consultation.

The area that I am particularly concerned about today and would like to spend some time on is the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. This agreement is an agreement between the Commonwealth and the states and is a particularly longstanding arrangement. In fact, these agreements have been in place since 1945. It is quite astonishing that an agreement that has been negotiated by various governments—both coalition and Labor governments—seems to be causing a great deal of trouble for this particular government. But, of course, this is not the only area of concern. Later we will be looking at the areas of health and disabilities where this government has been quite uninterested and, I think, quite reckless in dealing with the rights and entitlements of disabled people in the community.

The failure of this government to finalise a lot of Commonwealth and state agreements has meant that services that everyday, average Australians rely on are essentially falling apart. When this coalition government was elected, there was an existing Commonwealth-state housing agreement in the housing arena. Essentially, a new agreement should have been negotiated almost immediately, but this government was unable to achieve that.

It struggled on until November of last year where it essentially did not actually negotiate a new agreement because that was beyond its capacity. But the government told the states that it would provide funding for a further 12 months on similar lines but with some additions and, of course, that level of funding was not at the same level that it has been to date. It is quite interesting to look at the coalition's election policy, which states:

The Commonwealth-state housing agreement has provided a framework for establishing public and community housing stock. It remains the most appropriate vehicle for achieving the Liberal and National parties' goals in the efficient provision of public and community housing.

I wonder how that sits comfortably with a coalition government which is uncommitted to a Commonwealth-state housing agreement. In fact, at the last estimates when I was questioning the department about the housing agreement, I was advised that, in fact, this latest interim agreement, which I suppose is what you might describe it as, which is for a period of one year, is likely to be the last agreement ever to be signed.

So after 50-odd years of having a Commonwealth-state housing agreement, this government is no longer able to achieve a uniform provision of housing services across Australia because of its incompetence and incapacity in consultation and negotiation. In fact, the government has said that it will negotiate—I think a word unknown to this government—with each state individually and will work out on an ad hoc basis what sort of funding will be provided for housing and what the benchmarks and key indicators will be.

This is an extraordinarily sad development. It is sad for the Commonwealth and for the states, and it is also sad for the large numbers of public housing tenants who rely on some sort of certainty in the arrangements to ensure that they have security in their housing.

In fact, the previous government decided that there should be a three-year agreement so that there could be some certainty and so that the states could develop a more long-term strategy to adequately fund public housing. This, of course, has been an ongoing criticism in all areas. But particularly in housing, a short-term funding arrangement—finding out each year how much funding will be provided for housing—has meant there is a lack of long-term strategies and a deterioration in housing stock.

Senators on both sides will acknowledge that in many areas there has been a vast deterioration in the quality of housing. I am advised as I travel around that, particularly in the state of South Australia, there is a crisis occurring in the standard of housing that presently exists. I have to say in passing that, I suppose because of a bit of a hangover from the days of Don Dunstan in South Australia, in terms of the proportion of population that has access to public housing, South Australia has done particularly well.

When I was advised by officers of the department that in fact there might never be another Commonwealth-state housing agreement, I was very concerned because, in recent times, one of the ideas that have been embraced is that wherever you live in Australia, whatever your circumstances are in terms of your geographic location, you should be able to rely on the same quality of housing and have the same access to housing, bearing in mind your age, your employment situation and, in general, your need. But that is no longer the case.

If a general agreement that covers the whole of Australia is no longer applied, if you are a young unemployed person of 18 years and if you live in South Australia, then you might access housing, if you live in New South Wales you might not, and if you live in the ACT you might access it if you wait for a couple of years. It is extraordinarily important for people within Australia—which is one nation, not six—to feel that they can rely on one criterion, that they can rely on a particular standard of housing and that they can have security of housing.

In 1995, before the election, the Labor government had already done most of the legwork for another Commonwealth-state housing agreement. It had already negotiated with the states pretty much what the new agreement would look like. In fact, the states were quite desperate to sign an agreement as soon as the election was over. It seems quite extraordinary, in light of that situation, that in fact it took until November 1997 for this coalition government to get around to signing what was in reality, I suppose, a short extension rather than a completely new agreement.

But that is very much in accord with the general view of this government. It is not about governing for the general good of the community; it is about enhancing conflict, it is about playing off one party against another—in this case, one state against another state. It is not at all concerned about ensuring that there is high quality housing available for public housing tenants and that the states are adequately funded to provide it.

This also happened in relation to state-Commonwealth agreements on legal aid. There was a debacle, a slanging match, between the Commonwealth and each state Attorney-General about exactly how much would be provided. The Commonwealth was trying to pick off one state individually and then pick off another. It asked the states to accept fairly large cuts and told them that, if they did not accept fairly quickly, the amount of funding provided would be even less than was initially offered.

As I understand it, after just under 18 months of slanging matches between the Commonwealth and the states, agreements in relation to legal aid were signed with all states except New South Wales. That is not terribly extraordinary bearing in mind that, on a proportionate basis, New South Wales was being told—I will not say `asked' because there is no negotiation in these sorts of arrangements with this present government— that they were to bear the largest proportion of all cuts in legal aid.

Senators may remember the sort of distress expressed in the community regarding those cuts in legal aid. We had a situation where the Commonwealth said, `We will only fund those sorts of legal matters that arise directly from federal legislation.' On the face of it, I suppose that could be seen as somewhat attractive and perhaps even fair but, when you look at the detail of it and examine what it really means, it is very far from adequate and very far from fair.

There are some very serious areas that come strictly within state legislation that I believe the federal government should be funding. One such area is domestic violence. How the federal government can say, `Because domestic violence actions arise under state legislation, it is not the responsibility of the federal government to support women who are trying to protect themselves from violence in their own homes', I find quite extraordinary. That is only one of many examples of areas where the Commonwealth shrugged its shoulders and, despite the protests of the states—and I mean all states—failed to provide adequate funding and negotiate a reasonable agreement under the Commonwealth-state legal aid arrangements.

It goes on and on, because they failed under the Medicare agreements as well. Senator Forshaw will be talking about that.
