They failed under the disability agreements; they failed in relation to enrolment benchmarking and the schools policy. In all those areas, this government has failed to reasonably negotiate any Commonwealth-state agreement which has the wholehearted support of the states, because they do not believe that it is reasonable to have regard to the rights and needs of every Australian. They think it is just about cutting back the dollars and making sure that the states fund more than they do.

talk.start.para: —Today we are debating a rather remarkable motion moved by Senator Neal on behalf of Senator Carr. It deals with what he claims is the government's inability to work cooperatively with the states, as evidenced by its failure to negotiate certain agreements. It is interesting that such a claim should be made and it was interesting to hear Senator Neal's contribution a moment ago, as a senator for New South Wales. I was waiting for her to refer to the predicament and circumstance surrounding her own Labor government in New South Wales and the health minister's position in that state.

speech.para: The New South Wales Labor Deputy Premier and health minister, Dr Andrew Refshauge—he is also the Chairman of the Australian Health Ministers Conference—gave a very fascinating interview on the ABC back in February. It gave a very, very good insight into the confusion of the Labor Party at a state level, and also probably the confusion that is so often demonstrated by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) at a federal level, about the issue of funding. Dr Refshauge said:

Well, I think it has got to be really for John Howard and Peter Costello and the others in the Cabinet to recognise they're predicting a two and a half billion dollar surplus this year, (so) what is their interests? Are their interests the preservation of Medicare and the treatment of patients in this nation, or are they interested in having a two and a half billion dollar deficit? We are saying—
`we' being the Labor Party—
that some of that deficit should be spent on looking after patients in this nation.

Isn't that fascinating? Your own Labor minister in New South Wales is advocating spending money that is not there—spending money on the deficit. He does not know the difference between a deficit and a surplus. His maths are simply as bad as Mr Beazley's.

talk.start.para: —It is the only state in Australia with a deficit.

—That is exactly right, Senator Campbell. People will recall that Mr Beazley, as Finance Minister and Deputy Prime Minister in the Keating government, told Australians before the last election that we were operating in surplus. He said, `Our projections are for surpluses in the future.' They were the words of Mr Beazley prior to the last election. He did not know and understand the difference between deficit and surplus either, because he told the Australian people, prior to the last election, that we were operating in surplus.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is it in order for the senator to make such an outrageous untruth in respect of a state minister? She alleged that Dr Refshauge had called on the federal government to draw health funds from a $2½ billion budget deficit. I have here in front of me a press report of Dr Refshauge's comments. His comments specifically refer to a surplus, not to a deficit.
—If you want to join the debate, put your name on the list. Don't debate it. What is your point of order?
—The point of order is that the honourable senator should at least have the decency to tell the truth.
—Sit down, you stupid fool.
—Senator Campbell, that is of no assistance to the deliberations in this place either. Senator Forshaw, there is no point of order.
—I remind the Senate that the words I quoted were not mine. They were Dr Refshauge's.
—They are wrong. There it is. You are wrong. Someone has given you the wrong quote, my dear.

—They were from a transcript of an interview that Dr Refshauge undertook. Therefore, I am simply quoting Dr Refshauge's words in the same way I am quoting Mr Beazley's words when he said, `We are operating'—`we' being the Labor government—`in surplus and our projections are for surpluses in the future.' They were his words. The honourable senator can rabbit on all he likes about his version of events. I am simply repeating the words.

speech.para: At the time when Mr Beazley was making those comments, he knew—as the rest of Australia now knows—that the budget was actually in a $10.3 billion deficit, not a surplus. The coalition has had to work hard and take a lot of difficult decisions to repair this awful black hole in the Commonwealth budget.

Dr Refshauge demonstrated that the same confusion about the difference between surpluses and deficits exists in the New South Wales government. If the Commonwealth budget were in deficit—which, thankfully, it will not be in the coming budget, but no thanks to the Labor Party in the state or Commonwealth arenas—you could justify some of his comments as being a mistake. But he knows that that is not true. You could understand how he could be so confused.
Why did not a senator from New South Wales talk about the fact that New South Wales will not come to the party? The situation in New South Wales is absolutely and utterly appalling in every area.

One of the other things that is listed here—it is not just the Medicare agreement—is the Commonwealth-state disability agreement. While talking about New South Wales, I would like to ask the honourable senators from the Labor Party whether they can give the Senate some justification as to why the New South Wales Labor government failed to keep pace with other state and Commonwealth moneys in increasing funding for disability services over the last six years? Why is its per head funding only half of that of Victoria? Why does New South Wales say that the Commonwealth should put in more funds when Commonwealth increases in that state over the last six years were much larger? They were 84 per cent against 50 per cent.

The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare says that an increase in funding of $294 million is needed in areas which are a state government responsibility. What sort of increase in funding does New South Wales plan over the next four years? None of this was covered by a senator from New South Wales. It will be interesting to see whether another senator covers it. Will it at least guarantee to keep pace with population growth? Will it at least guarantee not to reduce its present levels of funding over the next four years?

It has to also be said that accommodation support for people with disabilities is, and always has been, a responsibility of the state governments. Funnily enough, when Senator Neal and Senator Forshaw et al were in government, they never actually made that point; but now that they are in opposition, they are quite clearly saying that it is the Commonwealth's responsibility.

The Commonwealth has a very small involvement, but it has provided substantial increases in funding. The Commonwealth is offering an increase in funding of 14.2 per cent between now and the year 2001-02. Yet Senator Neal just continues to spread these furphies around. This funding is on the table and guaranteed in each year.

The New South Wales Labor state government will not promise any increase. It will not promise that there will be no cuts. It will not even declare what its funding will be over the next four years. Why does the New South Wales state government say that unmet need is the Commonwealth's fault? The Commonwealth is offering New South Wales $56 million extra over current funding levels over the five years. So why is New South Wales refusing to take this money if unmet need is so bad?

I wanted to put those particular issues on the record because the only Labor state government in this country is cutting back funding year by year and trying to shift that funding back onto the Commonwealth, and the Labor opposition in this place is aiding and abetting it. The 1997-98 budget estimate for Commonwealth payments to the states under the Medicare agreements is $4,900 million, an increase of $175.5 million. That is on the 1996-97 estimate. Now 99.9 per cent of this is for payments to the states with the remaining $7.2 million going to national projects.

Since the budget, hospital funding grant estimates have been updated, including for revised data on the number of people living with AIDS, variations to the agreements which have been accepted by the states relating to funding for adult heart and liver transplants, drug therapy for AIDS patients and 1996-97 actuals. The current approved estimate for 1997-98 is $4,997 million dollars, bringing real growth over the five years to about 15 per cent.

Here we have the Labor government in New South Wales cutting their funding and we have the Labor opposition in this place saying that we should increase the funding. If they think that is the correct course of action, why did they not do that? They simply did not, but now that they are in opposition they are so politically expedient that they could not care about the way in which this country is run, and that is why we were confronted with a $10.3 billion deficit—not a surplus—when we came to government.

The need for flexibility and service delivery options is being considered in the context of the next agreements. This is something that the Labor government did not do. The Commonwealth intends to work cooperatively with the states and territories to achieve reform within the context of our commitment to retain Medicare in its entirety.

The issue of increased pressure on our public hospitals will be addressed constructively through the implementation of reforms in the context of the agreements. On that point, it is worth noting that one other issue that the Labor Party refuses to acknowledge is the fact that the coalition government will provide up to $120 million for action on waiting lists, with $4 million released each week commencing on 16 March. What they are saying is that the funding is constantly being cut. This is a genuine offer to the states and territories to help them reduce waiting lists and is additional assistance that they have been seeking for some time.

When talking about waiting lists, it is always worth remembering why there is a waiting list problem in the first place. What happened under 13 years of Labor was that private health insurance membership went from between 60 and 70 per cent down to 30-odd per cent. Therefore, the demand on public hospitals increased enormously. What did the Labor Party in government do about that problem? Absolutely nothing. So now that a coalition government is in office, it has decided to try to address some of the problem that Labor created by giving the states $120 million to help resolve the problem of waiting lists.

In preliminary discussions with the state and territory health ministers last year, the government was able to agree on a vision for the health system into the next century and the principles that should underlie the agreements and support worthwhile reform of the system. The Commonwealth's offer is consistent with these principles and supports the reform process with both structure and dollars. It is important to know that in terms of structure the offer would allow funding to flow between sectors and support improved integration of care and better patient outcomes. They should surely be priorities with which Labor agrees. But no, their political partisan nature will not allow them to say that that is an acceptable, sensible and desirable course of action.

In terms of dollars, the offer includes half a billion dollars to be spent on projects to improve the system, including devising means to improve integration of care—particularly for the aged—improving the use of information technology so that patient data goes with the patient instead of following them around, and implementing alternative treatment modalities that do not require expensive acute hospitalisation.

It is clear that the current agreements, negotiated by those opposite, did not deal adequately with changing levels of private health insurance. They just ignored it. They just let it slip. What is now being proposed will actually address this issue by making automatic population-based adjustments to funding as private health insurance participation rates fluctuate.

The Commonwealth this year will provide 19 per cent more funding in real terms for public hospitals than it did in 1992-93 under Labor. I would be very interested to hear what senators who are following in this debate will say about the increase in funding for waiting lists, the increase in funding that I have just referred to for public hospitals, and the other increases in funding. They are grizzling and grizzling, and yet they chose to do nothing.

The fact is that the agreements that were negotiated by Labor also overlooked the fact that states themselves reduced their funding for the first couple of years of the agreements. Did they do anything about making sure that the states rectified that? No, they did not, because quite frankly they thought they were going to be out of government soon after the agreements were signed anyway. The Commonwealth is to make available that $120 million this year, as they sign the new agreements, to help that immediate problem of the waiting lists created by Labor. This government will not repeat the mistakes of Labor, which increased funding by 10 per cent in the first year of the current agreements, and then stood by while the states reduced their funding by an equivalent amount.

On the question of the Commonwealth-state disability agreement, that is even more breathtaking, as I say, because New South Wales in particular is the main state that has decreased its funding right across the board. Questions really need to be answered as to why its per head funding is half that of Victoria, and why the Commonwealth should put in more funds when the state itself is cutting its funding.

The Commonwealth has offered more money to the states for disability services than has ever been offered. So if anyone hears from this point on in this debate that we have cut funding in terms of the CSDA, the Commonwealth-state disability agreement, it is wrong. More money has been offered than ever before. The Commonwealth offer recognises the needs of people with disabilities and provides a substantial increase in the base funding over the next five years. It includes a commitment from the Commonwealth to strategically identify and target resources to areas of unmet need.

This area of unmet need is something that the Labor Party totally ignored. They simply put all the money into a pot and said to the states, `You just spend it however you want.' We are trying to identify different areas of unmet need from state to state, because the Labor Party does not understand that the need and unmet need differs from state to state. Labor's CSDA agreement never acknowledged the extent of unmet need. They should hang their heads in shame that, after 13 years in government, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare report should identify such an unacceptable level of need—which was 13,400 people that you left without anything.

We know that repairing this mess will take time. The new agreements with the states will allow unmet need to be specifically identified and, through a process of joint consultation between all levels of government and the disability sector, resources will be strategically harnessed for the benefit of people with a disability. All of this will occur while current services are maintained and enhanced. Once again, if there is any argument in this debate at any time that we are grinding down services, it is wrong on two counts: all current services are to be maintained and enhanced; and we have offered the states more money than has ever been offered before. I wait to hear the apology from the Labor Party in their contribution to this absolutely and utterly false debate.

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to rise now and speak after Senator Knowles, because it gives me the opportunity to refute many of the falsehoods that were contained in her remarks. My experience on a couple of other occasions has been that I have not had that opportunity because I have preceded her in debates on these issues. Firstly, I want to go to one of the glaring falsehoods contained in her remarks—her supposed quotes from Dr Refshauge, the New South Wales Minister for Health. Senator Knowles quoted from some transcript that, apparently, she has in front of her, and argued that Dr Refshauge had called on the federal government to fund increased expenditure to public hospitals in the states out of a budget deficit. I do not know what document she is reading from, but she had better go and check the source and the accuracy of it, because it is totally inaccurate.

speech.para: The word `deficit' is wrong. She can wave a piece of paper around—I do not know whether she wrote it herself. She can do a Chamberlain act, but it will not get her off the hook. Let me go to the report of the meeting that took place between the federal minister and the state ministers for health not so long ago. I refer to an article in the Weekend Australian on 17 January this year. It states:
Federal Health Minister Michael Wooldridge yesterday snubbed a State ministers' Medicare crisis meeting as they rejected a $100 million federal lure and demanded a new deal from the Commonwealth.
The States—
I emphasis the plural `states'—all states, not just New South Wales—

also warned the Howard Government it risked fighting an election without a public hospital agreement unless it came up with an offer better than the current $1.7 billion. The States have demanded an extra $5.5 billion.
NSW and the federal Opposition called for John Howard to personally intervene and ensure a realistic public hospital funding proposal was put to Cabinet as early as Monday to break the deadlock.

NSW Health Minister Andrew Refshauge, Victorian Minister Rob Knowles and Tasmanian Minister Peter McKay were forced to hold their own meeting and press conference after Dr Wooldridge refused to meet them yesterday.
Why don't you stay, Senator Knowles, and hear the truth for once? The article went on to say:
The latest row erupted after the ACT broke ranks to sign an in-principle, five-year Medicare agreement. The States—
Plural—the states. All the states: the five Liberal-National Party states and New South Wales—
rejected a $100 million waiting list bonus designed to reward those who signed by March.
I would like to stress the following words from this article, because they put the lie to the absolute falsehoods that were perpetrated by Senator Knowles a moment ago. The article states:
At the press conference in Melbourne, Dr Refshauge called on federal Cabinet to draw health funds from the $2.5 billion Budget surplus expected for this financial year.

The first point is that the public knows—because the government keeps crowing about the fact—that, on the government's estimate, they will achieve a surplus of $2.5 billion this year. We will wait and see, but that is their claim, their expectation. The second point is that, clearly, the reporters who were present at the press conference when Dr Refshauge made his remarks correctly heard what Dr Refshauge said. It is as plain as the glasses on your face, Senator Heffernan, that Dr Refshauge called for the government to fund increased health funding out of a budget surplus. For Senator Knowles to start her remarks by claiming that Dr Refshauge said the word `deficit' instead of `surplus' shows, firstly, the depths to which they will descend to try to distort the truth and distort what state ministers such as Dr Refshauge have said and, secondly, shows the puerile nature and paucity of their argument.

Having put that furphy to rest, let us get back to the crux of this issue, which is that there is no agreement between the states and the federal government on health funding under the Medicare agreements. The Medicare agreements have been due to be re-negotiated for some time. Negotiations have been taking place, but no agreement has been reached. Dr Herron, who is present here in the chamber, knows what I am saying is exactly true. Senator Knowles talked as if there was an agreement, but there is no agreement. All the states and the Northern Territory have rejected the proposed offer from Dr Wooldridge and this federal government because they say that it is totally inadequate.

talk.start.para: —The ACT have accepted.

—Dr Herron interjects and says the ACT government accepted the agreement. Let me remind you, Dr Herron, that the reason the ACT government caved in and signed the agreement is well known—it has been asserted by some of your own political colleagues in other states. The reason the ACT government signed the agreement was, firstly, that they were offered an extra $2.5 million a year and, secondly, there was an election on. The Chief Minister, Kate Carnell, and Dr Wooldridge did a sleazy little deal and got the ACT to sign up. Indeed, the ACT government has been criticised by all the other states. The Queensland government, the National Party, the South Australian Liberal government, the Western Australian Liberal government, the Tasmanian Liberal government and the Northern Territory Liberal-Country Party government have all criticised the ACT for breaking ranks on the totally unanimous position that the states and territories have adopted so far.

speech.para: Let us look at what representatives from states other than New South Wales have said. Senator Knowles talked about New South Wales and attacked the performance of Dr Refshauge and the New South Wales government on health and public hospitals. She spoke as though New South Wales was the only state where there is a problem with public hospital funding because this government has ripped over $800 million out of the public hospital system since it came into office, and it has also ripped out $400 million in terms of public dental programs.
Senator Heffernan interjecting—

talk.start.para: —For your benefit, Senator Heffernan, I will quote what has been said by other leaders about the federal government's offer in the latest round of Medicare agreement negotiations. What did Mike Horan, the Minister for Health in Senator Herron's home state of Queensland, say about the government offer? He said that it was a `cynical bribe, little more than a sweetener, and neither here nor there'. That is what your Liberal Party colleague said about Dr Wooldridge's offer.
—He's a Nat—he's not a Liberal Party colleague.

—National Party colleague—my apologies. Dr Napthine, the Victorian acting health minister, said—and Senator Conroy will be interested in this—that `the offer did not come close to the amount needed by the state to meet rising health care costs'. That is what the Liberal Party acting health minister in Victoria said about Dr Wooldridge's offer on Medicare.

speech.para: I will go back to what was said by Mr Horan, because that seemed to raise some interest in Senator Herron. As I said, he referred to it as `a cynical bribe'. On the subsequent offer of an extra $100 million if they all signed up by March, Mr Horan said:
The first we heard of this is when The Courier-Mail put it to us. One would have thought that Minister Wooldridge would have put this to Minister Horan rather than announce it to a press conference.
What a way to conduct negotiations over health policy in this country. Dr Wooldridge has a track record of not attending meetings when he should, and then calling meetings that no-one goes to.

What did Denis Burke, the minister for health in the Northern Territory, say? He said that `millions of extra dollars were needed in the Northern Territory to continue the high level of health care and that the Territory is in very bad shape to maintain its services'. This is the minister in the Northern Territory—not some Labor state like New South Wales; it is one of your lot.

Let us travel across to Senator Knowles's home state of Western Australia. What did the Western Australian health minister say about Dr Wooldridge's offer on Medicare? Mr Kevin Prince said that the offer `was not worth while because the state would lose $30 million in the first year of the new Medicare contract'. That is what the Western Australian health minister said about Dr Wooldridge's proposal. Is it any wonder that there is no agreement and that there is unlikely to be any agreement?

All the states and the Northern Territory—and originally the ACT, but it was bought off because it had an election around the corner—are saying that this government's record on health is atrocious. While we are talking about Western Australia—and it is a pity that Senator Knowles is not here, although Senator Bishop has just come in, and he is from Western Australia—what did Premier Court say about the performance of Dr Wooldridge in respect of the private health insurance incentive scheme—the $1.7 billion scheme that this government introduced that is designed to increase private health insurance coverage?

When the scheme was introduced, at the same time as they ripped pretty close to $1 billion out of public hospital funding, Dr Wooldridge said in the budget papers that levels of private health insurance would increase to 34 per cent by the end of this financial year. As of December last year, they had dropped to their lowest level ever of 31.6 per cent, and there are now only three months to go. It is not going to improve, and Senator Herron knows it is not going to improve.

This is a great waste of taxpayers' public money. A subsidy is being paid to the private health insurance companies, supposedly to try to improve the level of participation in private health insurance to take the pressure off public hospitals. You are paying this huge subsidy to the private health funds, and yet the private health funds are still increasing their premiums—and they have increased them by in excess of 30 per cent since you came to office.

talk.start.para: —It went up 200 per cent under Labor.
—If you do not believe me because I happen to be a member of the Labor Party—a Labor senator—and you do not like what I say, listen to what Premier Richard Court says.
—Is a he a Liberal?
—He is a Liberal. What does he say about this private health insurance scheme? He says, `It is a dud deal.'
—A done deal!

—A dud deal. There is no misprint in this one. He said that it is a dud. The Australian Medical Association has also said that this is a dud scheme. It is not working and it has told you to go away and completely re-look at it. Why is this happening? It is happening because this government, notwithstanding its solemn promise at the last election that it would maintain Medicare, is still bent on undermining Medicare.

speech.para: When you went to the election in 1993, at least Dr Hewson told the truth. He went to the people with his GST and they threw that out. But you also went to the people at that time and said that you were going to undermine, dismantle and destroy Medicare, because you have never liked Medicare. The people rejected you in 1993 because they were not prepared to risk a government that would destroy Medicare.

At the last election in 1996, John Howard put his hand on his heart and said to the people, `Don't worry, you can be relaxed and comfortable, I will maintain Medicare,' because he recognised that the people of Australia wanted Medicare. But what has happened since you have come to office? You have ripped out over $1.2 billion from public health funding; you have abolished the dental scheme; you have ripped $800 million out of public hospitals; you have given a subsidy to the private health insurance industry and that scheme has not worked; and you have allowed them to put up increases of in excess of 30 per cent in their private health insurance premiums.

Then you come up to the states to negotiate a new Medicare agreement. You put $1.7 billion on the table and the states say, `You're a long, long, long way short.' The states have rejected it and they will continue to reject it. You have a unanimous position across all of the states, with one Labor state and five conservative states all telling this government that its proposals on the Medicare funding agreement are totally unacceptable.

The motion that has been moved today in general business is absolutely pertinent to the circumstances. It is clear that on the issue of health—and particularly in respect of renegotiating the Medicare agreement—this government and this minister, Dr Wooldridge, have totally failed. When they have to stoop to the extent of having Senator Knowles come in here and try to defend a totally indefensible position, then all I can say is that I rest my case. This government has been exposed for the falsity of its health policy, and the people will certainly give them the message at the next election.

talk.start.para: —I would like to remind the Senate of the motion that is before the chamber, given the 20 minutes of rubbish that we have just had to put up with which would have misled our listeners out there. The motion reads:

speech.para: That the Senate notes the Government's inability to work cooperatively with the States, as evidenced by its failure to negotiate agreements with the States . . .

It is ironic that that great Kremlinist, Senator Carr, should put this motion before the Senate, when the coalition government has spent its first two years in government fixing the result of Labor's 13 years of mismanagement and neglect. Labor could not do the numbers—the difference between zero and $10 billion is a great expanse. When they cannot tell a difference between a deficit and a credit budget, there is not much to be said for them.

Because of Labor, the state public health systems are stretched to the limit. In my own state of New South Wales, we have had to put up with Bob Carr's fraud on the waiting lists. When Labor was in federal government, they could not see the importance of putting a handbrake on the decline in the membership of private health insurance. They could not see that, for every person who is capable of helping himself or herself, governments are able to help more of those who cannot.

The former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was one of those people who might have been a member of the private health system. Senator Forshaw, you should have encouraged your Prime Minister Keating to join up in the private health system instead of using a system that could have been better used by those who could ill-afford it.

Labor let the private health system run down. When they came to government in 1983, nearly 65 per cent of Australians were covered by private health insurance but, by September 1995, this proportion had plummeted to 34.5 per cent. The proportion was falling by two per cent a year and they could not give a damn about it. This placed intolerable demands on the public health system and on the waiting lists.

In my own state of New South Wales, the waiting lists—as Senator Forshaw well knows—are bulging. One of the reasons they are bulging is that, when the Premier, Bob Carr, came to government, he said that he would resign if he had not halved the waiting lists after the first year in government. Well, the waiting lists have doubled, and the fraud that he has perpetrated is that he is still in power.

This is the government that will be known not as the weak Labor government but as the great U-turn government. Instead of a healthy hospital system, the Carr government has given us 10 per cent of the world's poker machines. These are the guys who did a U-turn with the tax on clubs, so they decided to best way to square off would be to allow more poker machines and put more misery into the lives of people out there in every man's-land with more poker machines and gambling. What a great statistic New South Wales now has: 10 per cent of all the poker machines in the world are in New South Wales! What a disgrace!

Going back to health, Dr Wooldridge, on the other hand, is making available $120 million this year to the states to help address the immediate issue of waiting lists—waiting lists that have doubled under Bob Carr. This is a genuine offer to the states and territories to help them reduce waiting lists and is additional assistance that will give them time. Health ministers from the states and territories will be meeting next week to discuss current health funding issues. Dr Wooldridge has worked with his state and territory colleagues to secure a national vision for our health system into the next century.

The Commonwealth's offer before the states is consistent with this vision and supports the reform process with both structure and dollars. In terms of structure, the offer would allow funding to flow between sectors and support improved integration of care and better patient outcomes—making more efficient use of the money in the system. In terms of dollars, the offer includes $½ billion to be spent on projects to improve the system, such as devising means to improve integration of care, particularly for the aged; improving the use of information technology so that patient data goes with the patient instead of following them around; and implementing alternate treatment modalities that do not require expensive, acute hospitalisation.

Kate Carnell has recently had that magnificent victory. Despite the perceived hard times in Canberra, Canberra decided not to bury itself and re-elected Kate Carnell, the longest-serving health minister. She has taken the lead and indicated her government's in principle agreement to the Commonwealth's proposal. Working together, we can turn back all those years of Labor's mismanagement and neglect.

Thirteen years of Labor failed the nursing home sector and older Australians, who deserved better. In the last four years of the Labor government, capital funding for nursing homes was reduced by 75 per cent. What a disgrace! They ignored their own report by Professor Bob Gregory on the urgent need for an upgrading of nursing homes. In fact, they did not have the guts to do anything about it. Their neglect particularly affected service delivery in rural and regional Australia.

Thirteen years of Labor failed our youth. Thirty per cent of school students have inadequate literacy and numeracy skills. We have seen the great debate occurring now, with Dr Kemp trying to bring that to order. There is the worry in some sectors of the education system that they might fail the test themselves. Apprenticeship opportunities under Labor also declined. As at 30 June last year, the number of apprentices and trainees in training was 175,354, which represents an increase of 11 per cent over the previous year—the highest ever achieved.

Through the Workplace Relations Act, the government has reformed apprenticeships and traineeships that meet the needs of business. The government's new apprenticeships initiative is reforming the delivery of workplace based training and making it a much more attractive option for business. Labor—the people who allegedly look after the workers—just let the apprenticeships scheme fall apart. Regulation is being simplified and the training and qualifications will be much more relevant to industry as well as being nationally recognised. Labor made it hard for employers to take on apprentices and trainees. Employees had to go to the states, the Commonwealth, training providers, and the list goes on. It was an endless paper chase. There was no real equivalent to the new apprenticeship centres under the old CES system.

Senator Carr, that great Kremlinist, the truth is the contrary of your motion. This government is moving ahead, working with the states to find solutions for the best possible delivery of service in areas of health, education and housing. I am sure, in view of this motion, that all the Liberal premiers around Australia will be pleased to know they have Senator Carr on side. Senator Carr has assumed a strong and healthy federalist position. He has abandoned his long-held position on Kremlin-like centralisation of all government services and now embraces the wisdom of federation as identified in the Australian constitution.

Unfortunately, Senator Carr's analysis of the current state of Commonwealth-state relationships is sadly distorted. Senator Carr is confusing the right for two parties to engage in a genuine negotiation process with failure. There is nothing wrong with a bit of argy-bargy. Senator Carr is confusing the Howard government with the Keating government—you know, the former Prime Minister who attempted to intimidate, harass and bully state governments on a regular basis, and who, when speaking against giving the states a fixed share of revenue, wooed the states with statements like the one he gave on 9 November 1995:
The Commonwealth is the shock absorber in the national economy. The Commonwealth budget is a shock absorber, the state budgets are not.
Real diplomacy! He had a wonderful negotiating capacity. Of course, that was well recognised at the last election.

I simply advise Senator Carr that he should take it easy—go and have a lie-down and a Bex or a valium. With respect to the Australian National Training Authority agreement, Senator Carr raised the status of ANTA agreements in estimates only last week. He was told by the minister that we now have a new ANTA agreement in principle. Queensland, Victoria and the ACT have signed up. Western Australia and South Australia have indicated their agreement subject to some queries being satisfied. The opposition would keep pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into TAFE and make an even bigger budget black hole when the national statutory authority, ANTA, has reported on the scope for efficiencies in the system. Under Labor, the opportunity to take advantage of those efficiencies was ignored.

Under the current ANTA agreement, the Commonwealth has provided additional funding to the states and territories every year up to, and including, 1997. Since 1992, Commonwealth funding has increased by 37 per cent in real terms, with the Commonwealth funding most of the total growth in vocational education and training over this period. Under the revised ANTA agreement, 1998 funding will be maintained in real terms up to the year 2000. There has been no such increase in state and territory funding. In addition to making the system work more efficiently, the federal government continues to support the sector as a premium option for young people leaving school and will provide a total of more than $1.3 billion for vocational education and training in 1997-98. This is an increase of $144 million, or 12 per cent, on funding provided in the last year of Labor.

The opposition neglected the potential of the apprenticeships scheme and allowed it to decline. They never addressed the needs of business. They were too busy with artists-in-residence and such glamorous outfits for the various unions who then, of course, had the opportunity to donate that money back to the Labor Party for the election.

As I mentioned earlier, at 30 June 1997 the number of apprentices and trainees in training was 175,354—11 per cent higher than the previous year. According to figures issued by the National Centre for Vocational Education Research, this is the highest ever achieved. Through the Workplace Relations Act, the government has reformed apprenticeships and traineeships. The new apprenticeships scheme, which addresses the real needs of industry and real jobs, is making a more attractive option for us all. Regulation is being simplified. Some $265 million has been allocated by the Commonwealth in 1997-98 for more than 100,000 new apprenticeships.

Labor made it so hard for employers to take on apprentices and trainees. There was no real equivalent to the new apprenticeship centres under the old CES scheme. From 1 May 1998, employees, apprentices and trainees will be able to obtain these services directly from the new apprenticeship centres. These centres will provide a streamlined service, cut through the red tape, respond to the needs of industry, save time and effort for employees, apprentices and trainees, provide ongoing assistance for the same people, and create growth in numbers and types of new apprenticeships. In conclusion, Kim Carr with his Kremlinist option today is nothing but a fraud and a waste of time in this chamber.

talk.start.para: —The disability services industry in Australia is in a state of confusion and chaos, and several non-government service providers are on the brink of collapse. After a series of paltry offers by the Commonwealth to the states, the Commonwealth-state disability agreement has still not been signed and disability service providers are now unable to plan for the future.

speech.para: There is evidence of secret negotiations between the Commonwealth and individual states. The presumption to be drawn from these hidden discussions is that the Commonwealth is plotting to disband the multilateral nature of the Commonwealth-state disability agreement in favour of bilateral agreements with individual states. If this were to occur, it would be hard to see how the lack of uniformity between the states is going to help people with disabilities in Australia. In fact, it will make the situation manifestly more untenable.

The Commonwealth would lose the capacity to require each of the states to pass legislation that is consistent with the Commonwealth's. The national peak body for disabled people and their families, the National Council on Intellectual Disability, is uncertain if this complementary legislation requirement exists in the recent Commonwealth offer. One can only speculate on the Commonwealth's real agenda if this complementary clause is not explicit. Perhaps the Howard government is contemplating changes to federal legislation in the area of disabilities.

One of the worst features of a bilateral agreement is that it throws the whole multilateral framework out the window and in the process puts in jeopardy over a decade of uniformity practised by various levels of government in this area. For example, under this potential system it would be quite possible for a person with a disability who receives funding support in the Australian Capital Territory not to receive the same level of support if he or she were to decide to relocate to Queensland. Why should these people be denied the right to freely move between the states as the rest of us do?

The Minister for Family Services, Warwick Smith, in his media release of 26 February 1997, fails to see any potential problems with bilateral agreements. He said, `People with disabilities will benefit more from bilateral agreements.' Maybe the minister could explain how a person who moves to another state fails to have his or her previous provisions transferred benefit. Perhaps an explanation is beyond this minister who has created chaos and confusion in the aged care and child-care communities and is clearly not up to explaining the benefit of this situation.

Bearing in mind the appalling provision of social services in Queensland under the present coalition government, it is safe to say that any person with a disability moving to Queensland would experience difficulty accessing services that may exist elsewhere in Australia under a bilateral agreement structure.

The Howard government's inaction over the Commonwealth-state disability agreement is a recipe for several tiers of care arrangements and a backward step for all stakeholders. It is clearly a sign of a government struggling to come to terms with its role as a government for all of Australia, not for the sectional and sometimes selfish agendas of cash-strapped states.

The Howard government recently requested the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare to report on the level of unmet need in disability services. The report estimated that the Howard government needed to inject $294 million into disability services immediately in order to address unmet need in this country. It found there were 13,500 people with disabilities not receiving their requirements in relation to accommodation services. It found there were 70,000 people with severe disabilities who require a meaningful day support program. It also found that 7,700 people with severe and profound disabilities are cared for by parents who are aged over 65 years.

The same government-commissioned report found that there were 30,000 people with disabilities who do not get the employment assistance that they require. As the shadow minister Jenny Macklin has commented in the other chamber, this figure is likely to get worse as a result of the forthcoming changes to employment service providers. It is highly unlikely that new large private providers will put the same commitment and tenacity into finding employment for people with disabilities—a role that was previously performed with distinction by many not-for-profit community organisations and smaller private operators—as they will for others.

Last week the National Council on Intellectual Disability labelled the Commonwealth's latest offer to the states as part of the Commonwealth-state disability agreement as miserly and inadequate. This organisation said it felt that the Prime Minister had let down all people with disabilities and that his government had failed to live up to the promises that were made to this sector of the community. The National Council on Intellectual Disability should not be entirely surprised by the actions of this Prime Minister and his government.

This is the same government which has ripped $174 million from the disability services budget over the past two years. It is also the same government which is planning to pilfer a further $25.3 million out of the disability sector by excluding 8,000 recipients of the child disability allowance by changing the definition of who is considered to have a disability. This is the same mob who abolished the Disability Discrimination Commissioner and have taken this sector back to the dark period prior to the early 1980s, before the groundbreaking legislative reforms of the previous Labor government.

This is a government whose latest offer starts at $8 million in the first year and rises to $60 million in the fifth year contrasting with its own commissioned report by the AIHW which estimates that there is $294 million in unmet need in the first year alone. Clearly, this is a government which not only has no commitment to the disability services sector due to its ideological predilections against funding the social services, but also is without compassion and understanding for the disadvantaged in our community.

My fear is that, if this Commonwealth-state disability agreement is not signed, my own state of Queensland, which has an appalling record on funding disability services, will revert to the bad days before the Commonwealth started to assert some authority in this area. I fear for the consequences this will have for people with disabilities, for their families and for the many hundreds of non-government organisations that provide support to people with disabilities.

I recently visited a respite centre in Rockhampton. The organisation responsible for its operation were despairing about the huge task they had in catering for families from the Central Queensland coast stretching west to the Northern Territory border. These people are permanently on call to provide respite support for this vast region where there is a desperate need for another such facility. Despite the strain and the effort to continue operating, they have a first-class facility which is testimony to their unfailing enthusiasm and commitment.

It is an unfortunate fact that in Queensland the number of days available to families already accessing respite has been reduced by 70 per cent over the past few years. In 1996-97 in excess of $40 million worth of funding applications were received by the Queensland Department of Families, Youth and Community Care from non-government service providers on behalf of people with disabilities. Amazingly, only $1.7 million was made available to these organisations. This poor result is all the more staggering when you consider that many of these providers had their hopes raised by the coalition during the 1995 state election.

Mr Borbidge and Mrs Sheldon promised they would provide an additional $34 million per year over three years to assist Queenslanders with a disability. But the big promise never eventuated and Mrs Sheldon's second budget allocated only an additional $1.9 million over three years to address the existing unmet needs of the disability sector. This resulted in there being no funding round this year for the first time since the implementation of the Commonwealth-state disability agreement and many priority applications have been put on 40-year waiting lists, which is absolutely disgraceful.

At the same time the Queensland Treasurer, Mrs Sheldon, could find the money to pay off a $200 million toll road which just happened to pass through her electorate. This, of course, was an election promise. I might add there is a toll road in the electorate in which I live, but our toll road was not paid for by the state government. We still have to pay the toll. Maybe that is because it is a Labor electorate. The government could also locate another $14.5 million to fund a politically motivated and biased inquiry which attempted to close down the Criminal Justice Commission. Is it any wonder I have concerns about the priorities of the Queensland coalition government to do the right thing by the disability sector?

What needs to be realised is that it is the rural and regional areas of Queensland—the same areas which coalition governments at the state and federal levels claim so ably to represent—that are the communities hardest hit by the lack of a multilateral disability agreement. There is an endless list of unmet demand services in regional Queensland. The Endeavour Foundation in Toowoomba has 58 people on an accommodation waiting list over the next three years. The Queensland Deaf Society has 120 people on waiting lists. In my home town of Ipswich there are 28 adults and children in inadequate respite arrangements and a further 96 people have unmet therapy needs.

In closing, I urge the Howard government to reconsider its offer to the states in relation to the Commonwealth-state disability agreement. It can only be through a multilateral framework that governments can be in a position to provide to this sector of the community fair and equitable care, which it rightly deserves. I support this motion.

talk.start.para: —Whatever Senator Carr hopes to achieve with this ridiculous motion is very similar to one he put on the books last September which was debated in this place at that time. Again on the day of the debate Senator Carr's motion was not supported by his own participation or rhetoric. On that occasion he spoke for about 15 seconds and today he has allowed others from the Labor Party to stand ahead of him in the queue. He has not even spoken on his motion today, which just goes to show how poor the information on it is.

speech.para: What is he seeking to achieve? Can we imagine him updating his earlier paranoia on some sort of a thesis that is based on bad blood that he thinks exists between the Commonwealth and the states? His motion refers to `the inability to work cooperatively with the states'. I am going to comment very particularly on that aspect of the motion that refers to the Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

I am interested to know what constituency Senator Carr sought to represent on this occasion. Is he going to photocopy his Hansard and distribute it around to the premiers and the chief ministers with a covering note saying, `Look what a good job I did representing your interests in federal parliament'? I hardly think they will buy that, because the states and territories would soon write back—including the Labor Party Premier from New South Wales, Bob Carr—saying, `You don't represent our interests.'

What about the claims about the Commonwealth-state housing agreement? This motion is very clearly out of step with the views of the states and Senator Carr's own federal party colleagues. The government successfully negotiated with the states and the territories a Commonwealth-state housing agreement which came into force on 1 July 1996 and has a year and three months until it expires on 30 June 1999. In addition, all state and territory governments accepted the offer of the Prime Minister in May 1997 of funding certainty for the final two years of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

In relation to service delivery, the government has successfully negotiated and agreed strategic plans with the states and territories for the provision of housing assistance which outline agreed targets and strategies. Negotiations are shortly to commence on the targets for 1998-99, the final year. During the life of the agreement, the government has worked collaboratively with the states to produce a more efficient and effective public housing system.

At the housing ministers' meeting in June last year, a range of proposals in regard to pricing, tenure arrangements, eligibility and wait list management were discussed. As a result, significant reform is now under way in the states which will direct assistance to those in greatest need. Let me quote from the communique issued at the housing ministers' conference in Perth on 6 June 1997, which included the participation of Labor housing ministers. The final sentence of that communique reads:
All ministers agreed that the reform agenda is progressing steadily and that this is the right approach to ensure that good outcomes are achieved.

The government is keen to see the future arrangements evolve in the current context of cooperation, and housing officials are meeting—there is one meeting here in Canberra next Thursday—to provide the opportunity for informal discussions about the Commonwealth's objectives for housing funding after the expiry of the current agreement. These matters will then be further discussed at the housing ministers' meeting to take place on 27 March, and I do not think they will be shrouded with the sort of pessimism that Senator Carr would have us believe.

What about the goodwill that exists between the Commonwealth and the states? Is Labor just trying to drive a bitter wedge between the two? There are good working relationships between the states and we need to look at them very carefully. But it is also important that we look carefully at a Senate committee report on housing assistance which, I would point out, Labor Senators Bishop, Forshaw, Neal and O'Brien signed off and approved recently. It was the report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee of December 1997, entitled Report on Housing Assistance. As I said, a majority Labor membership—Senators Bishop, Forshaw, Neal and O'Brien—signed it off, and what did they sign to? Let me give some quotes. Chapter 3.1 said:
The 1996 CSHA represents a considerable change on earlier agreements—
From 3.2:
The 1996 Agreement removed many of the restrictions on the States—
From 3.3:
The aim of the changes in the 1996 CSHA was to allow the Commonwealth to monitor outcomes and agree on strategic directions while giving the States maximum freedom over provision of assistance.
From 3.4:
The 1996 CSHA also requires each State and the Commonwealth to agree on a strategic plan for housing assistance.
From 3.14:
There was support from a number of the submissions for the broad framework of the 1996 CSHA—
From 3.16:

Queensland, Western Australia, and the Northern Territory all expressed, in their submissions the view that Commonwealth involvement in the provision of housing should be to reduced to the minimum possible.
From 3.17:
They all argued that CSHA funding should move towards an outcome-based funding model—
From 3.18, very importantly:
The New South Wales Department of Urban Affairs and Planning expressed general support for the changes introduced in the 1996 Agreement.
And what about the recommendation of this important issue relating to Commonwealth-state housing? Recommendation 5 states:

The Committee recommends that on its expiration on 30 June 1999, the 1996 Commonwealth State Housing Agreement be replaced by a new Agreement which retains the specification of performance and the strategic planning processes which are in the existing Agreement measures and addresses the issue of State accountability.
A majority of Labor senators signed that report in just December of last year and are now totally out of step with this motion that, for some perverse and political reason, Senator Carr has moved.

There were over 400 submissions to that inquiry from various advocacy groups, state and territory governments, the Commonwealth and the general public, and they developed proposals that were educated and informed, unlike the debate we have heard here today. So Senator Carr should take a leaf out of the book of his peers. He should acknowledge the good work of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement for what it is. There is really no merit in trying to do what he is doing today with this motion. He is playing the politics of the issue, rather than offering some sort of positive contribution like Senators Bishop, Forshaw, Neal and O'Brien did back in December.

We all know the environment in which the Commonwealth-state housing agreement is negotiated. It is always a difficult one. Each party has its own individual, very different expectations. The demands and the circumstances are certainly different in each state. From this environment, the Commonwealth must steer a common course.

If we look very carefully at the particular motion that we are being asked to consider today, we have to ask the reasons for it. What is the motivation behind it? Why did Senator Carr put up such a motion in which he sought to drive wedges between the Commonwealth and the states on issues where there is no major disparity? There are consistent and very good motives.

In the community at the moment, the fact that there are so many Liberal, National and Country Liberal Party governments at the federal and state level is very important and it runs contrary to the motion that is currently before us and how it has been presented. This motion should, of course, be totally rejected. There is no way that we would want to see any success for this particular motion. It certainly does not endorse the action of the federal government.
Debate interrupted.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Hill, I wish to inform the Senate that, following the retirement of the Right Hon. Ian Sinclair as chairman, the members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade have met and elected Senator David MacGibbon as the new chairman. I am sure all honourable senators will join me in congratulating Senator MacGibbon and wishing him well in this important position.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 4 March, on motion by Senator Newman:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Yesterday the Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Fischer, tabled his second outcomes and objectives statement for the trade portfolio. I have described this statement as a bland and visionless document. I will demonstrate why that is so in a moment.

speech.para: But, first of all, can I say in reply to Mr Fischer's statement yesterday, the leader of the Labor Party in the House of Representatives, Kim Beazley, did say that he regarded Mr Fischer as being at least one of the people on the government's side who was trying his best to open markets for Australia and congratulated Mr Fischer for the work that he was doing. I would like to join with the Leader of the Opposition on those personal remarks about Mr Fischer.

The problem for this statement, however, is that, for the first time, it is an admission by the government that the Asian currency crisis will affect the level of economic activity in Australia. Page 25 of the statement says:

Lower export earnings will affect domestic activity through their impact on sectoral incomes (eg, lower corporate profitability and higher input costs). This will flow on to domestic spending. The consequent slowing in output growth will affect employment, though not until later in 1998-99, given the lags between output variations and employment. Any reduction in employment growth will adversely affect household incomes. In addition, both the direct impact of developments in Asia and the associated impact on sectoral incomes could affect business and consumer confidence, though these effects can be difficult to quantify.

So there we have the first official statement by the government about the types of effects the crisis will provoke in this economy. We do not have any detail about the timing except that it will be 1998-99. We have no detail about the depth of those effects on corporate profitability, on economic growth in the nation and on household incomes and the contraction that this report foreshadows will occur there, making life more difficult for Australian families. We do not have any figures from the government about how many jobless will be created and added to the long queue of unemployed in this nation because of its inability to deal with the impact of this crisis.

We have asked the government to make that information available. They have not. It is important that they do move quickly in this area. We know from figures tabled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics just this week that, over the last 12 months, the current account deficit in this nation blew out by 23 per cent—23 per cent in the current account deficit in 12 months. We know from the same figures that the foreign debt this nation holds now is a record. We hold $222 billion in foreign debt, the highest level of foreign debt this nation has ever had.

We recall, though, that during the last election campaign the government ran the debt truck up hill and down dale and saw it break down in promising to the Australian community that they would rein in foreign debt. It is now at a record level. It has never been as high, and the forecasts are that it is expected to balloon further.

We know as well from the national account figures published yesterday that economic growth has undershot the forecasts that were anticipated. Already, before the Asian currency crisis hits this economy, the growth levels for Australia are much lower than anticipated, and the levels of economic growth for the nation for the two years thus far of Liberal government are below the average for the entire 13 years of Labor government.

So we have a situation in which the promise of growth, employment, higher profitability and the reining-in of foreign debt is not being kept by the government. That is why it is important that we get on the record what the impact of the Asian currency crisis will be so that Australia can form in its mind the right policies and apply an action, the appropriate measures, for dealing with the impact of that crisis. While this report admits it, it does not give the detail. It is important that the government answers those questions and does so swiftly.

Let me turn to some of the things in this report that I have criticisms of. In the area of trade promotion, this report does not adequately report to the people of Australia, as the minister promised it would when he said that he would impartially and fairly present the facts. This report does not refer to the fact that the government has not done a number of things, which has undermined trade promotion in Australia.

Last year we saw the Howard government decide that it would not fund Australia's presence at the year 2000 World Trade Expo in Hanover, although that is the Olympic Games of world trade promotion. In the end it gave in. Sir Llew Edwards, who is promoting the Gold Coast for the venue for the year 2002, managed at last to persuade the government that, if we are to encourage Australian exporters to get into the international marketplace and display their wares, they should at least be at the premier world event and that Australia should be an active bidder to attract that event to Australia.

We saw as well just last month that Australia did not participate in Milia 1998, the multimedia expo held in France on 7 February. Over 50 countries were represented at the expo. Over 10,000 potential buyers did attend, and Australia was not present in any official way. We did not have a stand. This is in the area of IT—information technology.

It is not as though we are running a surplus in information technology exports. The deficit in IT&T for Australia currently stands at around $4 billion, and it is predicted to blow out to a level of $20 billion by the year 2000. This is the biggest industry for the future. Australia chose, however, not to be in the biggest event in which we could display our wares to the world marketplace and pick up important custom for our struggling IT&T sector in Australia. That is not referred to in the report either.

One of the other things that is not referred to in the report is the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference. This was a stunning success. In 1995, the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference succeed ed by independent audit in attracting $1.04 billion in new investment for Australia and $2.02 billion in new export potential. In 1996, it succeeded by independent audit in attracting $592 million in new investment and $3.4 billion in new export potential. Why would you not hold that event, given that we know that we are losing markets in Asia because of the downturn in those economies? Why would you not strive to attract more industry to Australia and more investment and export opportunities for Australian companies?

The National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference was cut for budgetary reasons. We spent $1.3 million on it to attract $3.4 billion in exports, but the government made it as a budgetary cut and handed it over to the private sector. There will be an International Herald Tribune event run next month. We know from internally leaked documents from the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism that that event is proposing to charge the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism $125,000 for a speaking spot at that conference and participants up to $900 to attend. So much for the promotion of Australia. The report does not refer to that. These are opportunities forgone and chances to build our national income and trade profile.

In the area of exporter support the government in its slash and burn budget of 1996-97 cut the export market development grants back quite dramatically. It topped them up a little in its industry statement before Christmas, but still this nation will lose up to about $30 billion because of the amount of support cut out of industry in promoting Australian small business overseas. The export market development grants are the premier way in which that is done. These grants have been independently refereed by respected econometricians to see what the earning rate is. For every public dollar put on the barrel head, how many dollars do we win in the private sector in new markets? We know that this is the single most effective way of attracting small business into the international marketplace.

It is vitally important they be there to defend the markets that are going down on them in Asia. It is vitally important that they be there to find new prospects. It is vitally important that they travel to places like South Africa, India, Russia, the Czech Republics, Latin America, Mexico and others where they need to find more markets. Is the money there to support them? No, the scheme is capped so that they cannot use that chance to win access.

There is a range of other matters that could be properly canvassed. The big gap is the vision for the future. Where do we want to take this nation in trade? The routine things are talked about. The big challenges are ignored. There is a lot more that could be done. It is a poor report in that respect. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —by leave—I want to make a few comments regarding the statements made by Senator Cook in relation to the Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement tabled yesterday by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, Tim Fischer. We have already acknowledged, Senator Cook, that there will be an impact from the Asian currency correction. Offsetting that currency correction is strong growth in our domestic economy, with private investment and consumption at healthy levels.

speech.para: The reason for that is that we have corrected the $10½ billion hole in the budget that you gave us when we came into government. Had we not corrected that we would have actually been more vulnerable than we are now to the Asian currency crisis. If we had not tackled that deficit our exporters would not have the secure base now in which to operate. If we had not restored the economic fundamentals, our exporters would not have been as competitive as they are—a fact that exporters in Australia acknowledge.

It is not just on the domestic front that the government has been active and successful in improving Australia's trade effort. Indeed, 1996-97 was a record year for the export of Australian goods and services with exports totalling some $105 billion—an increase of 6.2 per cent on the previous year. It was not 2.5 per cent as stated by you, Senator Cook, or the Leader of the Opposition in the last few days.

The reason the government has been so successful in leading Australia to record export success is that it has actively pursued trade strategies at the bilateral, regional and multilateral levels. Unlike your government, Senator Cook, this government has aggressively pursued bilateral trade strategies which have opened up new markets for Australian exports of rice, sugar, citrus and financial services. It is a fact that we have done it. It is on the record. The market development task force established by this government will continue to be a key element of our bilateral strategy in 1998.

On a regional level, Australia will continue to advocate economic reform and open trade policies which will be even more important in light of the economic developments in Asia. The government will continue to play a leading role in APEC in pushing hard to accelerate the early liberalisation of the 15 priority sectors in which we have vital trade interests. The government has also made substantial progress on the multilateral front. Next month, Australia will be hosting a major meeting of the Cairns group in Sydney to advance multilateral agricultural reforms and build momentum for a new comprehensive round of trade negotiations by the year 2000.

Contrary to your comments, Senator Cook, and the statements that you have made, the government and its agents have acted quickly and effectively to support Australian exports to the region. I will remind you of these measures, because you know we have done them; you know in your heart of hearts that we have done the right thing. We have had involvement in the IMF's support packages for Korea, Thailand and Indonesia. We did that very quickly. We are providing up to $300 million in short-term credit insurance for exporters to Korea and similar assistance on a case by case basis for Indonesia.

We are tightening the anti-dumping laws—something that you did not do anything about. We are doing something about labelling products so that the Australian people can buy, and know that they are buying, Australian made products. We are continuing to push for further trade and investment liberalisation to open up new markets for Australian exporters. Through Austrade's branch of trade exporting facilities, we have helped Australian firms to hold their positions in the affected markets and increase penetration of new markets outside the region. We have established an Austrade Asia help line for Australian exporters. Just for your benefit, and for the benefit of any listeners, that phone number is 1300 368 225. That was done quickly, and it helps.

We have increased trade with Iran by about 71 per cent; with Egypt by 51 per cent; with South Africa by 31 per cent; and with Mexico by 24 per cent. They are not bad figures when you think about it; not bad figures at all. You said also in one of your media releases—and I think you might have said it in question time today—that we should be conducting seminars for Australian businesses to help them to understand the impact of the developments in Asia. That is exactly what the government is doing. We are holding Austrade seminars on the Asian situation in all major capitals. We are having trade round tables for exporters from rural and regional areas all around Australia. They have been very fruitful and very fulfilling, having regard to the feedback we have had from exporters on how they have seen the situation.

Another mistake that you made in your assertions here today concerned the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference. You said that it does not exist. It does still exist. It has been renamed as an Australian summit. So it does continue to exist.

talk.start.para: —It doesn't.

—I am afraid it does, Senator. I take you up again on another area where I thought that you would have given a little more thought to things. You said on 3 March, in your criteria for the second statement, that it must satisfy certain credentials to be credible. I am pleased to say that the statement meets the criteria for your standards of credibility. Look at your media release of 3 March and see what this statement says—it satisfies everything you asked for.

speech.para: In a press release on 4 March, Senator Cook, you said that the government should have reformed the EMDG scheme. You made mention of it again tonight. You said it should benefit small and first-time exporters. You know—you took part in putting through the legislation—that that is exactly what we have succeeded in doing. We have brought down the level of the criteria to get into the scheme to $20,000 instead of the higher level which you had implemented. That has been helpful. If you had read page 7 of the transcript of Mr Fischer's statement which was tabled yesterday, you would have realised that that was exactly what the government did when it amended the EMDG Act last year.

This government has been creating an environment for Australian exporters to be winners, not trying to pick winners, as you always tried to do. It is only through putting in place a competitive domestic economic framework that Australian exporters will be competitive and our exports will grow. We have low interest rates, low inflation and an economic climate which allows labour market reform and reform of the waterfront to occur. This means we can compete with others in the world who are competing against us.

If you read the Trade Outcomes and Objectives Statement put out yesterday by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, I think you will find that the right things are being done for the trading environment in Australia and for our exporters.

talk.start.para: —The President has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate seeking a variation to the membership of a committee.

interjection.para: That Senator Neal be discharged from the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties and Senator Reynolds be appointed to the committee.

talk.start.para: —There are 219 government documents listed for consideration on today's Notice Paper . There is a time limit that takes us to 7 p.m. for their consideration. To expedite consideration of the documents, I propose, with the concurrence of honourable senators, to call the documents in groups of 10. Documents called in each group to which no senator rises will be taken to be discharged from the Notice Paper. Documents not called on today will remain on the Notice Paper .

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Science and Tourism

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —With regard to the annual report of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, I note that, because of the way in which the estimates were conducted last week and, indeed, this week, very little of that department's business was able to be dealt with. One of the matters which took up the time of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee during the estimates hearings was the evidence of Mr Gillespie, who is an officer of the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business.

speech.para: As a result of that evidence, I have caused a letter to be sent to the Clerk and he has responded. In that letter I drew the attention of the Clerk to certain responses that were given to questions by Mr Gillespie and the Clerk has recommended a certain course of action. I have forwarded the correspondence to the secretary of the committee with a view to the committee reconvening, subject of course to its own decision, to allow matters of conflict between evidence previously given by Mr Gillespie and evidence which was given last week to be further tested. I understand I have agreement and I now seek leave to table the correspondence which I sent to the Clerk on 4 March and his response on the same day.
Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 21 and 23 October 1997, on motions by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the documents.

talk.start.para: —The reports by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, namely Report for 1996-97 on the operation and effect of the Native Title Act and Report for 1996-97 , were both signed off by Michael Dodson. It is a sad thing that he is no longer the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. Indeed, it is a sad thing that his brother Patrick Dodson has also lost the position that he held at the time that these documents were prepared. The Dodson brothers have great genes within their bodies. They are both outstanding Australians. I want to talk about Michael Dodson and explain why it is sad for Australia that he is no longer in the position he held at the time of signing off these documents.

speech.para: I remember at the bar there was a great advocate, Ted Laurie, who was a person with an incisive intellect and a great understanding of human nature. He knew the minds and souls of people and knew them well. In addition, as he told me one day, he had the ability to cry. What he meant by that was, not only did he have great learning, a great mind, a great intellect and insight but also he had the ability to feel compassion and empathy and had a deep sense of wanting to help others. He had a real hunger for justice, if I can use the language of the beatitudes.

Michael Dodson is a man like Ted Laurie was. He knew Ted Laurie. Michael was at the Victorian bar when I was there and when Ted Laurie was there, and he would understand the reference.
