Michael Dodson is a man who has connections with Victoria. He went to school there, played football there and was at the bar there. On this occasion, on the basis of the two reports which he signed off and have come before the Senate tonight, I want to acknowledge him and his great contribution to Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 21 October 1997, on motion by Senator Hogg:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —The 1996-97 report of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal is certainly not a bagatelle of complaints. If one looks at the report, it really draws to one's attention the problems that we are going to be confronted with now that there are jurisdictional problems with the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. In chapter 4, it highlights that there were 1,383 written complaints and 10,447 telephone inquiries received by the tribunal. That is a significant number. It goes on to point out that there were 694 written complaints, which represents 42.5 per cent more than the 487 complaints received in the previous year. We have a serious issue now because of the jurisdictional problems that we have with the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal.

speech.para: One certainly should not whiffle at the seriousness of the issue that is before us. If one looks at the nature of the complaints that appear throughout this report, one sees the necessity to protect the rights of people in respect of the superannuation that many of them look forward to in either retirement or as part of a total and permanent disablement claim. There is also a need to protect rights in respect of a death claim. It is interesting that at page 37 the report notes that, of the complaints received by the tribunal, 24 per cent were in respect of death claims and 27 per cent were in respect of disability. That is by far and away the majority of claims that were received. More importantly, one needs to look at the analysis on page 39 where it is drawn to our attention that clearly employer sponsored funds are far more likely to be complained about to the tribunal than are any other types of funds.

If the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal is now, in effect, hitting the wall, where are the people going to register their complaints? It is drawn to our attention in the report that complaints are six times more likely against employer sponsored funds than the next highest category of funds, which is industry funds. Clearly, this is an opportunity for people to have their superannuation rights protected by being able to lodge their complaints with the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. Some of the complaints that are outlined—particularly with the likes of TPD time limit complaints, time limits and valid lodgment of claims complaints—provide excellent examples of real protection being given to those people who are at odds with either the superannuation fund or the life manager, who may well be in charge of the fund.

This should not be treated in a marshmallow fashion by the government; it should be addressed in a serious way. The complaints mechanism is very important indeed for the future protection of people and their life savings in the superannuation area. I commend the report to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —Like my colleague, Senator Hogg, I wish to make a few comments about the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. This is an important document, because it deals with an area of financial supervision that affects almost every Australian.

speech.para: The report on page 7 firstly makes reference to a report of this Senate in June 1992, the first report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, Safeguarding super. It refers to the demographic, social and economic forces that have given superannuation greater prominence over recent times. It then goes on to note the passing of the superannuation guarantee legislation in July 1992.

I think most senators, most members of the other place and certainly most Australians are aware that superannuation in this country is compulsory for all employees. When I last looked, two weeks ago at a meeting of the superannuation committee, there were some 16.8 million superannuation accounts in this country. The amount of money in superannuation is gradually increasing. Last time I looked, about this time last year, there was an average amount of approximately $36,000 or $37,000 in a superannuation account.

One important feature of modern superannuation, as established by the Labor government, is that most funds now provide for insurance cover in the event of death or disability. That is a very important aspect. With the advent of the superannuation guarantee, now six per cent of ordinary time earnings and increasing to nine per cent by 2001-02, superannuation will form—within 20 or 30 years, I suspect—a very significant financial asset, which will be greater than the family home in the case of many Australians. So it is therefore necessary to have a strong effective complaints resolution mechanism.

The tribunal which was established by the Labor government and commenced on 1 July 1994 does that. It cannot deal with all disputes. As my colleague Senator Hogg has referred to them earlier, I will not go into the statistics. But I will draw the Senate's attention to the nature of complaints that can be dealt with by the tribunal: disclosure, fees, death and disability, surplus distribution payments and matters relating to administration, statement area, trustee misrepresentation and malpractice. I think it is fair to say that this is the major disputes tribunal dealing with issues relating to superannuation.

One of the reasons that the then Labor government set up the tribunal was to provide a cost-free and user-friendly forum to persons who have complaints about decisions on the conduct of trustees, insurers, RSA providers and superannuation providers.

As I said earlier, the amount of money in superannuation accounts is not a mere bagatelle. The amount of money is increasing slowly and steadily, due to the very strong, proactive and visionary outlook of the Labor government in the passing of SG legislation.

Senator Hogg has also referred to the recent Federal Court decision with respect to the legal ability of the tribunal to deal with complaints. Regrettably, the teeth have been taken away from the tribunal. Some would say, `It is now a mere lemon.' Perhaps `marshmallow' is a more apt description. We should not treat that Federal Court decision as a whiffle to glow lightly in the dark. It is a very significant Federal Court decision, which has regrettably left many Australians wondering who is going to determine the very important issue of disputes with respect to superannuation. We can look forward to more disputes. The government's announced so-called `choice' I refer to as deregulation of the superannuation industry. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Science and Tourism

talk.start.para: —by leave—I rise to speak on the report of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism for 1996-97.
—Senator Conroy, Senator O'Brien has already spoken to this document and did not seek leave to continue his remarks later. If you wish to speak on it, you will need leave to do so.

—This document shows the abdication of the government from the tourism and industry sectors. The figures on page 43 show the reduction in staffing and appropriations for tourism. It used to be a whole department. One of the first decisions this government took was to collapse the department. The government has decided that the economy is fine. They flattened it when they first came to power. They ripped billions out of it, claiming that there was a problem. That saw growth drop from 3½ per cent to 2½ per cent and unemployment go up. They were complacent this year, and this document shows it.

speech.para: We have got an economy that is like a marshmallow. It is soft. The growth is not there. The government is pretending, even yesterday, that everything is still on track. Their strategy has been to have the economy, on their claims, `steaming into 1998'. This economy is barely whiffling along. It has dropped from 1.7 per cent in June to 0.5 per cent in this quarter. That means that what they were hoping to do—get this economy over the hump of the Asian crisis—will fail. We have got growth, but barely a bagatelle. We see a government that has lost the plot.

This document shows that the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism needs more funds and an industry strategy. If we do not take up the challenge in the coming budget and restore the cuts which are shown in this document, unemployment numbers will go up further. As the former Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs said, `If we don't get unemployment down, we deserve to lose.' That will be the judgment of the Australian people.

This document is an indictment on a complacent government that is not interested in job growth and not interested in promoting the tourism industry. You just have to talk to people in the tourism industry to know this—they are screaming. There was a story recently from your area, Senator O'Chee. A whole refit of windows in one of the resorts was cancelled. The company that was scheduled to do the refit of the windows has laid off its glaziers as a direct result of the Asian crisis.

talk.start.para: —But the government is not responsible for that, Senator.
—No, but the government is irresponsible if it does not do something, Senator O'Chee.
—What does it have to do—employ the glaziers?
—No, you are supposed to recognise the problem, have an industry strategy, talk to the tourism industry and get together.

speech.para: Senator O'Chee interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is not enough—that is my point.
—Where are you going to get the money from?
—Taxing family trusts would be a good way to start.
—And death duties. Where are you going to find the money to balance the budget?

—If you are worried about where the money is coming from, let us start with negative gearing. Let us start with taxing trusts if that is where you are saying we are going to get the money from. The tax office has said there is plenty of money out there.
—Trusts are taxed now.
—I suppose you are going to say part 4A fixes the tax avoiders too—chance would be a fine thing. (Time expired)
—We are dealing with document nos 1 to 10. Senator Quirke, I will be interested to hear whether you make `marshmallow', `bagatelle' and `whiffle' relevant to your remarks.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 October, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I do not know why you raised the point of whether I can make `marshmallow', `bagatelle' or `whiffle' relevant or not. In your first sentence you fixed one of the main problems I have had since coming out of a committee meeting some time ago—in fact, I was wondering how I was going to do this. So I want to thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. You have solved one of the fundamental problems of the age.

speech.para: My remarks tonight are to do with the National Nuclear Safety Bureau's 38th quarterly report for the period 1 January to 31 March 1997. This well run organisation has reported that all problems are under their control, including the chances of a nuclear discharge either from ANSTO's facility at Lucas Heights, other smaller stockpiles of nuclear material or a nuclear powered ship. If there was any discharge at all, it was from the ANSTO facility, but the bureau tells us that the monitoring that they did during that period indicates it was well below those levels required under the various regulations under which that organisation operates.

It is very important that these things be monitored properly. It was only a whiffle in Eastern Europe in 1986 when there was that terrible problem because a Soviet reactor at Chernobyl effectively melted down one of the main containments. It has got to be said that it is only the marshmallow apologists for nuclear accidents who would get up and say that that was not a major thing.

I was very concerned about Chernobyl when it happened. As the Senate knows, I have a very balanced approach to nuclear energy. I cop it every time somebody brings up the question. I have very strong views about what happened in the former Soviet Union. It has to be said that this was not a bagatelle or a trifle. Some people said that what happened at Chernobyl was a bagatelle or a trifle. That is not so.

I am please to report that we have not had a marshmallow, bagatelle or a whiffle in this report that could be said to concern us at all, at least for the first three months of last year. I am not sure that any nuclear propelled ships actually came to Australia during that period—I cannot remember any. I quite often get invited to go out on them, as I am that sort of person who is interested in that level of technology.

I am very happy when the invitation is extended to visit a ship, and I know that lots of other senators have been on nuclear powered ships. Even though they come in here and say something different, they obviously do not mind the possibility of glowing in the dark if things go wrong. At the end of the day, having a marshmallow, bagatelle or a whiffle in respect of glowing in the dark is something that I would be very concerned about. I believe that this report is a very worthwhile document. I commend it to senators, and I thank you again, Mr Acting President, for giving me the opportunity to say `marshmallow', `bagatelle' and `whiffle'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 21 October 1997.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I was prompted to speak to the Australian Law Reform Commission report by the address given earlier by Senator Hogg, who spoke on the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. His speech prompted me to speak to this report because there is forever a need in any society for the law that operates in that society to be kept under supervision by appropriate bodies, to be monitored and, when there is need for change, for change to be made. Clearly, there is a problem in the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal area which ought to be looked at.

For years, the Australian Law Reform Commission has performed a great task in looking at issues in Australia where there is need for reform or alterations in the law for the betterment of everybody in society. I acknowledge the part that the commission plays in the all-important task of law reform. I wish it the best and hope that it has at least satisfactory funds in the future to operate as it should.

I was, as I said, impressed by what Senator Hogg had to say, and also with what was said by Senator Sherry, who had so much to do with the successful establishment of superannuation in Australia. When superannuation was being looked at to make it effective for everybody within the community, Senator Sherry played an important part in getting that movement going. Another Tasmanian on the other side, Senator Watson, has also done great work in that area, but Senator Sherry should certainly be praised. I make those remarks in the context of the Australian Law Reform Commission, and I wish it well in its future work.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 21 October 1997.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I address my remarks to the National Museum of Australia report 1996-97. This is a very important report about a very important building which will hopefully be constructed in the not too distant future. The report starts out with the letter of the chairman, Mr J.G. Service, who sets out the process for the construction of the museum, pointing to the site selection and the commitment of the now government to its construction.

Mr Service, who is the chairman of what is known as the Construction and Coordination Committee, has often been described as a marshmallow, but I would certainly reject that. He has a real task ahead of him to get this job done. He appeared before the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works and said that he is totally committed to doing that. That remains to be seen.

Construction of the National Museum of Australia is very important; so much so that the Public Works Committee, which is a joint standing committee of this parliament, has already had three days of hearings on this matter. It has found that the department responsible, the Department of Communications and the Arts, has, in what can only be described as monumental terms, made a complete mess of the process of getting the National Museum constructed. The government initially committed $133 million, which is not an amount that could be described as a bagatelle; these are huge dollars. But it was not long after that that it was increased by a further $18 million, and the opposition asked what the $18 million was for.

I have to go back a couple of steps to address some things set up by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, who, along with the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, announced that they would have an international design competition for the National Museum. However, they did not conduct the international design competition in accordance with international design competition rules. The coalition government made up its own rules, but it still announced that it was an international competition.

What else has gone wrong with this process? As recently as this morning, I received yet another design as part of the Public Works Committee information. All of the competitors in the design competition were given a brief which contained a minimum area of around 16,000 square metres of floor space to house all the icons, goods and chattels that we would want to house for the people of Australia in our National Museum.

When the National Museum is built, it will be, I hope, a tremendous building and one that will serve as a very important asset for Canberra. Building it in Canberra is the right thing to do. From the opposition point of view, we want to ensure that, when the museum is built, it will be a building that Australians will be able to be proud of, because that is important. It really should not come down to the question of whether it costs $133 million or $150 million; it really should come down to getting a building in place that can function as Australia's National Museum for the next 50 years.

Mr Service along with his committee members from the Department of Communications and the Arts seem to have made a right royal mess of this. Indeed, as late as December last year, they had to head off to the United States to talk to people about exhibit space because they did not really know about it. I have to say that this is no whiffle of a process. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Communications and the Arts

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 21 October 1997.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

This 1996-97 annual report of the Department of Communications and the Arts covers a range of issues. One of particular interest to me is the government's policy relating to the removal of the parallel importation restrictions. Today I asked the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, a question on reversing the onus of proof. The minister, as I recall, stood up and said, `I don't really know what you mean.'

But the minister seemed to know plenty about it as he has gone around the country speaking on radio interviews and saying that the government will reverse the onus of proof. He had plenty to say about it. So one would assume that he would know what the reversal of the onus of proof actually means. To the layman I suppose—for those less experienced than Judge Roy Bean who often sits over there—it means that you take the onus of proof from the plaintiff and put it on the defendant. That is pretty much the layman's explanation. It is about as good as I can do because, unlike Judge Roy Bean, I am not a barrister—

talk.start.para: —You are a lay person.

—Yes, I am a lay person. It is the lay persons within this country that deserve a proper explanation from the minister on the onus of proof. If you read the minister's statements as he has gone around the country, it has been fairly clear that the minister does mean taking the onus of proof from the plaintiff and placing it on the defendant. But unfortunately for the minister, who is in El Desperado straits to try to get something right—he promised Australia the review of the print media ownership laws and failed there—this is his last stand. This is like Richard Custer's last stand: he has to get the parallel import restrictions up.
—General Custer.

—General Custer's last stand. The problem for the minister, Senator Alston, is that the Attorney-General's department came before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee last week and said in their submission, both verbally and in writing, that `the new section 130A'—which the minister seems to place so much credence in—`will not reverse the onus of proof. The government has not asserted to the parliament or to the public that it will.' That is very clear. Yet the minister today said, `Oh well, Attorney-General's has got it wrong.'

speech.para: I am sure the legal and constitutional committee will be very keen to hear about that because this whole process is not only a mere bagatelle show. I have often heard Senator Alston described as a doormat. Well, in this case maybe marshmallow might be more applicable. He is just whiffling up a long, dark alley in this case because he is not going to get parallel import restriction legislation up.

The minister will not get it up by trying to deceive the Australian public by telling them something that he cannot do. Attorney-General's has clearly put the case before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in legal terms—which may be a little bit above the minister—but at least they have tried to do it for the lay people. They have made it categorically clear that the onus of proof will not be reversed as a result of the introduction of their legislation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being almost 7 p.m., we will move to the consideration of committee reports and government responses.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 2 March 1998, on motion by Senator Bishop:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak on the report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee on housing assistance. That report was tabled at the conclusion of the business of the Senate last December, and this is the first opportunity that honourable senators have had to address the content and recommendations of the report. I can say that it is a report of substance and certainly not from a group of bagatelles.

speech.para: As I said in my tabling statement earlier this week, the committee took evidence and submissions on this topic right throughout 1997. At all stages of the committee's deliberations, there was extensive interest in the progress of the committee's work. The committee received over 300 submissions, re ceived evidence from some 47 organisations and some 82 witnesses, and inspected a number of community organisations in Canberra. Many of those submissions were lengthy and of a high quality. Certainly they could not be described as being mere whiffle. I particularly refer to quality submissions from the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute, the Australian Institute of Family Studies, the National Community Housing Forum, the Australian Council of Social Service, the New South Wales Department of Urban Affairs and Planning, the New South Wales Department of Housing, National Shelter, the Community Housing Federation of Australia and, finally, the Department of Social Security.

The submissions and evidence from representatives of these organisations or agencies were notable for a range of different reasons. Some of those reasons in the reports were that they contained considerable intellectual rigour supported by useful economic analysis of a particular argument, the outlining of philosophical viewpoints, and the benefit to the community from part or whole adoption of a particular course of action. There was succinct evaluation of other submissions, often putting a contrary viewpoint to that of the majority of submissions received by the committee. The objectives of different states which have implemented responsibilities in the area of public housing and public housing assistance were outlined to the committee, particularly by New South Wales.

In total there were some 24 recommendations. Whilst all recommendations of committees are important, some do have more consequence than others. In this context, I identify recommendations 1, 5, 6, 11, 19, 21, 22, 23 and 24 as being of particular note. Those nine recommendations fit neatly into three subgroups: firstly, recommendations of current levels of public housing stock and adequate planning for the future, recommendations 1, 5, 6, 11 and 19; secondly, the importance of community housing and community based organisation, recommendations 21 and 23; and, thirdly, the role of finance and the private sector in the ongoing provision of low cost housing, after lengthy discussion, recom mendations 22 and 24. I now wish to address briefly each of those subgroups and offer a few comments.

The first subgroup of recommendations goes to the issue of public housing itself. In the postwar years, the social role of public housing has been both essential and critical to the ongoing development of this nation. Paragraph 2.5 of the report outlines some of the historical developments that led to very high levels of home ownership in this nation, and the committee notes that those housing policies have served well the majority of the population of Australia. In this context, recommendations 1, 5, 6, 11 and 19 highlight the critical role of public housing and its maintenance at minimum of current levels, the need for ongoing research and the worth of proper planning and accountability measures.

The second subgroup of recommendations, recommendations 21 and 23, go to the role of the community housing sector. Community housing is defined in the report from one of the submissions as being `publicly subsidised non-profit housing which is not publicly managed'. The report goes on to state:

The two most common forms of community housing are housing cooperatives, in which new tenants take full responsibility for all of the management decisions related to the properties under their control: and secondly, housing associations, in which tenants are encouraged to participate on a board of management, which in turn takes responsibility for that housing decision making.

Chapter 6 of the report outlines the benefits of a continuing role for community housing. Those benefits may be summarised as it caters to niche markets, single parents with children, disabled persons and those in need of support services. Community housing develops, as its name suggests, a sense of community within the affected community. It offers choice for those of a low income with special needs. Considering the background, recommendations 21 and 23 are particularly appropriate.

The final subgroup of recommendations are those numbered 22 and 24, which address the role of the private sector and accessing of finance. In this country, as in most OECD countries, we will shortly enter a sustained period of oversupply of capital in worldwide markets. In a recent edition of the Economist there was a table of future likely bond issues by national governments. The table demonstrated that a range of OECD national governments are, in an unprecedented fashion, reducing their issues of debt. Because of this, there will be significantly less demand for government bonds. As governments dramatically reduce future issues of debt, balance budgets and the like, the price of capital—that is, interest rates—will also decline as we have seen it do in this country in more recent years.

With less competition in capital markets, continuing increases in national savings pools and an overall decline in interest rates, there will exist an opportunity for other players to enter the market and secure long-term bonds at low interest rates to fund their particular cause, interest or whatever. In this context, recommendations 22 and 24 have particular immediate appeal as they, if given effect, will facilitate the entry of community organisations into capital markets.

Work obviously needs to be done with a range of financial institutions to work out the details of appropriate packages that will suit the varying needs of a range of financial institutions. Those institutions are obviously going to be looking for security for their investments and guarantees of returns over 10-, 15-, 25- and 30-year periods if they are going to be issuing bonds that are going to be utilised to fund the development of community housing. In this context the discussions at paragraphs 6.37 and 6.56 set out a number of signposts which might assist the entry of a range of players into this market.

In summary, as my earlier tabling statement this week says, the committee believes that all governments need to investigate ways of facilitating private sector involvement in low-cost housing and of increasing the capital available for all those housing projects. Current national government policies of massive debt reduction and likely reduced future bond issues do give an opportunity for new methods of low-cost housing development. In conclusion, I commend the report to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I would also like to speak to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee report on housing assistance, which was tabled in the break between sittings. It is a report of substance, as Senator Bishop, the chair of that committee said. It took over 300 submissions and had three fairly extensive days of public hearings in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. It is a pity it did not get up to Queensland and into the regions a bit, but I recognise that you cannot go everywhere.

speech.para: Housing is obviously a fairly fundamental and crucial need. It is an issue that I think does not get as much attention from governments at all levels as it should. It is something that impacts fundamentally on every Australian at the most basic level. There are lots of issues in the housing area around Australia that need addressing and this report has identified a good number of them. In the short time available to me I will not be able to go into full depth in relation to all that is contained in the report, but I would like to highlight a few issues that come from it.

One of the issues, which was touched on earlier on today as part of the motion that was debated during general business, relates to the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. In recent weeks before the Senate resumed sitting I spent a bit of time travelling around regional parts of Queensland and meeting with groups involved in the housing area, the people involved at the coalface who are having to work with the real issues that are facing people.

It is very clear that there is a lot of concern in the non-government housing sector in relation to even just the direction of housing policy in Australia. At one level there can be criticism about the content of the policy, but when it is not even clear what direction it is going in, then that is a great cause of concern for those people who put so much time and effort and so much of their lives into trying to assist people in the area of housing.

The lack of clarity about the direction of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement is something that is of great concern. That spills over into things such as funding—reliability of funding, the scope of funding for various organisations and the adequacy of funding, whether it meets the needs that are out there in the community. I think all those issues are of great concern to people working in the non-government sector in the housing area. I am sure that a lot of those concerns were raised during the committee hearings that were held. They were certainly raised with me in parts of Northern Queensland.

In Cairns, for example, I was fortunate enough to attend a meeting of the local Cairns housing network. A lot of those sorts of issues were raised—not just the adequacy of funding but the adequacy of assistance from levels of government and the inability of government to understand the needs of the community and the needs of the community sector in working with people in the housing area. Whilst things can never be perfect, I think there is a long way to go in terms of recognising and giving the community more flexibility to address the needs that are there. I think the committee's report identifies some of those issues and goes some way towards addressing them.

I would like to draw attention to the minority report of my colleague Senator Lyn Allison, who was the Democrats' representative on this inquiry. The Democrats initiated this inquiry into housing assistance at the end of 1996. We believed that the model of housing reform proposed at the time by the Howard government would not address the growing housing crisis within the community.

I hope this report does go some way towards developing a greater recognition about the need to change directions. Certainly there has been a lot of changes since that time at state and Commonwealth levels in terms of the direction of housing policy, partly in terms of deciding not to go down a particular path but not necessarily being much clearer about what other paths we will go down instead.

The issues highlighted in the Democrats minority report relate to the area of Commonwealth-state responsibilities and, again, the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. It is an essential framework for a national housing policy. The Democrats strongly believe that, for that policy to operate at its maximum effectiveness, we really need a more clearly defined nationally agreed housing strategy that has clearly defined proposals and specific outcomes. This would help the Commonwealth government not only in terms of its responsibilities at the housing level but also in terms of having more consistency and clarity of the focus of housing policy across the states.

The majority report incorporates what the Democrats regard as the central features of such a strategy, which would include the continuation of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement and recognising that both levels of government have an important role to play in that. However, we are concerned that there is no specific framework which unites all the various factors into a single, comprehensive and cohesive national housing strategy. It is still somewhat disparate and fractured. The Democrats believe that that can be a hindrance to a housing strategy and a housing policy that has maximum effectiveness.

One of the recommendations in our minority report is the establishment of a housing task force to assist with the development of a national housing strategy, particularly recognising the important role that local government can play, as well as the community sector, in both policy development and implementation of a housing strategy. Whilst it may not be appropriate for local government or local government associations to be a formal partner in the Commonwealth-state housing agreement—and its involvement is by no means uniform across the country and its input in the housing area varies enormously—we certainly believe that, if local government did have a strong involvement in the development of a national housing strategy, this would be a great contribution to a clearer national housing strategy.

As part of that, there is always a need for consultation with the community. As I mentioned just before, one of the strong issues that kept coming up at a meeting with housing groups recently in northern Queensland was the disconnection that the community and people working on the ground in the community feel with not only the development of housing policy but also the implementation of housing policy and the sometimes inflexible and unhelpful implementation that occurs through the state government housing departments.

Certainly, there is disquiet in terms of the changes in Queensland with the Queensland government in relation to the operation of public housing in that state—changes which will affect people in terms of having not only to pay higher rents but also reduced security of tenure. Obviously, security of tenure is very much a crucial issue for people. There is nothing much more important than feeling secure about your own home, and it is something that the Democrats believe needs much greater attention.

Similarly, residential tenancy laws in the private rental sector vary enormously from state to state and across the territories. Again, the Democrats believe that we should be setting a national set of benchmarks. I believe the report also touches on this area in terms of agreed standards of tenant protection across the states and of having not necessarily uniform legislation but uniform bottom line protection which all legislation has to embrace.

I would like to mention briefly another issue concerning private tenancy which also came up at the consultations I had in Rockhampton as well as Cairns—the issue of privacy and the development of tenant databases. I believe it is something that is going to be a growing problem. As the Senate would know, the coalition came into government with a commitment to extend privacy legislation to the private sector. It has decided not to go down that path now. Some of the problems with not doing so are arising and this is one area where I think problems will arise more quickly than most.

Basically, privately operated tenancy databases that record so-called bad tenants exist now—a tenant black list, if you like. People can be put on these lists without their knowledge, sometimes completely unjustifiably. They can then have major problems in accessing rental accommodation, often not even knowing why they may be having a problem. They have no legal right to access their information, even if they are aware that they are on those databases. They have no right to demand the correction of incorrect information. That is something the Democrats are greatly concerned about and something which we believe needs more attention at both the state and federal level. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 2 December 1997, on motion by Senator Calvert:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I take this opportunity to make a few observations about the report of the Joint Publications Committee on the future of the parliamentary papers series. The report was tabled on 2 December last year. The report was made in response to a request for advice from the Presiding Officers on a proposal to discontinue the series. Before directly addressing the detail of the report, I should like to make some general remarks about the Publications Committee and the parliamentary papers series itself.

speech.para: The committee was first established in 1970 to replace the then Printing Committee. Its establishment resulted from a recommendation of one of the most influential but perhaps little known committees of the parliament, the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary and Government Publications, which reported to the parliament in 1964. That committee, commonly referred to as the Erwin committee after its chairman, the Hon. Dudley Erwin, made 67 recommendations, including recommendations for the establishment of the Publications Committee, the Australian Government Printing Service and government bookshops. It also made important recommendations in relation to the parliamentary papers series itself, the subject of the report being debated here tonight.

The select committee's recommendations and their ready acceptance by the Presiding Officers and the government had a major influence on government publishing in Aus tralia. One knowledgeable commentator has written that:
.. the ultimate reward of an enhanced level of political education and political participation . . . in the Australian electorate is not the least of the blessings to flow from the Irwin committee.

Honourable senators will know that on the second Thursday of every sitting fortnight, the publications committee presents to the Senate a report in which it recommends that a number of documents be printed. That represents the committee's necessary routine work. Occasionally, however, the committee presents special reports, such as the one tabled in December. Four of the 10 special reports presented since 1970 have concerned the parliamentary papers series.

The parliamentary papers series consists of those documents presented to the parliament which are ordered to be printed by either chamber. Parliamentary committee reports, annual reports of government agencies and other reports tabled pursuant to statutory requirements are included in the series. The parliament, when it determines that a document is to be included in the parliamentary papers series, ensures that it is produced in sufficient numbers for the needs of parliamentarians and the electorate and that it is deposited in major libraries in a numbered and indexed printed series for easy retrieval by researchers and the general public.

Professor Finn Crisp, who gave evidence at an inquiry into the parliamentary papers series almost thirty years ago, stated that publication of the series enables the general public to understand the transactions, discussions and concerns of parliament and its committees, and assists the rising generation of Australians to understand the nature and purposes of parliament, its transactions and discussions and the issues it is confronting and dealing with. It could also be argued, as it was by a witness during the committee's recent inquiry, that the continued publication of the parliamentary papers as a set and their preservation through deposit in libraries are important elements in the Australian parliament ensuring and maintaining the accountability of the executive to the parliament.

Why then was it proposed to discontinue the series? The Presiding Officers stated, when seeking the committee's advice on the proposal, that most documents included in the series now receive wide circulation outside the series, that many are available in other than hard copy and that the costs to the parliament of maintaining the series, much of which consists of publications of the executive government, was unjustifiable in a climate of financial constraint. The Presiding Officers assured the committee that, if the parliamentary papers series were discontinued, they would ensure that distribution of significant parliamentary publications would be maintained but the onus for the distribution of executive government documents would be with the executive. The committee, having considered the Presiding Officers' proposal, resolved to conduct an inquiry into the future of the parliamentary papers series so as to obtain the views of interested parties, not only within the parliamentary departments but also throughout the wider community.

During the inquiry, the committee received 58 submissions, many of which came from libraries or from the academic community. Public hearings were conducted in February and September 1997. The great majority of submissions and the bulk of the oral evidence supported the continuation of the parliamentary papers series in its current form.

During its inquiry, the committee focused on two main issues—firstly, whether electronic printing and publishing have now reached such an advanced stage that a printed parliamentary papers series is no longer needed and, secondly, whether there are other more effective or more economical ways of disseminating and preserving for the public the major documents presented to parliament. On the first point, the evidence demonstrated that, despite advances in electronic publishing and dissemination, there remains significant problems to be resolved. Foremost among these is the limited access to the Internet of the public, and even many libraries. The Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), when responding to the committee's invitation to make a submission to the inquiry, stated that, while he supported the use of technology to reduce costs, he was mindful that access to the Internet and other on-line technology is limited in our community. He asked the committee to consider that issue during its deliberations.

Another major problem with electronic publishing is the archival limitation of electronic copy. The committee concluded on the basis of the evidence that on-line technology is not now a suitable substitute for a printed series. The committee also concluded, however, that government agencies should be encouraged to publish their documents electronically. It has therefore recommended that agencies which do not produce documents for the parliamentary papers series in this form should advise their reason for not so doing in their letters of transmittal to the minister. The committee intends to monitor progress in this matter and to report on progress in 12 months time.

On the second point—that is, on whether there are suitable alternatives to the parliamentary papers series—the committee considered a proposal put forward by the Department of the House of Representatives. Briefly, this involved extending the current library deposit scheme to disseminate all the documents now covered by the parliamentary papers series and adapting to the new scheme an index already produced for all tabled documents. The Department of the House of Representatives stated that the proposed scheme would improve on the current parliamentary papers series in a number of respects, such as in the more timely dissemination of publications. The department observed, however, that steps would need to be taken to ensure that documents in the scheme were identified and numbered and that sufficient numbers of copies were provided for the scheme by authors. On this latter point, the department suggested that it might be necessary for the parliament to legislate to require agencies to make sufficient copies of their publications available.

The committee, having considered this and other proposals, concluded that the proposals were not sufficiently developed and that further investigation is required. The committee has recommended, therefore, that the parliamentary papers series should continue in its present form until there is a viable alternative in electronic or printed form, but it has also recommended that the Presiding Officers establish a working party to explore further the proposals made by the Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate for possible alternatives to the series.

During its inquiry, the committee also investigated the administration of the current scheme and has made a number of recommendations relating to distribution and to the provision of documents by agencies. Government agencies are obliged to produce 250 copies of certain of their publications—usually their annual reports—for the parliamentary papers series. From time to time, some agencies have not fulfilled this requirement, which has resulted in unnecessary administrative expense—and occasionally printing expense—for the Australian Government Publishing Service and the parliamentary departments.

The failure of agencies to provide copies for the series was identified during the committee's inquiry as a failure of the series. The committee does not agree but is concerned that the failure of some agencies to provide copies of documents for the series, if allowed to continue, would adversely affect the value of the series. The committee has written to ministers to remind them of agencies' obligations and will present a report to the parliament every 12 months identifying any agencies which are in default.

Finally, I would like to thank the other members of the joint committee for their assistance and support during the inquiry and in drafting the report. I should especially mention the contribution of Mr Lou Lieberman and Senator Jim McKiernan, also the secretary of the committee, Mr Terry Brown, and committee staff. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 2 December 1997, on motion by Senator Carr:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: —I rise in respect of report No. 5 from the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled The Implications of Australia's Services Exports to Indonesia and Hong Kong and the government response. The reason I rise is that, when I looked back at the original report—and this is the concern that I have—I noted that this report spanned two parliaments, the 37th and the 38th parliaments. I noted from the report that there was a substantial change in the membership of the committee over that period, and the hearings spanned from 1994 to 1996.

speech.para: I do not know if the government's response is the right response because they are dealing with the difficult situation that, firstly, the report was a long time being compiled and, secondly, the circumstances moved extra fast in this area. One could say that the original report, if one looks at it, was deficient in the fact that it ignored our involvement in APEC, it ignored our future and developing role in APEC and, therefore, our role with Indonesia and also with Hong Kong. I think the government's response has failed to pick that up.

talk.start.para: —It is a load of whiffle.
—One would not whiffle about this, Senator, if one took it very seriously. One would note that we are dealing with a major meltdown crisis.
—Marshmallow.
—No, it is not marshmallow either, Senator, and you know that. It is a very serious crisis.
—It's a lemon!

—It is not even a lemon. One would not even say it was a bagatelle of small trifling matters. It is a very serious issue that we are seeking to address, and the government's response has failed to deliver on addressing this report.

speech.para: In the contemporary circumstances that are before us, we now have the Asian meltdown crisis—Indonesia, of course, being one of the worst affected. We are seeing Austrade now making a response, but one thinks that we are seeing a response that should have been better prepared by the government. Of course, if we look at the difficulties that we are confronted with, we see in the nation of Indonesia itself—and I want to focus on Indonesia—a likelihood that we are going to see internal turmoil as a result of the impositions placed upon that nation by the IMF. One would have hoped that we would see a fairly proactive role by the Australian government in ensuring that the average ordinary Indonesian was not brought to their knees by the action of the IMF.

One has to be fairly critical of the government in one area where I believe they have failed and failed dramatically—that is, the area of aid through a mixed credit scheme, which proved invaluable to the Indonesian nation. This scheme was unceremoniously dumped by the government not long after they took office. It provided a forum and an opportunity for small to medium exporters to get a toehold in Indonesia. If that scheme had not been dismantled back in 1996, Australian companies with very innovative products would now be very well placed to take advantage of the meltdown crisis that has occurred. Instead, we are now trying to fight our way back into the Indonesian market where we have missed opportunities through the actions of this government.

So the government response not only to the report but also to the crisis in Indonesia has been abysmal, to say the least. One would have hoped that there would have been a more proactive and more deliberative response in this particular instance. Of course, Indonesia will play a significant role in our development into the future, as will the other Asian nations. But it is unfortunate that we see the report tabled in 1996 and then the government response, albeit belated. We have had all these events happening in the meantime and life has passed this government by. We need a more effective and efficient response coming out of this government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
