talk.start.para: —Order! Consideration of committee reports having now concluded, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I wish to take a few moments of the Senate's time to discuss the question of airline passenger security—a matter very close to the hearts of honourable senators because we spend a lot of our time in the air. Australia is a signatory to the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation. The convention agrees on world international airline legislation in order that international civil aviation may be developed in a safe and orderly manner and that international air transport services may be established on the basis of equality of opportunity and operated soundly and economically.

speech.para: Australia is not obliged to put any of the legislation in place for domestic air transport. Countries make their own judgments on what legislation is to apply domestically. Over time, Australia has chosen to implement some legislation domestically, particularly in relation to large aircraft. On a cost versus risk basis, it has been a decision of successive governments not to take security measures down to small aircraft. Whilst most senators would applaud airline passenger screening as an anti-hijack measure and passenger baggage reconciliation as a standard anti-sabotage measure, few senators would be aware of the passenger numbers to which these regulations actually apply.

The Air Navigation Act 1920 as amended determines that on domestic flights passenger screening only applies if a regular public transport aircraft is fitted to carry 100 passengers or more. The security systems for screening and clearing passengers and airline personnel travelling from major Australian airports have been in place since the mid-1980s. The last hijack occurred in 1986 and the official viewpoint is that screening has had a significant deterrent effect since that time. Travelling from regional Australian airports, some operators have chosen to implement the screening of passengers and their possessions but others have not. In these instances, up to 100 passenger could be technically at risk.

Similarly, the Air Navigation Act 1920 as amended determines that carriage of baggage regulations apply to an aircraft fitted to carry 38 passengers or more. Under section 22C(8) of the act, if a person whose baggage has been accepted by an aircraft operator to be carried on board an aircraft has disembarked from the aircraft or has not boarded the aircraft, the operator of the aircraft must remove the baggage from the aircraft before the aircraft starts its flight. This section therefore applies only to aircraft fitted to carry 38 passengers or more and prompts the observation that legislators believe it is all right to blow up fewer than 38 people but more than that number is not on.

Sabotage is presently unknown in this country. With greater risk from exposure as a result of world events, Australia must consciously work to ensure that this perfect record remains intact. The Sydney 2000 Olympic Games are almost upon us. It would indeed be prudent to review the regulations applying to airline passenger screening and passenger baggage reconciliation before the massive influx of people expected for this event of international significance where terrorist activity has, unfortunately, carved a path into its history.

I take this opportunity to welcome a re-evaluation of the floors pertaining to passenger numbers under sections 20 and 22 of Air Navigation Act 1920 and recommend that they be reviewed downward, especially in the light of the strengthening international focus on Australia and Australia's increasing significance on the world stage.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in the adjournment debate about an issue that has arisen in Western Australia in the last few days. It is something that I think may well be unique in the history of television broadcasting in Australia. At midnight on Saturday, 28 February the Golden West Network television station, which covers most of outback Western Australia and many small to medium sized regional towns, went off air while people were watching it. This did not happen to those in the main towns like Kalgoorlie, but to those who rely on having the signal sent to them by satellite system either direct to an outback farm or station or to a smaller town where it would be picked up by the dish, put through the black box and then rebroadcast by a very low powered transmitter to the local town.

speech.para: I stand to be corrected, but since we have had television operating in this country I have not heard of any other example of this happening. There are some suggestions in the Western Australian press that, at midnight on Saturday night, as many as 100,000 viewers lost the signal, and it has not been restored. It will not be restored, according to a statement by the ABA, until the middle of next week at the earliest.

This has all come about because there was a change in GWN's transmitting technology. They changed from using Optus's analog satellite to a digital system run by Telstra. That is fine, but when you change from analog to digital, unless you have a black box that is digital, you cannot pick up the signal.

Well back into last year, this move was going to occur. The government announced a major program of subsidising the replacement of analog black boxes with digital black boxes to the tune of $11,200,000, of which $8 million would come from the Networking the Nation fund. This was done as a special deal, I think, under the influence of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), who was trying to find a way to make people less upset about having to pay the cost of a black box conversion or a new black box, which could be as high as $1,500. The subsidy was to the tune of about $700 per black box.

That was put into place last year, and the minister made a generous statement about how wonderful it was to reach this agreement to make the money available. What he forgot to do, on the day of the agreement with the Golden West Network, was to ensure that, if it was going to change from analog to digital, those that had not until that stage transferred over to the new digital black box could still get the analog signal. But because Optus, Telstra and the television station played hard ball with each other, when it was changed to a digital system with Telstra, Optus and the Golden West Network could not reach agreement to continue the arrangements for a limited period, in order to continue the analog broadcast.

In a statement today, the ABA indicated that they knew this was going to occur some time last year unless action was taken. The ABA has informed me that, under section 212 of the Broadcasting Services Act, they have the power to give special exemption to Optus to rebroadcast GWN's network signal on the analog for a period of time so that people could still receive the transmission. However, that was never taken up. Optus did not approach the ABA, apparently, until late last week, when it was much too late.

I point out that yesterday the minister issued a statement criticising Optus, Prime and Telstra over this satellite switch-off. But in the statement there is no mention that the ABA, given fair warning, could have allowed Optus's analog signal to continue. He said in his statement yesterday:
We—
that is, the government—
have at all stages in this process encouraged the commercial parties concerned to take the necessary steps to ensure that regional Australians did not suffer.
He also said, way back on 25 November, on this same issue, when he announced that the money would be made available through the black box conversion program, as it is called:
After long and extensive negotiations with the carriers, Telstra and Optus, the government has ensured that viewers in remote areas will receive a full suite of services from a single set-top box.

The problem is that the minister did not follow through to ensure that in the change-over period there would be dual broadcasting of both digital and analog so that this situation, whereby up to 100,000 Western Australian regional viewers now have a blank television set, did not occur.

This minister was far too lackadaisical for far too long, because advice was available from the ABA that this would occur. He could have, at the very least, suggested to Optus months ago that they apply immediately to the ABA to get an exemption under section 212 of the act. He did not do that. I do not know what his discussions were; the extensive negotiations with carriers clearly meant that he did not understand what he was doing. That is probably the most charitable description I can make of his incompetence.

This minister now has the record, as far as I am aware, of being the first communications minister in the history of Australian television broadcasting to allow a television network to go off air, to the detriment of many tens of thousands of viewers in a particular area of Australia when it could have all been avoided. This is another example, in our view, of the slapdash, lackadaisical attitude this minister has to the task of ensuring that Australians receive the best communications system that they are entitled to receive under the legislation which this parliament has carried.

I hope that the people in regional and remote areas of Western Australia, when they are looking at their blank screens, remember the name of Senator Richard Alston, the communications minister. If he had been on the ball, they would have been able to watch programs tonight, tomorrow night and over the weekend. They would not have to wait until some time next week at the earliest—the middle of next week, if they are lucky—to get their programs back on.
If people do not think it is serious, today I received a letter from the Shire of Yalgoo addressed to me and signed by the Chief Executive Officer. It reads:
I advise that we are still unable to obtain a commercial Scientific Atlanta decoder, and GWN terminated its B-Mac signal from Optus B3 satellite at approximately 1.30 a.m. yesterday.
The letter is dated 2 March. It continues:
This means that this community is presently without a service (as are all other communities around here).
Believe me, we are not well pleased!

Here is a letter saying that they have lost their service. The problem with the lack of planning by this minister is that, even if they want to get the new decoder, they are not available. This, again, is a terrible indictment of this minister's lack of ability and lack of planning. The minister is to be condemned for another disaster in a series of disasters that he has inflicted on the communications industry in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Recently I received an invitation from the Maritime Union of Australia. I was particularly keen to accept it because it is not every day that I receive an invitation to meet with a trade union, especially given the unfortunate histories of some trade unions which, in the past, have come through the front door of this place even when the door has been closed. The invitation which I happily accepted gave me the chance to raise some very important questions about how our Australian waterfront should be managed and by whom.

speech.para: Today, I met with members of the Webb Dock's new peaceful assembly. Last week I believe they were known as the picket line. It gave me the chance to ask them why they believed they were entitled to have so much say in the selection of people who staff our waterfront and to ask why they do not see the new Webb Dock trainees as prospective new members of their union and not as the advance guard of the working class war.

They told me that they have already been active on the Webb Dock recruiting members. In fact, they have signed up a couple, a choice they are perfectly entitled to make and, of course, the new trainees are also perfectly entitled to choose to do. But I wanted to know why it was that they insisted on performing all the functions on the wharves such as security, maintenance and other ancillary functions, and why they have not allowed these activities to be contracted out to some of the specialists in those fields. In other words, why do not wharfies want to do what wharfies do best, or what they say they do best—that is, stevedoring and seafaring activities?

Their answers to these questions were both informative and enlightening and I would like to share them in this place tonight. Apparently, wharfies cannot outsource activities because wharfies are a totally integrated work force. They say, `One minute we are doing security functions and the next minute we are climbing up a crane somewhere.' I wanted to ask them about the poor record of security on the wharves, to get them to tell me why it is that up to 78 spare wheels roll off the dock when they are not attached to a vehicle. It intrigued me that they would want to carry the can for such a questionable record on security.

Interestingly enough, they told me that pilfering on the wharves is not a big issue and that they got blamed for everything. But I still could not understand, in spite of that, why they would let themselves become the guilty party, why they would carry the can for that security.
But most of all I wanted to ask the wharfies about their public relations campaign and to learn from them what they were doing to turn public opinion around.

I must declare immediately an interest here. I have a longstanding interest in public affairs management and I had it long before I came to this place. So I wanted to ask the delegation why it was, when the first shots went over the bow of the good ship MUA, that they allowed such a negative image to be portrayed in the media—the lawless, angry mob—notwithstanding the spitting, the name calling and the stone throwing. I could not believe that this professional group of a totally integrated work force could have allowed that to happen. They agreed with me that it was regrettable that some of the boys had got a bit carried away, but they explained that it was `very hard to stage-manage that stuff'.

One of the delegates told me today that he was proud of the discipline shown by his fellow wharfies and of how they conducted themselves on that very important first day. I can only say that Australians must be incredibly proud of such effective crowd control. Thank goodness they are not down at the footie grounds.

All of this happened before the MUA hired a public relations company to develop a communications and marketing strategy and to brush up those negative perceptions that are around in the community. So what intrigues me now is why that public relations company allowed the boss of the wharfies, John Coombs, to be filmed last Sunday night, strolling around the chardonnay grapes growing on his lifestyle hobby farm. I just cannot see how that communication marketing strategy is going to help turn around the negative perceptions of these working-class heroes. Could this footage of John Coombs strolling around those chardonnay grape vines and frisking around on his horse really be the working-class warrior that we know him to be?

I was prompted to ask: if wharfies can be farmers, why can't farmers be wharfies? Indeed, why can't anyone be a wharfie? Why can't they apply, like anybody else, to work on the waterfront? Provided, of course, they undertake the necessary training and pass the necessary tests, why can't they join that totally integrated work force on our waterfront and then have the choice to join or not to join the MUA or any other relevant union that they might choose?

The delegates told me that they were worried that those people currently undergoing training on the Webb Dock will not be allowed their basic freedom to choose to join—the freedom of association rule—or not to join a union and that, in some way, those new recruits on the Webb Dock will be financially coerced not to exercise their freedom of choice. In fact, the delegates told me that they were worried that they will not even have the opportunity to explain the benefits of joining the union to those training on the Webb Dock. I certainly hope that is not true.

Every Australian worker now enjoys the right to choose to join or not to join a union, free from coercion and free from compulsion, in the factories, on the farms or at the waterfront. That is what our government, along with the Labor Party's newest recruit, Mrs Kernot, has delivered for all workers. That is why in this place our legislation passed with the consistent support of those Democrat colleagues whom she has now so dramatically deserted.

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to talk about the issue of the parallel importing of CDs. During question time today the minister responded to a question put by me on this issue but, because of the tactics employed by the government following question time, we did not have the opportunity to take note. The issue of parallel importing of CDs is quite a critical one, particularly for young people of Australia who do spend a proportion of their income or their available funds on music.

speech.para: The issue I would like to speak to tonight relates specifically to a strategy that has been developed by the Department of Communications and the Arts to counter what they have described as a `campaign by the industry against the government's policies.' The draft strategy for an information campaign on sound recording prices has been prepared for the minister, and funding has been achieved as one of the first steps in this strategy, which is to conduct research. This research, on behalf of the government, is designed to establish whether or not there is a need for an ongoing information campaign and focus on the general public to help determine attitudes to the government's decision.

So we are dealing with a publicly-funded information campaign designed to foster and promote support for a current government policy—not a current government initiative, not anything that has passed through this parliament, but to support the view of a government that is currently engaged in a political and a public debate. And that issue is of course the parallel importation of CDs.

The government has long contended that this will result in some reduction of prices in CDs but it has as yet been unable to convince the industry sector—and certainly many people in Australia—of the virtues of their policy. I suppose if you look at it cynically it is no surprise that they have now come to find the solution to their political problem in a $750,000 information strategy on which they will embark—if it receives the appropriate levels of approval—within the next few weeks, the period of time leading up to when the legislation is scheduled to be dealt with in this place.

I ask this question: is this a justified use of taxpayers' money? Is the public funding of an information campaign, designed specifically to support the government's political arguments during a public debate, a legitimate expenditure of taxpayers' dollars? I contend that it is not; and that what we are seeing is taxpayers' money subsidising part of the Liberal government's political campaign.

The issue of the cost of CDs and parallel importation of CDs has been framed by this government as being simply one where their policy equals cheaper CDs. This is patently false. One of the reasons the government has found itself in a position where it needs three-quarters of a million dollars to support and sell its own policies is that they cannot justify that claim.

Many contributions on the part of the minister have repeatedly referred to statistical information about the cost of CDs overseas and the relationship with the cost of CDs here—information that cannot be substantiated. In fact, what I have found is that the minister has contradicted himself on a number of occasions when he has tried to argue and specify just what those costs are and how his policy would be implemented here.

I would like now to turn to this draft strategy for an information campaign prepared for the minister by the Department of Communications and the Arts. It has some interesting features that I think are worthy of being placed on the public record. One feature is who is targeted by this information campaign. The target market reads as follows: the general public, broken into market segments based on research results; CD retailers; independent and small record companies and performers, artists and composers.

But it goes on. The target market also includes government backbenchers, the media, and consumer organisations and related bodies. So this publicly-funded information campaign is designed to convince the government's own backbenchers of the worthiness of their particular policy. It certainly does raise some questions about Senator Alston's ability to convince his own rank and file of the merits of the position they are pursuing.

Let us turn to another interesting feature of this particular document: the communication mix. What we are talking about here is a proposal for a $600,000 advertising campaign. And it has listed the national press, Arts on Friday, the Weekend Australian, the Contemporary CD Review, all the major state and territory newspapers, no less than about twenty regional press outlets from New South Wales and, systematically, each regional newspaper from every state.

Then we turn to the section where they target editorial or `free publicity' as it is in brackets. They will attempt to organise interviews, primarily with the minister, on Triple J—look out Mikey and Jen on the breakfast show; you are about to get bombarded with requests from the minister's office so he can come on and justify his policy on the parallel importation of CDs—the ABC, major commercial talkback stations, Recovery, and the summer edition of the 7.30 Report. But Recovery is a classic example. I can see the minister making a real impact there.

The timing of this particular strategy is also worth while looking at. The contract, that has already been let and is contained within this proposal worth $73,000, sits about a third of the way down the list of the program. It is all designed to culminate in the advertising campaign in late March and April. We did hear at estimates just the other day that the legislation was due to arrive in this place in the May sittings.

All these questions about the probity of this particular campaign need to be answered by the minister. To simply rattle off `cheaper Cds, cheaper Cds, cheaper Cds' is not going to convince the young people of Australia that this government's policy is worth sacrificing our music industry for. As so often with Liberal government policies, one of the effects of these harebrained ideas that cannot be justified in terms of the final effect on consumers is that a major sacrifice is made by Australian industry. We know, and we have heard so much evidence before the various committees of this place, that the Australian music industry stands to be decimated if this particular policy of the government goes through.

So, Australians—young Australians, in particular—beware. You are about to be bombarded with a $750,000 information campaign, courtesy of Senator Alston, at your expense. It will tell you through postcards in cafes, through the regional press and through all the youth cult media outlets that they can possibly access, that their policy is right. Meanwhile, you will hear a voice from Labor and you will hear the voices of many Australian artists saying that the government's policies will do untold and devastating dam age to the Australian music sector. That is a price that I believe is far too high. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Because people have dropped off the list tonight, or have made short speeches, an opportunity has arisen for me to say one or two words about a person who was mentioned earlier this week and who became a very good friend of mine in the last few years. I refer, of course, to the late Roger Shipton.

speech.para: I listened to the very generous contribution of Senator Robert Ray from Victoria the other evening. He delivered what I think is one of the best obituaries I have heard in this place in the 10 years I have been here. Senator Ray is from the other side of politics and I think it shows the character of the man that Roger Shipton was that a person of the stature of Senator Ray delivered such a generous and heartfelt obituary. In a few words he summed up the person that Roger was:
He was honourable, gentle, urbane—a Liberal in the true Whig tradition. He was a good listener who provided wise counsel when necessary, and he always thought the best of people.

That is, in fact, exactly as I knew Roger. I got to know Roger particularly well after he left politics. He used my whip's office as a depot when he was here in Canberra doing the rounds of his many clients. He certainly gave give me wise counsel. I found him to be a very generous person and I treasured his friendship. You get to meet a lot of wonderful people in politics, but Roger Shipton was a true gentleman by any stretch of the imagination.

I am very privileged to have spent New Year's Eve and New Year's Day with Roger, his wife Suzie and James, Katie and Richard. I will always remember those days. I was most distressed when I heard that he passed away on Monday, 19 January.

Roger had a very keen interest in the Interparliamentary Union, of which I was a member for three years. We had many discussions about international affairs. He obviously had a lot of friends and contacts overseas because of his association with the United Nations, where he did an absolutely fantastic job.

I think Robert Ray summed up a lot of Roger's life. On this side of politics, we treasured Roger's friendship, we admired him as a person and we found him to be a very loyal person and colleague. His friendship is something I will not forget in a long time. I am pleased to say that my association with his widow Suzie, his son James, his daughter Katie and his son-in-law Richard will continue. In fact, I hope to meet them this weekend and I hope that our friendship will continue. We will always remember Roger for what he was—a true gentleman and a wonderful friend.

talk.start.para: —I also rise to say a few words about Roger Shipton and to join Senator Calvert in his remarks. Roger was somebody I knew as a friend when he was a member of parliament. When he left this place, he remained a friend. I believe he became a very good lobbyist on behalf of different industries when he came back here. He very often visited in that capacity, both when I was in opposition and since we came to government.

speech.para: It is not often you can say that you have got friends in politics, but the friendship that we had when he was in politics and the friendship that we retained afterwards is something that I very much respect and enjoyed. I know my wife joins me in extending our condolences to Sue, James and Kate on his sudden passing. I believe that he will be very much missed, not only by his family but also by those of us who regarded him as a friend. He will be missed because of the very many happy times we had together, and he will also be missed because of the good lobbying he did in this place on behalf of many industries.

talk.start.para: —I am sure that the whole of the Senate shares the sentiments expressed by Senator Calvert and Senator Brownhill.

subdebate.1.para: The following documents were tabled by the Clerk:

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Indigenous Policy and Advisory Structures
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1048)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 19 December 1997:

question.para: (1) Has a review of Commonwealth Indigenous policy and advisory structures been established; if so, why.
(2) (a) What are the terms of reference for the review; and (b) which individuals or agencies provided advice on the terms of reference before their finalisation.
(3) (a) Who is conducting the review; (b) under what statutory or contractual basis is the review being conducted; and (c) to whom does the review report.

(4) (a) What is the contracted cost for the review; (b) how much has been paid to date; (c) what is the contracted term for undertaking the review; (d) which agency is paying for the review and is this being done under ministerial direction; and (e) which agency is responsible for managing the contract.
(5) What consultation have taken place or will take place, while the review is being undertaken, with; (a) indigenous groups or individuals; and (b) Commonwealth departments or agencies.
(6) Has the review provided any reports to date; if so; (a) what conclusions did the review come to; and (b) what did the review recommend.
(7) Will the complete results of the review be made public; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is:

answer.para: (1) There has been no review of overall Commonwealth indigenous policy and advisory structures but there has been a review of existing arrangements for the provision of policy advice and support to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs
(2) (a) A copy of the terms of reference is attached
(2) (b) The Office of Indigenous Affairs and ATSIC were consulted about the terms of reference.
(3) (a) The review was conducted by Mr Rae Taylor with assistance from Mr Thaddeus Leach
(3) (b) and (c) Messrs Taylor and Leach were engaged as consultants by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, to prepare a report for consideration by the Department and me as Minister.
(4) (a) The total cost was $43,203
(4) (c) The review was completed on 8 December
(4) (d) The review was funded by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet under normal consultancy contract arrangements
(4) (e) The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet
(5) A range of current and former officials of ATSIC and of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet were consulted plus myself, my predecessor and the current Chairman of ATSIC
(6) The review concluded that current arrangements are unsatisfactory and canvassed a range of possible alternatives which are currently the subject of consideration
(7) The complete report will be made publicly available once the Government has completed its consideration of the matter.
APPENDIX I
REVIEW OF POLICY STATEMENT ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE MINISTER FOR ABORIGINAL TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS
Terms of Reference

The review will examine the current arrangements for the provision of policy advice and support to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and propose any changes to these arrangements, which would lead to the provision of more effective support to the Minister. In particular, the review will consider:
(a) the current roles of ATSIC and the Office of Indigenous Affairs (OIA) in providing policy advice and support;

(b) the extent to which existing arrangements provide the Minister with expert, independent and impartial advice; c) possible administrative arrangements for providing such advice and support to the Minister. Arrangements for the Review

The review will be undertaken by Mr Rae Taylor with the assistance of a reference group comprising Dr Peter Shergold, Public Service Commissioner; Ms Patricia Turner, Chief Executive Officer of ATSIC; Mr Bill Blick, Executive Co-ordinator, Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet; and Mr Greg Hunting, Chief of Staff, Office of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

The reviewer will undertake the review over the course of 4-5 weeks through discussion with the key stakeholders (the Minister's office, ATSIC and PM&C) resulting in the preparation of a report containing key findings and recommendations.
The review will provide a report to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs by 29 November 1997.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minster for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, on 1 October 1997 (Hansard page 7332):

question.para: (1) Is the government aware that in the US and Canada it is estimated that more than 10 percent of students are affected by specific learning disabilities such as dyslexia and dysnomia.

(2) Minister, what research has your government undertaken to determine the number of Australian students who have diagnosable learning disabilities and how many children in Australia are affected by attention deficit disorder and other disadvantages which cause learning difficulties.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Government is aware of estimates of numbers of children in Australia with attention deficit disorder, dyslexia and other learning disabilities but does not accept that these students cannot meet minimum standards if appropriate strategies are used to meet the needs of every child.

In setting the National Literacy and Numeracy Goal: That every child leaving primary school should be numerate, and able to read, write, and spell at an appropriate level and sub-goal: That every child commencing school from 1998 will achieve a minimum acceptable literacy and numeracy standard within four years , Ministers in the Ministerial Council for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) noted that a small percentage of the total school population does not have the cognitive capacity to process linguistic information in print necessary to become literate. For these students, who general attend special schools, it is recognised that the minimum acceptable literacy and numeracy level by Year 3 may not be realistically achievable.

(2) According to research conducted by Professor Peter Hill of University of Melbourne, about 2% of the total school population do not have the cognitive capacity to process linguistic information in print necessary to become literate. Generally, these students attend special schools.
Of students attending mainstream schools, Professor Hill's research indicates that:
. 80% of students can achieve an adequate level of literacy when provided with quality teaching in their first year at school;
. 18% require one to one intervention to reach an average literacy by year 3; and
. 2% require intensive intervention and an individual learning plan in order to reach a minimum literacy standard by year 3.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer on 3 September 1997, (Hansard page 6294), a question without notice:

question.para: Whether the Government's policy of not compensating for legislative changes will apply to the GST, if it is introduced, thus ruling out any proper compensating reduction in the income tax payable by families.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: There is no inconsistency between the Prime Minister's statement on tax reform and the response from the Treasurer to your earlier question concerning the youth allowance.
The Prime Minister has clearly indicated that, for any option for reforming the taxation system, there should be appropriate compensation for those deserving of special consideration.

There is no such analogy with decisions that reduce entitlements to benefits (as referred to in your earlier question). As previously indicated by the Treasurer to the honourable Senator's earlier question, the Government does not have a policy of introducing concessional tax treatment to the taxable income of those who may lose entitlements to benefits. This would seriously undermine the effectiveness of the changes intended to those outlays programs.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer on 23 September 1997, (Hansard page 6716), a question without notice:

question.para: Will the consequent outlays, of a family affected by changes to the youth allowance, be regarded as tax rebatable under the taxation system and, if not, why not. Further, the honourable senator asked would he be able to get a response to this prior to discussing this legislation in the chamber.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: There is no inconsistency between the Prime Minister's statement on tax reform and the response from the Treasurer to your earlier question concerning the youth allowance.
The Prime Minister has clearly indicated that, for any option for reforming the taxation system, there should be appropriate compensation for those deserving of special consideration.

There is no such analogy with decisions that reduce entitlements to benefits (as referred to in your earlier question). As previously indicated by the Treasurer to the honourable Senator's earlier question, the Government does not have a policy of introducing concessional tax treatment to the taxable income of those who may lose entitlements to benefits. This would seriously undermine the effectiveness of the changes intended to those outlays programs.
